column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113984,2023,BIM Company-based Research Project,"Engels, Nederlands","Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. D Tsekouras'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The BIM Company-Based Research Project (CRP) allows students to replace one free elective course in the program with a full-time thesis / research internship for one of the elective blocks (minimum of 168 hours). During the remaining two elective blocks, the student is recommended to continue working part-time and follow the remaining electives.

The BIM CRP should seek to combine the writing of the thesis with an internship at a company during one of the elective blocks (Blocks, 3, 4, or 5). It is therefore important that the internship is related to the thesis and students will need to decide on an internship in consultation with their thesis coach and the master thesis coordinator. Students must be able to show that the internship will allow them to collect company-specific data (for that specific company), and that it is essential for their thesis project.
The CRP will be assessed separately from the thesis (on a pass/fail basis) by the thesis coach, company supervisor and master thesis coordinator.

If a student opts for the CRP, it will count as a free elective for 6 EC. This will give them the opportunity to work exclusively within the company for a period of 7 weeks. Thesis internships may be agreed for a longer period of time, but a minimum of 168 hours is expected and a maximum of 6 ECTS is credited. During the remaining two elective blocks, the student is recommended to work part-time and follow the remaining electives.

THIS ELECTIVE COUNTS AS A FREE ELECTIVE FOR BIM STUDENTS ONLY. In order to graduate you MUST complete at least two other BIM Programme Electives! Please do not select this elective if you have not signed a contract yet.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Design and manage a small project to research or solve a practical business problem by using established techniques and insights of research
• Analyse specific challenges an organization is facing in the contemporary context
• Conduct a practical research project that addresses these challenges
• Present a well-structured, well-argued research project, its findings, and your own recommendations

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113985,2023,BIM Master Thesis,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. DK Zegners', 'dr. S Mehta', 'RM Silva, MSc', 'Y Kuper, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: During the year you will participate in a structured master thesis trajectory. You will start in September, during the core courses, to familiarize yourself with the research being done at our department and the relevant academic literature and topics available. Staff involved in this MSc will present their current research projects, and you will be invited to link your master thesis to one of these projects. Before Christmas you will decide on a final topic and be assigned a coach who is an expert in the subject area chosen. Early January a thesis clinic will provide you with the foundation that you will need to complete your thesis successfully. In February you will deliver your research proposal after which you will implement your research question and finalize your thesis before the summer. Staff and researchers will provide assistance by coaching you through the entire master thesis process.
The following themes are examples of possible BIM Master Thesis topics:

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The writing of your master thesis – the report of your scientific study – is the most important part of the Business Information Management programme. The master thesis is your opportunity to show your potential as a next generation manager. During this period, you will interact with internationally-recognized companies and well-known researchers in the field of Business Information Management.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113983,2023,BIM Research Methods,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. D Gutt', 'dr. D Tsekouras', 'prof.dr.ir. HWGM van Heck']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In today’s economy, data-driven decision making in firms increasingly replaces decision based on gut feelings. As data is becoming increasingly available for firms from sources both internal and external, the need to understand methods to process and analyze data grows steadily.

Therefore, this course will equip students with the necessary tools to extract knowledge from data to succeed in their master theses and ultimately conduct their own research. To this end, students will be introduced to the fundamentals of selected empirical research methods (case studies and econometrics) and selected types of data provenance (observational, experimental, and survey data). This lecture will follow a bootcamp spirit. Students will be familiarized with the basics to set the foundation for their future courses and theses. Some content might be familiar from undergraduate studies, but this will ultimately facilitate deeper comprehension.

Understanding these methods and data types will be essential for the students’ success in their master theses and, not only but especially, when considering pursuing an academic career after their master’s degree in form of a PhD. Students will have hands-on experience with data to acquire expertise in solving practical data-related issues. These skills are not only crucial to the success in this course but are valuable assets in other courses covering data analytics in their master’s programme as well as in their professional lives, of course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Describe different types of data and variables
• Illustrate data in different graph types and discuss advantages and disadvantages of the different types
• Analyze a given data set by selecting and applying appropriate statistical methods
• Demonstrate a wholistic view on research questions and the appropriate methodology to answer these questions

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: One of the reasons companies hire university graduates, is because of their academic posture. This includes a critical attitude towards what is presented as “the truth”, the ability to assess the quality of research presented to them, and the competence to study a phenomenon in a structured way. These same qualities are required of you as you design and execute your Master thesis project. This course will focus on the basics of conducting sound scientific research and writing a good master thesis. </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course students should be able to:

column2: • Create (plan & set‐up) a solid scientific research project and understand the key considerations in designing and implementing it.
• Formulate a sound research objective and research question for a research project in Business Information Management.
• Critically evaluate research in the area of Business Information Management and related fields.
• Conduct a literature review and collect, organize and interpret academic literature.
• Comprehend the research methodologies and develop the ability make an informed decision for a research methodology, appropriate for their research objective.
• Understand the foundations of academic writing and develop the vocabulary required to communicate their research.
• Write a sound proposal for an academic study.

column1: The Bachelor Graduation Project offers students guidance in formulating an appropriate and relevant research design, and in structuring and conducting research in the field of Arts and Culture Studies. After successful completion of the Bachelor Graduation Project, students are able to conduct a theoretically informed empirical study and provide an adequate report on their research and findings.
During the Bachelor’s Graduation Project, students are expected to perform the following activities independently, but under the supervision of a lecturer:
•             Demarcate and study a particular subject in the field of Arts and Culture Studies;
•             Formulate a relevant and appropriate definition of a problem and research question(s) that derive from this;

column2: • Formulate a relevant and appropriate research design;
• Formulate an appropriate method of analysis with an adequate reporting and analysis of the results;

• Write a thesis that adequately describes the entire research process, from formulating research problems, creating a theoretical framework, describing the chosen methodology and methods, and provides clear arguments for analyses, results, and conclusions.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>During the Bachelor Graduation Project, students demonstrate and combine the knowledge and skills acquired during the three-year BA program, or one-year premaster program, in the form of a bachelor thesis. Students learn how to formulate and design an appropriate research study in the field of Arts and Culture Studies.</body>

column1: The final product of the Bachelor Project is the bachelor thesis: an individual research report of maximum 8,500 words (10,000 including cover page, table of contents and appendices). Students choose a thesis topic from one of the themes offered. The themes correspond to the content of learning paths in the Public Administration programme.

An introductory session will be held in period 6. During this session, the structure of the Bachelor Project will be explained, and the themes will be presented. The tutorials and supervision for the Bachelor Project will subsequently start in period 7. At least 1 tutorial group consisting of approximately 8 students will be established for each theme and these groups will be supervised by lecturers affiliated with a particular theme. Supervision usually takes place in (smaller) thesis groups consisting of around 4 students. In total, eight sessions have been planned (not including the introductory session).

Admission to the Bachelor Project course is only possible after the student has fully completed the Bachelor 2 (see article 4.2. of the Education and Examination Regulations). Students who do not meet the admission requirements, but still wish to take the Bachelor Project course, will have to submit a request to the Examination Board asking for permission to take this course (see Canvas, Contact: request form Examination Board). It is recommended that students submit this request before period 7 commences. The Public Administration bachelor programme (and therefore the Bachelor Project) must be successfully completed in full in order to gain admission to a master programme. Consult the Education and Examination Regulations (EER) for supplementary admission criteria for Public Administration master programmes.

• The student is able to design and carry out a public administration (social sciences) study and reflect on the research.
• The student is able to clearly report the research results in accordance with academic standards in a format that is accessible and understandable for academics and/or policy-makers.
• Based on a concrete scientific research project, the student is able to form an opinion and formulate recommendations.

column1: The bachelor’s thesis is an important assessment in the bachelor’s program because it tests the student’s ability to report about their own small-scale historical research. The bachelor’s thesis follows on the bachelor thesis class of a specific focus area. The bachelor thesis is considered as an independent course within the bachelor’s program. Students have to write their own thesis individually, although they can consult their supervisor by appointment. The different focus areas of
The bachelor’s thesis is an elaboration of the final paper of the bachelor thesis class. This implies that the students are asked to:

column2: • Expand their secondary and primary sources (e.g. longer period, more samples, broader geographical reach and/or a comparative approach).

• The student has to process the remarks of the teacher of the bachelor thesis class in the bachelor’s thesis. Students can find more information on the assessment criteria of bachelor’s thesis on MyEUR.

column1: Deadline: For students following the Bachelor Thesis Class in term 2; the thesis should be written in term 3.Theses that are submitted after the deadline will not be marked and will not get a re-sit opportunity.

The student is able to set up a small-scale research project under supervision. They can find and critically interpret different types of primary sources and engage with relevant secondary literature to answer this research question and they also are able to apply theoretical and methodological concepts in their research. Finally, the students are able to write an academic report about their small-scale research.</body>

column1: Students complete their Bachelor's programme by writing a Bachelor's thesis. Although the BA thesis is completed individually, students receive guidance while working on the thesis by means of a weekly thesis class, which starts in term 3 and continues into term 4. The classes are arranged around themes in accordance with the focus areas of IBCoM. In consultation with the lecturer, students develop a research question that is related to the wider theme of their thesis class.

The BA Thesis Class starts with a discussion of potential research subjects and addressing background literature as well as relevant research methods. The main part of the course concerns conducting the actual research. Students are invited to submit questions and to talk about the progress and results of their research.

The BA thesis is a reflection of the knowledge and research skills obtained in the field of Communication and Media. In addition, the BA thesis is designed to further train students' ability to develop, conduct and report on a theoretically informed, practically relevant, empirical study.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114697,2023,Bachelor Thesis Class Consumption, Material Culture and Globalisation",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['TJ Combrink'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Consumerism and mass consumption are often seen as linked to the industrial revolution and the rise of capitalism. Yet, early modernists have shown that consumption revolution(s) predated the industrial era, and rather coincide with the rise of global trade. Global connections affected consumption habits and related (material) culture on all side of the oceans. Think for instance of the spread of tobacco. In Europe, the new consumption culture is related to both the increasing popular consumption of ‘global’ foods and ‘new drugs’, such as sugar, tobacco, tea and coffee, and the increasing popular acquisition of objects, such as textile manufactures, china, furniture, toys like watches etc.

Providing for this rising consumption, new productive relations came in place that changed the world profoundly, such as Atlantic plantation slavery and industrial capitalism. Debates continue whether mass consumption was the result or perhaps rather a driving force of the development of capitalism, and of colonialism and their complex relationship. Eventually vast parts of society worldwide became occupied with organizing the rising consumption: from global production chains, to distribution, the emergence of shops and retail, branding, marketing and advertisement, packaging, delivering and finally with the disposal of its waste.

Do consumers have power? The relation between consumerism and environmental limits is a relatively new topic, but the morality of consumption is not. The symbolic value of consumption has been appreciated, used, and manipulated, both for political causes and for social stratification, identity affirmation or commercial ends. With the increasing centrality of mass consumption to our lives the term ‘consumption society’ came in use. French and Anglo-Saxon scholarship from the 60s onwards analysed how mass consumption interacts with cultural values and identities, especially through advertisements, marketing and the cultural industry.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students design their own (case) study within one of the following topics.

column2: • New or contested consumption: The spread of new consumption goods or habits, contest or conflict around new consumption. Topics can be related to

column3: • food history, fashion history, the history of drugs and intoxication

• sources may be: objects and material culture, images (drawings, paintings, photo’s), (databases based on) inventory records, published essays, ordonnances and documentation around regulation or taxation,
• places of consumption, f.i. (urban history of) retail (emergence of shopping streets, specific branches like take-aways, beauty shops

column2: • Work & waste: Social aspects of producing for, or cleaning after the consumer market.

column3: • Commodity history, commodity frontiers (f.i. the rubber rush)
• Slavery and other labour history
• environmental history f.i. waste; planned obsolescence; commodification of nature

column2: • Symbolic values and cultural frames of consumption and marketing,

column3: • Using decoding of advertisements as a method,
• looking f.i. at gender, race, nationalism or at innovations and sectors in transition

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114704,2023,Bachelor Thesis Class Disasters and History: The Vulnerability and Resilience of Past Societies,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. DR Curtis'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course focusing on economic and political history approaches, students are offered a new conceptual framework for understanding when and how environmental and biological hazards turned into disasters – and when and how this was prevented. Students learn that history is of great value for helping us understand the long-term economic and political consequences that very short-term hazards could create; and vice-versa, students learn that hazards, shocks and disasters can enrich our study of past societies by opening a window to facets of society hidden from view during “normal times”.

During the course, students focus on classifications and concepts such as “vulnerability”, “resilience”, “adaptation”, and “risk”, and apply these to their own historical case studies, which form the basis of a research proposal that will become the foundation of their BA thesis. Typical kinds of questions that students might want to address using explicitly historical approaches include: how do disasters affect state control of citizens, and how do disasters affect citizens trust towards governments? Do disasters make societies more unequal or equal? Who is to blame for disasters? Do disasters bring communities together or lead to discord? How disasters affect the relationships between states? Are we at greater risk in the age of the Anthropocene, or are we now more protected than in the past via science and technology?

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students will develop and write a research proposal as the foundation for their final BA thesis later in the year.
• Students will present their research ideas orally.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114701,2023,Bachelor Thesis Class Friendcraft: forging bonds of friendship in Politics and International Relations,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. Y van Hoef'],,"Inhoud
‘But when you talk about friendly relations in politics, it's not the friendship of schoolmates, of the Arbat’

Historians study both individual relationships, such as the famous friendship between Franklin Roosevelt and Winston Churchill, but also positive bonds between nations like the Special Relationship and Franco-German Cooperation. Others consider the role of networks and social movements, and friendships within civil society, even studying friendship within terrorist organizations. Many studies focus on how the meaning of friendship itself has changed through history, for instance how ancient friendship treaties that traditionally represented equality became treaties of subjugation, like those between the young US Republic and the native American nations. Other studies focus on processes of reconciliation, between France and Germany, but also between the latter and Israel.

In this BTC, the weekly class is divided in two parts. In the first part, we discuss in-depth 2-3 important contemporary articles by leading scholars on the subject, while in the second part we focus on a practical aspect of the thesis. In that way, you will gain both an in-depth understanding of the current historiography and of the most modern relevant methods of performing research for your own thesis subject.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

Intimately familiar with the leading works and authors in your own thesis topic
Able to produce a convincing and professional research proposal

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>When thinking about maritime history, one will in the first place think of ships and the history of the development of ships. But maritime history also is the history of overseas contacts, struggle between maritime powers over trade routes and colonies, the development of ports and the social conflicts there, the first contacts of Europeans with people from other continents and the position of sailors and their families. It therefore is about trade an trade conflicts, war and colonial expansion, the ideas of Europeans on people from Africa or Asia, on the position of these people when they came in a European port and racial conflicts in ports as shipowners preferred black people over whites as the former were less paid. On the position of women that had to raise a family without a husband as he lived on a ship or even died on sea, and as a consequence the quantitative dominance of women in sailor communities. Of course, it also is about sailing and trade and warfare on sea. In this course we will concentrate on a few aspects:

column2: • Economic aspects: The sea as a link between markets and the enormous growth of transport and ports in the last two centuries
• Political aspects: Ideas about controlling the sea as a method of controlling the world and the competition between the navies of major powers
• Warfare: Why were wars fought on sea, and why not?
• Cultural conflicts and racism: Ports as places where people from diverse background and colour met and the (race) conflicts that resulted from it.
• Women and the sea: how did women cope with the problem that they had to raise their families alone when the men were at sea.

column1: Note: the maximum number of participants is 12.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114703,2023,Bachelor Thesis Class Medicine, Health and Empire",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. SK Manickam'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The interventions, rationales and rhetoric of modern medicine and health are ubiquitous in our contemporary lives. Yet this particular present was very recent in its making. This course looks at the rise of ""medicine"" and ""health"" as objects of inquiry and government intervention, particularly in the colonial and imperial realms. Far from being neutral realms of knowledge, the formation of medicine and ideas of health are intertwined with social, economic and political stratification which are the result of local and global conditions with historical antecedents, often involving regimes of coercion and violence such as imperialism and the concomitants of modernization and globalization. Which groups were included or excluded from medical and health considerations in the past and why? How has imperialism in its various forms affected the cultures of medicine and health in diverse locations?

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: ‘Publics are queer creatures. You cannot point to them, count them, or look them in the eye. You also cannot easily avoid them. They have become an almost natural feature of the social landscape, like pavement’ (Warner 2002, 7).

What is a public sphere? How does the decision-making take place in public? How do common interests and collective ideas emerge? Who or which groups are in charge? How do social identities imprint on the formation of opinions and debates in public spheres? How can we understand and talk about alternative public spheres? In this thesis class, we invite you to research the changing perceptions of the public spheres in urban societies after the 18th century.

Due to modernization and bureaucratization, the post-18th century processes of decision-making and urban consciousness fundamentally changed. According to Jürgen Habermas, this happened along with the rationalization of public debates that formed an intermediate zone contesting the authoritarian regimes. However, scholars like Habermas offer us one perspective of how public opinions, collective attitudes, shared interests, and eventually urban changes are, in ideal terms, generated in the public sphere. What about the role of race, gender, religion, culture, or other factors in the formation of publics and counter or alternative publics? You may consider the diversity of factors and explore them through topics such as protest cultures, various forms of resistance, formation of counter-publics through popular and subcultures, processes of decision-making in transformation of public spaces or produce other topics fitting to this thesis class.

Students are expected to situate their research in the period from the 18th century towards more contemporary themes of the 20th century. Comparative and transnational approaches that go beyond the Eurocentric views and engage with more inclusive historiographies are welcomed and encouraged.

column1: The twentieth century witnessed a variety of international political and economic events and structural transformations that shaped the context which international actors had to deal with. This class concerns research on these various actors, ranging from businesses, non-governmental organizations, and communities, and how they were affected by topics such as war, economic recessions, pollution and climate change, protectionism, inequality and decolonization.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Twentieth Century International Business in Times of Political and Economic Crisis

The Twentieth Century was marked by a series of crises that changed the world. The First and   Second World War not only caused suffering and death on a scale hitherto unknown, they also profoundly changed the world in both a political and economic sense. The interwar period was marked by slow economic recovery, rising protectionism and a number of severe economic crises, both regional and worldwide. The Cold War prevented a return to the level of globalization that had been destroyed with the outbreak of the First World War. It was only with the end of the Cold War   that globalization would attain the levels it had at the turn of the century. Yet the nature of this late- twentieth century globalization - while very familiar in many aspects - was also very different from what had gone on before. The course allows students considerable leeway in examining how these events impacted international business both on the short and longer term, and particularly the economic and political consequences of both World Wars, the Great Depression, the Cold War, and Decolonization.
Note: the maximum number of participants is 12</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114702,2023,Bachelor Thesis Class War, peace, and the economy",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['L Zurné, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>With the onset of the Industrial Revolution, there also started a process of economic integration. This happens both on a large scale – e.g. globalization processes culminating in the first wave of globalization in the second half of the nineteenth century – and on a smaller scale – e.g. the Dutch and German economies, and what is commonly known as the transnational Rhine economy. Obviously, these are complex and broad subjects, so for your BA-thesis in this theme you should think about a subject that touches on an aspect of this. Below are just a few aspects that have sparked an extensive literature. Use one of these – or another aspect – as a starting point to come up with your own BA-thesis sized research subject:

column2: • Finance: trade needs to be financed, and international investments are a major part of economic globalization. The Dutch were major investors in nineteenth century American railways. Those same railways were part of the First Transport Revolution that caused an agricultural crisis in Europe and a shift in Dutch agriculture towards knowledge-, labor-, and capital-intensive types of agriculture. Money is important in other ways as well: both the reparations payments that France had to pay Germany after the Franco-Prussian War of 1870 and the reparations Germany had to pay the Allies after WW1 caused lasting resentment.
• Trade: trade is the most obvious way in which economies are interwoven. But how does that evolve, and why? How is that transported, what patterns emerge, how do they change, and why?

• International relations theory: the relationship between conflict and economic integration is a much-debated issue in international relations theory. Some argue that is brings peace, because war would interrupt trade, making it too costly. Others argue that the effects are the opposite: when economies become interdependent, this makes a country vulnerable. This could become a reason for the more powerful of the two countries to annex the less powerful country. You could use IR theory to study how disputes regarding trade or border issues are resolved, but there are many other possibilities.

column1: These are but a few examples of how economic integration can have unexpected consequences. I invite you to come up with subjects for your thesis that touch upon an aspect of this theme. Quantitative approaches are welcomed.</body>
At the end of this BTC you will be:

column2: • Skilled in the most modern methods of performing research in the humanities and social sciences

• Intimately familiar with the leading works and authors in your own thesis topic
• Able to produce a convincing and professional research proposal
• Perfectly primed for writing your BA thesis on a related topic

column3: Bachelorscriptie bouwt voort op de vakken Leeronderzoek I en Leeronderzoek II  uit Bachelor 2. Het grootste verschil met beide leeronderzoeken is dat in het Bachelorscriptie individueel verslag wordt gedaan van het uitgevoerde onderzoek. Tijdens het uitvoeren van het onderzoek kunnen studenten echter wel deels gezamenlijk optrekken. Sterker nog, in veel gevallen, zoals bij het verzamelen van data, is dat zelfs expliciet de bedoeling, omdat anders het tijdsbestek van dit vak te kort kan zijn. Het onderzoek wordt – net zoals bij de leeronderzoeken – intensief begeleid door een docent. Wat bij de leeronderzoeken – en methodologische vakken – aan bod is gekomen wordt voor het uitvoeren van dat onderzoek echter wel als bekend verondersteld. Het staat studenten natuurlijk vrij om weer bij de hoorcolleges van die vakken aan te schuiven om deze voorkennis weer op te frissen.

Dit vak beoogt studenten te ondersteunen bij de uitvoering van het onderzoek waarmee zij de Bacheloropleiding afronden. Van dit onderzoek dient verslag te worden gedaan in een bachelorscriptie, dat de vorm heeft van een onderzoeksartikel. Het vak bestaat uit zes bijeenkomsten waarin de studenten met de docent die hen begeleidt de voortgang van het onderzoek bespreken. De studenten voeren dit onderzoek uit aan de hand van een onderzoeksthema aangereikt in de vakken Modernisering 3: Beleids- en organisatiesociologie, Cohesion 3: Deviance en Identity 2: Politics and Society.

column1: • De student leert een sociologisch- of beleidsrelevante probleemstelling te formuleren die hij/zij beantwoordt door het uitvoeren van een kleinschalig empirisch onderzoek.
• De student leert gebruik te maken van theorieën door daar hypothesen of kwalitatieve onderzoeksvragen van af te leiden.
• De student leert op een verantwoorde wijze concepten te operationaliseren.
• De student voert zelfstandig empirisch onderzoek uit op secundaire of zelf-verzamelde data, daarbij gebruikmakend van de relevante methoden en technieken voor sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek.
• De student leert de sociologisch-theoretische waarde van haar/zijn onderzoeksbevindingen, alsmede de beleidsrelevantie daarvan.
• De student leert onderzoeksresultaten helder en logisch te rapporteren.

Er zijn verscheidene werkcollegegroepen, elk rondom een bepaald bestuurskundig thema. Studenten kiezen binnen het thema van hun groep voor een specifieke probleemstelling. De docenten begeleiden studenten bij de opzet en uitvoering van het onderzoek en bij het schrijven van het onderzoeksrapport. In de Handleiding staat beschreven uit welke thema's studenten dit jaar kunnen kiezen. In blok 6 zal een informatiebijeenkomst worden gehouden met uitleg over het Bachelorproject en de thema's. Studenten kunnen zich daarna aanmelden voor één van de groepen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Het Bachelorproject vormt de afsluiting van de Bacheloropleiding. De kennis, inzichten en vaardigheden die in de opleiding zijn verworven, worden nu toegepast, geïntegreerd en verdiept door een bepaald onderwerp te onderzoeken. Na afloop van het Bachelorproject kan de student:

column2: • De student is in staat om bestuurskundige (sociaalwetenschappelijke) theorieën en concepten toe te passen en te gebruiken om inzicht te verwerven in een bestuurskundig/sociaal fenomeen.
• De student is in staat om een concreet bestuurskundig (sociaalwetenschappelijk) onderzoek te ontwerpen, uit te voeren en hierop te reflecteren.
• De student is in staat om op academisch niveau en op heldere wijze te rapporteren over onderzoeksresultaten in een vorm die voor academici en/of beleidsmakers toegankelijk is.
• De student kan op basis van een concreet wetenschappelijk onderzoeksproject een oordeel vormen en advies formuleren
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>De volgende ingangseisen gelden voor het Bachelorproject (conform artikel 4.2 van het OER):   1. Toelating tot de onderdelen van bachelor-2 en bachelor-3 kan uitsluitend plaatsvinden nadat de student een positief bindend studieadvies heeft ontvangen.  2. Toelating tot het vak ‘bachelor thesis’, ‘bachelorscriptie’, ‘bachelorwerkstuk’, en/of ‘bachelorproject’ kan uitsluitend plaatsvinden nadat de student bachelor-2 volledig heeft afgerond.   Studenten die niet aan de toelatingseisen voldoen, maar toch het Bachelorproject willen volgen, moeten hiertoe een verzoek indienen bij de Examencommissie. Aan te raden is om dit ruim vóór aanvang van het vak te doen. Voor specifieke vragen kan men zich wenden tot mevr. Nathanja Boers via het contactformulier van het Onderwijsbureau Bestuurskunde en Sociologie.  De bachelor opleiding (en dus het Bachelorproject) dient succesvol te zijn afgerond om toegelaten te kunnen worden tot de master opleiding. Voor aanvullende instroomeisen voor de master, zie het OER.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

During the Bachelor thesis, students will work individually or in small groups on a literature review or an empirical study about a topic of their choice. Topics will be offered by the Psychology teaching staff. Teachers will supervise students during both the data/literature collection process, and the writing process. Furthermore, during the writing process, students will be supported through feedback from fellow students.

As a rule of thumb, literature reviews will include approximately 30 scientific references and will cover 20 pages (line space 1.5) or approximately 7000 words. This word count is excluding title page and references.
Empirical studies will include approximately 20 scientific references and will cover 13 pages (line space 1.5) or approximately 4500 words. This word count is excluding title page and references.

During the library practicals, students will learn to use advanced search techniques to find scientific information on a specific research question. In addition, students will learn to use reference software (RefWorks and Write-N-Cite)

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Being able to answer a research question based on empirical research or a scientific literature review is central to the Bachelor thesis. The Bachelor thesis is part of the academic writing trajectory, which is comprised of the following: year 1: Writing Skills I, year 2: Writing Skills II, year 3: Bachelor thesis, year 4: Master thesis. Within this trajectory, students first learn about basic writing skills (such as structuring paragraphs and creating links between paragraphs), after which they learn more advanced skills (such as sound argumentation based on scientific sources or data, as well as creating links between various sources). A second important skill used in academic writing is the giving and processing of feedback. Finally, a series of library practicals is featured in which students learn how they can systematically get an overview of scientific literature within a specific field of research.

column1: <body>This course aims at training and improving students’ academic writing skills and will result in an academic paper of 4,000 words (footnotes, bibliography and appendices not included). This course will guide students through the various stages of writing a larger academic paper, such as: finding and selecting relevant literature and sources; phrasing a research question; planning, drafting and revising the manuscript and using references. Attention will also be paid to research ethics and scholarly integrity. The tutorials will outline and introduce main issues of academic writing and will support the research and writing process. The final result of this course is a well-structured essay which answers a self-selected research question by means of a critical analysis of secondary literature. The paper is written in correct English or Dutch and uses correct references and citations.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• At the end of this course: students are able to search for and find relevant and credible secondary sources via the library resources and are able to explain their relevance in relation to their research topic by a.o. compiling an annotated bibliography.
• Students are able to write a well-structured, well-written and well-argued paper and compile (an annotated) bibliography according to the academic rules referring to the avoidance of plagiarism.

• Students are able formulate relevant and interesting research question and related sub-questions as well as identify and evaluate important historical debates that are central to their research topic.
• Students are able to design a structure for their paper and make a time schedule, making sure that they reserve enough time for researching, taking notes, writing, editing and final

• Students are learning to collaborate and are able to evaluate each other's work in a constructive way during the small peer review sessions; they understand how to use feedback to improve the quality of their work and they also learn how to work with a supervisor (prepare for meetings, use feedback).

column1: De scriptie draagt bij aan (een deel van) de volgende eindtermen van de bacheloropleiding. Studenten hebben kennis van:

column2: • Elke student werkt individueel aan de bachelorscriptie waarin hij/zij een pedagogische of onderwijskundige vraagstelling beschrijft en door middel van literatuuronderzoek of empirisch onderzoek de vraagstelling beantwoordt. Dit onderdeel bouwt voort op de ervaring die eerder is opgedaan in het curriculum op het gebied van schrijfvaardigheid. De student werkt aan de bachelorscriptie onder begeleiding van een interne of externe begeleider.

column1: De student kan kiezen uit twee vormen:

column2: • de literatuurstudie: in deze variant zoekt de student literatuur bij een pedagogische of onderwijskundige onderzoeksvraag en schrijft de student een reviewartikel. Het onderwerp van de literatuurstudie is gekoppeld aan de onderzoeksgebieden van de opleiding Pedagogische Wetenschappen.

• de empirische studie: in deze variant analyseert de student data en rapporteert de resultaten in een scriptie scriptie (als onderdeel van een onderzoeksstage). De student kan gebruik maken van een bestaande dataset en mag aanvullend zelf data verzamelen.

column4: De scriptie draagt bij aan (een deel van) de volgende eindtermen van de bacheloropleiding. Studenten hebben kennis van:

column5: de belangrijkste theoretische tradities, perspectieven en discussies binnen het domein van pedagogische wetenschappen (eindterm 1);
de geschiedenis van pedagogische wetenschappen en de relatie met culturele, sociale en politieke ontwikkelingen, zowel nationaal als internationaal (eindterm 2);
de pedagogische praktijk en tradities in verschillende niet-Westerse culturen die vertegenwoordigd zijn in Rotterdam (eindterm 3);

de belangrijkste theorieën binnen de aanverwante disciplines van sociologie, psychologie, kinder- en jeugdpsychiatrie, neurologie en filosofie en de relatie met pedagogische vraagstukken (eindterm 4);
modellen en methoden van preventie, diagnostiek en behandeling van pedagogische problemen en de pedagogische ethiek en wettelijke kaders die daaraan verbonden zijn (eindterm 5);
het doel, principe en de toepassing van wetenschappelijk pedagogisch onderzoek en, op elementair niveau, de huidige designs en methodes van sociaal wetenschappelijk onderzoek (eindterm 6);

de opbouw en structuur van het pedagogische beroepenveld en de daarbij behorende functies, werkterreinen en werkwijzen van pedagogen en onderwijswetenschappers, en ook van de ketenpartners, zowel op lokaal niveau (Rotterdam) als op nationaal niveau (eindterm 7).
een afgebakende pedagogische of onderwijskundige vraagstelling te formuleren en te beantwoorden (eindtermen 8, 9, 12);
literatuur selecteren op relevantie en wetenschappelijke kwaliteit (eindtermen 13);

verbanden leggen tussen bronnen, informatie uit verschillende bronnen integreren, tegenstrijdigheden, ontbrekende informatie en inconsistenties identificeren en bronnen kritisch beschouwen (eindtermen 13-15);
een samenhangende en heldere tekst schrijven (eindterm 15);
een wetenschappelijke schrijfstijl toepassen (eindterm 15);
een wetenschappelijke tekst schrijven met de juiste structuurindeling (eindterm 15);
zowel in tekst als in de literatuurlijst, refereren op basis van de normen van de American Psychological Association (APA) voor het gebruik van- en verwijzen naar bronnen (eindterm 15);
op een helder en sluitende wijze schriftelijk argumenteren (eindterm 15);
eigen werk kritisch beschouwen en op basis van feedback verbeteren (eindterm 15);
te reflecteren op hun wetenschappelijke schrijfvaardigheid en de feedback van een docent te hanteren en te verwerken (eindterm 18, 19);
vakinhoudelijke ontwikkelingen bij te houden (eindterm 20).

column1: In de stageperiode kunnen studenten verworven pedagogische kennis en vaardigheden toepassen in de beroepspraktijk. De beroepspraktijk is gevarieerd en een stage kan dan ook verschillende invullingen krijgen. De student kan kiezen uit twee vormen:

column2: De praktijkstage: Een praktijkstage houdt in dat je met een pedagoog of onderwijskundige meeloopt om zo een beter beeld te krijgen over de werkzaamheden en werkwijze van die instelling. Naast het meekijken is het ook de bedoeling dat je, onder begeleiding, leert om je verkregen pedagogische kennis en vaardigheden toe te passen in de praktijk.

De onderzoeksstage: Een onderzoeksstage kun je zowel intern (binnen de afdeling Pedagogische Wetenschappen) als extern (binnen een andere instelling of organisatie) doen. Een interne onderzoeksstage houdt in dat het onderwerp van het onderzoek is gekoppeld aan de onderzoeksgebieden van de opleiding Pedagogische Wetenschappen. Bij een externe stage werkt de student mee aan onderzoeksvragen die aangedragen zijn vanuit de externe instelling of organisatie.
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

de pedagogische praktijk en tradities in verschillende niet-Westerse culturen die vertegenwoordigd zijn in Rotterdam (eindterm 3);
modellen en methoden van preventie, diagnostiek en behandeling van pedagogische problemen en de pedagogische ethiek en wettelijke kaders die daaraan verbonden zijn (eindterm 5);
het doel, principe en de toepassing van wetenschappelijk pedagogisch onderzoek en, op elementair niveau, de huidige designs en methodes van sociaal wetenschappelijk onderzoek (eindterm 6);

de opbouw en structuur van het pedagogische beroepenveld en de daarbij behorende functies, werkterreinen en werkwijzen van pedagogen en onderwijswetenschappers, en ook van de ketenpartners, zowel op lokaal niveau (Rotterdam) als op nationaal niveau (eindterm 7).
onder begeleiding (diagnostische) instrumenten toe te passen, ook bij personen en groepen met verschillende culturele en sociaal-economische achtergronden (eindterm 10);

onder begeleiding en binnen een vastgesteld kader een onderzoeks- of interventie- of trainingsprogramma op het gebied van onderwijs- en/of opvoedingsproblemen op te zetten, uit te voeren en te evalueren, ook bij personen en groepen met verschillende culturele en sociaal-economische achtergronden (eindterm 11);
een wetenschappelijke bijdrage te leveren aan (het ontwikkelen van) beleid, de praktijk of onderzoek binnen een pedagogische context (eindterm 12);

op mondelinge en schriftelijke wijze wetenschappelijk verantwoord te rapporteren over plannen en onderzoek (zowel gericht op behandeling/interventie als op onderzoek zelf) en over daaruit voortkomende aanbevelingen, problemen en oplossingen (eindterm 15);
samen te werken en te communiceren met verschillende doelgroepen (zoals kinderen, ouders, leerkrachten, beleidsmakers en wetenschappers) (eindterm 16);

effectief en respectvol samen te werken en te communiceren met mensen vanuit verschillende achtergronden (zoals nationaliteit, cultuur, sociaal-economisch milieu en wetenschappelijke discipline) (eindterm 17);
te reflecteren op hun eigen competenties (en ontwikkeling hierin) en te bepalen waar hun persoonlijke leerdoelen en interesses liggen (eindterm 18);
feedback over hun werk te vragen, te ontvangen en op adequate wijze ermee om te gaan (eindterm 19);
vakinhoudelijke ontwikkelingen bij te houden (eindterm 20).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Dit vak draait in hoofdzaak om de publiekrechtelijke regulering van de bancaire sector. Het gaat over zogenoemd microprudentieel toezichtrecht en macroprudentieel toezichtrecht. Microprudentieel toezicht bevat regels die ervoor moeten zorgen dat banken financieel gezond (solide) zijn én blijven. Om financiële gezondheid te bestendigen, bevat het microprudentiële toezicht allerlei regels over risicobeheersing en andere regels met betrekking tot een goede besturing van banken (governance-regels). Macroprudentieel toezicht richt zich op de stabiliteit van het financiële stelsel. In het vak wordt ruim aandacht besteed aan de kredietcrisis uit 2008, maar wordt bijvoorbeeld ook uitvoerig stilgestaan bij klimaatrisico’s. En vanzelfsprekend zal ook worden nagedacht over de vraag wat een pandemie zoals Corona kan betekenen in de context van soliditeit en stabiliteit.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• De student begrijpt de kernfuncties van banken en kan uitleggen welke bijzondere soliditeitsrisico’s daaraan zijn verbonden.

• De student kan uitleggen wat onder financiële stabiliteit wordt verstaan, wat systeemrisico’s zijn en op welke wijzen banken deze risico’s kunnen veroorzaken respectievelijk daaraan onderworpen kunnen zijn.
• De student kan de redenen van prudentiële toezichtregelgeving overzien, mede in de context van het reduceren van de kans op respectievelijk het beteugelen van financiële crises.
• De student kan de diverse rollen van relevante internationale, Europese en nationale toezichthoudende autoriteiten duiden.
• De student ziet in welke dynamiek kan bestaan tussen regelgeving enerzijds en toezicht in de praktijk anderzijds en kan deze beoordelen.
• De student kan uit nationaal, Europees en financieel toezichtrecht de relevante prudentiële normen destilleren en complexe casusposities oplossen respectievelijk daarover adviseren.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructor: Prof. E.C. Perotti (UvA), Dr. S. Terovitis (UvA), X. Wang (UvA)

The course reviews the literature on financial intermediation and is relevant for students interested in finance, macroeconomics, and governance. It combines a classic contractual approach with recent work on system-wide risk creation. Drawing from the lesson of the crisis, it focuses on the risk transformation role of banks and shadow banks and the sources of endogenous credit cycles and instability. A key goal is to offer foundations for micro and macro-prudential policy reform, drawing from models of opportunism, risk externalities, or behavioral biases. Topics include debt optimality, moral hazard in risk choices, financial externalities, maturity and liquidity risk transformation, endogenous risk, induced runs, demand for safety, and their implications for capital and liquidity regulation.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students should have an understanding of, ability to apply, judge, and

column2: • The nature of financial intermediation in terms of its effectiveness of mobilizing resources while creating occasional instability
• Theoretical explanations for bank balance sheet structure, insight in the essential task of liquidity transformation
• Modern foundations of demand for safety as a driver of bank funding and instability
• The structural difference between banks and shadow banking business models

column1: Knowledge and understanding: Understanding the literature on bank monitoring, bank runs and demand for safety.
Application of knowledge and understanding: Identifying relevant policy and economic questions related to the role of banks, well-grounded in the literature
Making judgements: Ability to systematize literature in the field as well as to point out gaps and potential conflicts.
Communication: Write a structured and informed answer to specific questions on the practice and role of financial intermediaries.
Learning skills: Develop a set of research questions well-grounded in the literature, connecting it to other area of study such as macro and risk management.

column1: Why do financial intermediaries exist and what do they do? In this elective we examine the main activities of financial intermediaries, the related risks, and how these risks can be managed. Moreover, we will deal with specialized topics that have recently gained in importance, such as the role of banks in the green transition, credit risk transfer and fintech. Finally, we will consider the objectives and requirements of banking regulation, and discuss the challenges raised by recent financial crises and episodes of instability.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Recognize, understand and explain the key risks in banking
• Understand and apply modern analytical methods for bank management
• Understand and explain how regulation affects banks and what the limits to regulation are
• Be able to analyze the operation of a single bank in a systemic context
• Recognize, understand and explain recent trends in banking
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The Basestone Research & Writing Project brings together all skills taught in Quad 1 through 3. The aim of this course is to give the students an opportunity to perform a group research project to investigate a pressing societal challenge (i.e., the basestone), to summarise the results in a research report, and present the results of the project. In doing so, this course will help students further develop their writing and research skills that are needed to complete a basestone project. The course comprises a supervised research project supported and complemented by class and supervisory discussions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course will introduce you to the wide, beautiful and interesting world of chemistry. The purpose of this course is to provide a basic knowledge of fundamental chemistry, which can be applied in ensuing LSC courses, such as Biochemistry and Molecular & Cellular Biology. After completing this course, you will understand the periodic table including groups, compounds, metals and non-metals. You will learn about atomic and molecular theories, chemical reactivity and bonding, chemical equilibria, acids and bases theories, solutions, thermodynamics, nuclear chemistry and nomenclature of organic chemistry. Many examples will be drawn from chemical, biological, and medical applications to show you the connections between these scientific disciplines.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completing this course, you will be able to:

column2: • Explain what is atom and able to write electronic configurations of elements
• Explain what is the Periodic Table and name periodic trends
• Name ionic and molecular compounds and write their formulas
• Explain which type of bonding exist between chemical substances
• Understand the properties of liquids and solids
• Name types of solutions and calculate various concentrations
• Calculate different chemical quantities and apply them in the chemical reactions
• Distinguish among different types of reaction and balance chemical equations
• Explain what is the chemical equilibrium and relations between reaction rate and equilibrium constant
• Understand acids-bases concepts and calculate pH of solutions and dissociation constant
• Distinguish between oxidation and reduction reactions and be familiar with electrochemistry
• Understand basics of nuclear chemistry, types of radiation and nuclear reactions
• Classify and name organic and biochemical compounds and draw their structural formulas and isomers

column1: This 2-day course will explain basic concepts in human genetics and includes some history, basic knowledge of molecular biology, introduction to Mendelian and complex genetics, technical aspects and applications of sequencing and array technologies in genetics and the use of DNA technologies in society. Mendelian genetics will address different approaches to detect mutations in families segregating hereditary diseases, complex genetics will discuss the history and applications of genome wide association studies in populations.

This course is meant to give some introductory background for people wanting to start or become involved in such studies, or just wanting to know what it is all about. There is ample time for Questions and Answers during and after each talk.
The following books can used as reference books for basic knowledge of (molecular) biology (no need to read all of it beforehand):

column2: • ‘Genetics for Dummies’ (2nd ed.; T.R. Robinson, Wiley Publishing, Inc.; ISBN 978-0-470-55174-5, 2010)
• ‘Molecular & Cell Biology for Dummies’ (2nd ed.; R Fester Kratz, ISBN-10: 1119620406, Aug 2020)
• ‘Molecular Biology of the Cell’ (6th ed.; Alberts et al.; published by Garland Sciences; ISBN 978-0-815-34432-2, 2015)
• ‘The Problems Book: for molecular biology of the cell’ (5th ed.; W. W. Norton & Company; 5th ed.; ISBN-10: 0815344538, 2015);
• ""Human Molecular Genetics"" (5th ed.; Tom Strachan & Andrew Reed; published by Taylor & Francis Ltd.; ISBN-10: 0815345895, Dec 2018).

column1: This course is organized by the Graduate school in collaboration with speakers from Erasmus MC, AMC, NKI, UMCU, PMC and LUMC.
The course provides a comprehensive introduction to the field of basic and translational cancer research, including prevention and palliation.
The course is directed primarily at PhD students.
The program is set up logically in 5 steps, one step a day:

column2: Biology of the cancer cell, mitosis, genetic damage, repair
Epidemiology of cancer; prevention & screening, end-of-life interventions

column1: The program is enriched with 5 renowned keynote lectures followed by network lunch with the speaker. We strive for inclusion by the attendees via assignments, self-learning and interactive presentation to other participants and panel discussions.

During the course, we expect you to prepare a project pitch (Monday to Wednesday, 15:00h-17:00h), to be presented on the fourth day (Thursday) of the course. Four moderators will attend and comment the seven scheduled presentations/pitches.
How do you experimentally substantiate that the selected Cancer Hallmark has been listed as a hallmark?

In small groups, you will prepare a 5-6 power-point slide pitch for a project that aims to provide proof of the relevance of the selected Cancer Hallmark that explains its listing as Hallmark. Each group will be given a hallmarks selected by the course moderators. In the project pitch, the group will introduce the hypothesis, describe the research-based methods that will be used in the (hypothetical) project, and discuss (potential) outcome that support the given hallmark. Why does your potential result support that hallmark?

On Thursday, one member (appointed by the course moderators) of each group will pitch the developed project and will be given the opportunity to convince other attendees of the chosen approach. There will be a panel of 4 moderators joining the course attendees to ask questions and help the discussion (if needed).
The following Cancer Hallmarks will be divided over the groups:
The assignment will be further introduced to all participants on the first day.
Be sure to register at least one week prior to start of the course.
You will receive all details about the location and the final program for the course one week prior to the start of the course.

column1: This course will bring you across a journey that connects some of the most pressing challenges of our time with the basic knowledge in life sciences. For this, we will start by defining what ‘life’ actually is, and how it is organised. Specifically, the overall organisation of living organisms and their characteristics will be covered. We will zoom into the various classes of biomolecules and the way in which they are produced and metabolised within living cells. We will then focus on how life “works”, by discussing the fundamentals of DNA replication, the genetic code, cell division and genetics. Finally, we will zoom out and study the most vital aspects of the organisation of higher animals and plants and the evolution and ecology of living organisms on Earth.

column1: In dit blok staan drie groepen psychische stoornissen centraal die te maken hebben met de basisbehoeften van de mens: eten, seks en slapen. Eetstoornissen zijn de afgelopen decennia steeds meer voor het voetlicht gekomen. Zowel in de wetenschap als in de media wordt er relatief veel aandacht aan besteed. Maar wat is er nu eigenlijk precies over bekend?

Seksuele stoornissen zijn veelal een taboe voor de cliënt, maar zijn vaak ook voor de psycholoog niet het makkelijkste onderwerp om over te beginnen. Des te belangrijker dus om er in de Bachelor opleiding aandacht aan te besteden. Welke seksuele disfuncties kunnen we tegenkomen bij mannen en vrouwen, wat is er bekend over de achterliggende mechanismen, en hoe kunnen deze stoornissen het best behandeld worden?

Aan slaapstoornissen wordt in het psychologisch wetenschappelijk onderzoek nog relatief weinig aandacht besteed. In de praktijk is het echter één van de meest voorkomende stoornissen, die ook vaak als comorbide stoornis optreedt, en nadelige consequenties heeft voor ons psychisch- en sociaal functioneren. Voor een klinisch psycholoog daarom van belang om hier kennis over te hebben.

In dit blok komen van alle hierboven genoemde stoornissen de verschijningsvormen en theoretische verklaringsmodellen aan bod. Tevens wordt er aandacht besteed aan de verschillende behandelingsmethoden en de effectiviteit hiervan. Hoewel het zwaartepunt ligt bij dergelijke psychopathologie in volwassenen, wordt deze problematiek in kinderen en adolescenten ook behandeld in dit blok.
In dit blok wordt aandacht besteed aan de toepassing van theoretische kennis en richtlijnen in klinische situaties. Studenten werken daarbij in teams aan blokopdrachten.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: During this course, you will learn to:
1. Describe the core DSM-5 criteria for a variety of common disorders related to human needs: eating and feeding disorders, sexual disorders and sleeping disorders
2. Explain the development and course of key eating and feeding disorders, sexual disorders and sleeping disorders in children, adolescents and adults
3. Identify the presentation of symptoms in populations and communities (e.g. men, women, people with disability, gender and sexual minorities)
4. Evaluate evidence-based treatments for key eating and feeding disorders, sexual disorders and sleeping disorders
5. Analyze the interrelationship between eating disorders, sexual disorders, sleeping disorders and other (previously studied) common affective disorders
6. Utilize transdiagnostic frameworks of comorbidity in the context of eating disorders, sexual disorders and sleep disorders</body>

column1: Bayesian Econometrics plays an important role in quantitative economics, marketing research and finance. This course discusses the basic tools which are needed to perform Bayesian analyses. It starts with a discussion on the difference between Bayesian and frequentist statistical approach. Next, Bayesian parameter inference, forecasting and Bayesian testing is considered, where we deal with univariate models, multivariate models and panel data models (Hierarchical Bayes techniques). To perform a Bayesian analysis, knowledge of advanced simulation methods is necessary. Part of the course is devoted to Markov Chain Monte Carlo sampling methods including Gibbs sampling, data augmentation and Monte Carlo integration. The topics are illustrated using simple computer examples in Python which are demonstrated during the lectures.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The students learn the basics of Bayesian statistics (how to derive the posterior distribution)
• The students learn how to conduct Bayesian inference in econometric models.
• The students learn the concepts of Bayesian testing, point estimation and forecasting.
• The students learn how to interpret and use the outcomes resulting from the Bayesian analysis for decision making.
• The students learns the basics of simulation based inference and how to apply these methods for Bayesian inference in advanced econometric/statistical models.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Bayesian Econometrics plays an important role in quantitative economics, marketing research and finance. This course discusses the basic tools which are needed to perform Bayesian analyses. It starts with a discussion on the difference between Bayesian and frequentist statistical approach. Next, Bayesian parameter estimation, forecasting and Bayesian testing is considered, where we deal with univariate models, multivariate models and panel data models (Hierarchical Bayes techniques). To perform a Bayesian analysis, knowledge of advanced simulation methods is necessary. Part of the course is devoted to Monte Carlo integration using Importance Sampling and MCMC methods like Gibbs sampling, Metropolis-Hasting sampling, Slice sampling and Hamiltonian MC sampling, The course ends with variational Bayesian inference which allows for fast approximate posterior inference. The topics are illustrated using simple computer examples in Python which are demonstrated during the lectures.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1. Students obtain knowledge about the Bayesian view of statistics/ econometrics and understand the difference with respect to the frequentist approach.

2. Students understand the concept of prior specification, posterior inference, Bayesian testing and forecasting and can apply these concepts in univariate and multivariate regression models, panel data models and models with latent variables.
3. Students are able to use Bayesian analysis for problems in economics/ marketing/finance.

4. Knowledge of advanced simulation methods (importance sampling, MCMC sampling) allows them to implement a Bayesian analyses on complex econometric models in computer packages like Matlab R or Python.
5. Students are able to evaluate and criticize the statistical approach and results in scientific papers applying Bayesian econometrics/statistics.
6. Students are able to interpret the estimation results of Bayesian analyses, to apply these results for decision making and to communicate the results.
7. The content of the course provides students the ability to extend their knowledge about Bayesian econometrics after the course by reading advanced scientific literature.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112405,2023,Bayesian Econometrics in Finance,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. R Paap'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Bayesian Econometrics plays an important role in finance, where taking proper care of uncertainty is crucial for decision making. This course discusses the basic tools which are needed to perform Bayesian analyses. It starts with a discussion on the difference between Bayesian and frequentist statistical approach. Next, Bayesian parameter inference, forecasting and Bayesian testing is considered, where we deal with univariate models, multivariate models and panel data models (Hierarchical Bayes techniques). To perform a Bayesian analysis, knowledge of advanced simulation methods is necessary. Part of the course is devoted to Markov Chain Monte Carlo sampling methods including Gibbs sampling, data augmentation and Monte Carlo integration. The topics are illustrated using simple computer examples which are demonstrated during the lectures.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The students learn the basics of Bayesian statistics (how to derive the posterior distribution)
• The students learn how to conduct Bayesian inference in econometric models.
• The students learn the concepts of Bayesian testing, point estimation and forecasting.

• The students learn how to interpret and use the outcomes resulting from the Bayesian analysis for financial decision making. The applications include (i) predicting asset returns, (ii) portfolio optimization; and (iii) modeling and forecasting volatility in financial markets.
• The students learns the basics of simulation based inference and how to apply these methods for Bayesian inference in advanced econometric/statistical models.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this two-day course, students will be (re)familiarized with the basics of probability theory and introduced into Bayesian statistics. One of the main benefits of Bayesian statistics is that, in contrast to frequentist statistics and the null hypothesis significance test, it allows you to quantify the evidence in favor of the alternative hypothesis and the null hypothesis, thus distinguishing absence of evidence from evidence of absence. The students will be educated in the Bayesian alternative to standard statistical tests, such as the t-test and regression. A significant amount of time will be allocated to assignments and evaluation to ensure that the students receive hands-on experience with this approach to statistics. In addition, students can bring their own data to analyze under the supervision of the teacher.

column2: • Bayesian statistics makes use of a more intuitive form of probability. Namely, uncertainty instead of frequencies of values under a particular distribution (p-values).
• It can incorporate prior beliefs, knowledge, or results of parameters in the analysis.
• It enables comparison of the likelihood of the alternative hypothesis in relation to the null hypothesis as an odds ratio (instead of testing only the null hypothesis in frequentist statistics).
• Results are not based on unobserved data (Frequentist statistics assume hypothetical data under the null hypothesis).
• It is not influenced by sampling design.
• It allows for continual data collection until either the null or the alternative hypothesis is acceptably likely.
• Students will have a basic understanding of the basis and practice of Bayesian statistics and inference.
• They will know the basics of probability theory and the theoretical and philosophical underpinning of Bayesian statistics.
• They will be familiar with the Bayesian counterparts of basic classical tests, such as, linear regression, ANOVA, t-test, etc.
• They will have gained intimate knowledge of the software package JASP.
• They will be able to confidently use basic and more advanced statistical analysis using both frequentist and Bayesian statistics.

column1: Introductory knowledge of statistics is required and some knowledge of data analysis in a statistical software package (e.g., SPSS, R, Excel) is recommended.

Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course

This course includes mandatory attendance when registered. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points and the cancellation policy applies.

Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, participants may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Participants should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.

The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’.

Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years. On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.

Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided for PhD candidates and Research Master students. Other participants can e-mail the graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl to request a certificate after completing this course.

As an Erasmus MC PhD candidate, please ensure that the OSIRIS student number (the first six digits of the ERNA account) is registered in the Hora Finita account. This can be found under 'Research phase', 'TSP' tab, under the heading 'Education'. Please add the course using the course code to your Hora Finita portfolio. Once these two steps are completed the EC’s will be automatically transferred and approved.

Erasmus MC Graduate School PhD education is free of charge*. However, free of charge does not mean free of responsibility. Once you have signed up for a course or event, we expect you to attend. For every late cancellation or no-show, we have had to disappoint others who would have liked to join.
Please find the cancellation and no-show policy on STiP.
*A payment of €1.00 is required for administrative purposes.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Naast een algemene introductie in de uitgangspunten van de interne en externe verslaggeving, waarbij ook het jaarrekeningenrecht aan de orde komt, wordt tijdens het eerste deel van dit vak vooral aandacht besteed aan het boekhoudmodel. Geoefend wordt met het maken van journaalposten en het opstellen van een balans en een winst- en verliesrekening. Daarbij worden de verschillende onderdelen van de balans en de winst- en verliesrekening verder uitgediept: eigen vermogen, vreemd vermogen, opbrengsten en kosten. Er wordt gewerkt met verschillende methoden om in de onderneming aanwezige voorraden te administreren. Daarnaast wordt in dit deel geoefend met het opstellen van een kasstroomoverzicht. In samenhang met het voorgaande wordt ook aandacht besteed aan de financiële analyse van de onderneming.

In het tweede deel van het vak ligt de nadruk op de aansluiting tussen de bedrijfseconomie en het fiscale recht. Eerst komen daarbij de ondernemingen in groepsverband, de concerns, aan de orde. Geoefend wordt met het consolideren van jaarrekeningen, waarbij de balansen en winst- en verliesrekeningen van twee of meer ondernemingen worden samengevoegd tot één geheel. Hierbij worden ook de fiscale concernbepalingen behandeld. Daarna komen de verschillen tussen de bedrijfseconomische en de fiscale jaarrekening aan de orde, evenals de fiscale winstbepaling door middel van vermogensvergelijking. Ten slotte wordt aandacht besteed aan de verwerking van de belastingen in de bedrijfseconomische jaarrekening in de vorm van belastinglatenties.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Belastingheffing van ondernemingen vindt plaats op grond van de fiscale jaarwinst. Bij het vaststellen van de fiscale jaarwinst vormt de bedrijfseconomische jaarrekening meestal het uitgangspunt. Daarom is kennis en begrip van dit onderdeel van de bedrijfseconomie onmisbaar voor de fiscale praktijk.

column2: • Kun je journaalposten maken en een (geconsolideerde) balans, winst- en verliesrekening en een kasstroomoverzicht;
• Kun je een eenvoudige financiële analyse van een onderneming maken;
• Ben je in staat om de verschillen tussen bedrijfseconomische en de fiscale winst te berekenen;
• Kun je de belastbare winst en het belastbaar bedrag op basis van een vermogensvergelijking bepalen;
• Ben je in staat belastinglatenties te bepalen en deze te verwerken in de jaarrekening;
• Kun je fiscaal relevante berekeningen in een begrijpelijk betoog weergeven.
