column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115877,2023,Bewustzijnsfilosofie en Modale Logica,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. F Van De Putte', 'prof.dr. FA Muller']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: De cursus omvat twee luiken die enigszins op elkaar afgestemd zijn: een logisch luik en een systematisch luik. In het logische luik van de cursus staan de modale logica en haar toepassingen in de filosofie centraal, in de bewustzijnsfilosofie in het bijzonder. Modale logica voegt aan de klassieke logica operatoren toe die gelezen kunnen worden als noodzakelijk (of verplicht) en mogelijk (of toegestaan) en waaraan betekenis wordt gegeven in termen van mogelijke werelden. In het systematisch luik staan de centrale problemen uit de cognitie- en bewustzijnsfilosofie, zoals het lichaam-geestprobleem en het bewustzijnsprobleem, centraal, en worden mogelijke oplossingen vergeleken en beoordeeld, tegen de achtergrond van ontwikkelingen in de kunstmatige intelligentie, de brein- en gedragswetenschappen, de neurowetenschappen, en de psychologie.

Studenten mogen één werkcollege missen. Indien ze meerdere werkcolleges missen, moeten er ter compensatie opgaven gemaakt worden die bij het (de) gemiste werkcollege(s) horen en welke beoordeeld worden. Het tentamenonderdeel dat overeenkomt met de gemiste werkcolleges zal beoordeeld worden met het laagste cijfer behaald voor (i) de compenserende opgaven (ii) de tentamenopgaven behorende bij de gemiste werkcolleges.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1. De student is vertrouwd met de formele taal van de modale logica (welke naast de logische voegtekens  modale operatoren bevat), bekend met de (beperkte) uitdrukkingskracht van deze formele taal en in staat om alledaagse deductieve argumenten te vertalen naar de taal van de modale logica.

2. De student is vertrouwd met Kripke’s mogelijke werelden semantiek voor de taal van de modale logica en in staat om, gebruik makend van deze semantiek, (alledaagse) argumenten op hun geldigheid te beoordelen.

3. De student is vertrouwd met axiomatische afleidingssystemen voor modale logica's en is in staat om deze te gebruiken om aan te tonen dat een argument geldig is in zulke logica's. De student is ook in staat om aan de hand van de semantiek van modale logica's uit te leggen waarom een argument geldig is. De student is tenslotte ook in staat om, indien een argument ongeldig is, een tegenvoorbeeld te construeren aan de hand van de semantiek van modale logica's.

4. De student is bekend met verschillende interpretaties mogelijke van de modale operatoren (het is noodzakelijk dat / het is toegestaan dat / A weet dat / A gelooft dat) en in staat om uit te leggen welke modale logica’s meer of minder recht doen aan deze interpretaties.
5. De centrale concepten en thesen uit de hedendaags bewustzijnsfilosofie begrijpen en kunnen doordenken.
6. Begrijpen wat het geest-lichaam probleem behelst; velerlei oplossingen voor dit probleem kunnen vergelijken en beoordelen.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113982,2023,Big Data Management and Analytics,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. R Crisostomo Pereira Belo', 'dr. Y Zheng', 'L Punt, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The exponential growth in data generation and storage creates new business opportunities but also leads to major technical and managerial challenges. New tools, methods, and organizational changes are necessary to take advantage of these growing amounts data, popularly known as Big Data. Major determinants for the surge of Big Data include the amount of information generated on the internet, the evolving strategy of firms to collect data from sources both internal and external along the entire product and process lifecycle, the growth of social media, mobile applications, and the increasing availability of sensor based technologies.

This course will introduce students to what characterizes ""Big Data"" (e.g., volume, variety, velocity, and veracity) and to their main challenges. The course will cover the fundamentals of Data Science, including data preparation, modeling, evaluation, and deployment. Specifically, students will learn how to identify data problems and opportunities, and how to structure, design and deploy data-driven solutions that provide value to the business sector. Students will have hands-on experience solving practical cases using Big Data tools and technologies available in the market.
Your final grade will be determined based on one individual assignment, a group project, and a final written test, as detailed in the assessment matrix.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Describe the main steps of the Cross-Industry Standard Process for Data Mining (CRISP-DM)
• Distinguish among the four different Data Science methods covered in class
• Explain the main concepts and algorithms associated with predictive modeling
• Given a specific Big Data problem, apply the adequate Data Science method to solve it, and evaluate its performance (both practical and statistical)
• Using the frameworks discussed in class, recognize the ethical dilemmas in collecting and analyzing Big Data
• Evaluate the ethical position of a firm in a specific data collection situation
• Apply the Big Data tools architectural principles to formulate a solution for real-world scenarios

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116920,2023,Big Data and Business Analytics,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. DK Zegners'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: With the explosion of Big Data from social media and technologies, such as RFID, GPS, and sensor-data, organizations are increasingly confronted with the need to develop analytics capabilities to take advantage of their data. This gives many great opportunities to work on the cutting edge of science and business.

In order to design a practical Business Analytics application, we will explain throughout the course how to use the programming language and software environment R to collect, analyze, and visualize relevant data, be they publicly available data (social media or otherwise) or internal data from a company.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course will provide you with the knowledge and skills required to design and implement Big Data projects in organizations. Through practical, hands-on assignments, we will discuss:

column2: • Techniques for collecting and working with Big Data, especially online available (social media) data
• Quantitative analytics methods for analyzing and visualizing Big Data
• How to turn Big Data into practical decisions for management

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112245,2023,Bijzondere heffingen,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Economics,,['EG Borghols', 'EJ Monsma', 'LY Gramsbergen', 'mr. TC Hoogwout']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Nederland kent diverse bijzondere heffingen, te denken valt aan lokale en/of milieuheffingen, maar ook aan diverse specifieke Rijksbelastingen en –regelingen. Deze heffingen komen in de dagelijkse fiscale praktijk minder vaak voor. Toch is de financiële impact van deze heffingen voor diverse belastingplichtigen aanzienlijk en gaat het soms het belang van meer reguliere belastingen te boven. In de fiscale praktijk is de laatste jaren dan ook waar te nemen dat steeds meer fiscalisten zich specialiseren in bijzondere heffingen. De bijzondere heffingen worden niet alleen gekenmerkt door afwijkende materiële regels, maar vaak ook door afwijkende procedures. Een deel van de bijzondere heffingen kenmerkt zich door de veelvuldige rechterlijke procedures die daarover worden gevoerd. Daarmee zijn er voorbeelden te over om de theorie ook praktisch inzichtelijk te maken.

Het onderhavige vak richt zich op een aantal van die heffingen, te weten de belangrijkste belastingen op het gebied van de lagere overheid, milieu- en energiebelastingen als mede op de autobelastingen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Je verwerft inzicht in diverse bijzondere heffingen op centraal en decentraal niveau.
• Je bent in staat om deze bijzondere heffingen toe te passen op een concrete casus.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course, the basic aspects of cellular biochemistry will be covered. The biosynthesis, structure and function of all groups of biomolecules will be discussed, as well as the mechanisms that allow living cells to generate energy and to produce their essential building blocks. You will learn about the general principles of biochemistry among the plant, animal and bacterial kingdoms, but also focus on the specific differences between these groups.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: After completing this course, the students will:
1) Have a fundamental knowledge of organic chemistry;
2) Be familiar with biomolecules, through the study of the biosynthesis, structure (1-, 2- and 3-dimensional) and function of DNA, RNA, proteins, lipids, sugars and starch;

3) Be able to describe metabolic pathways, understanding how food is consumed and energy is generated in plants, animals and bacteria; including detailed analyses of the following processes: Glycolysis, Citric acid cycle (or Krebs cycle), Electron transport chains; Oxidative phosphorylation; Photosynthesis; The pentose phosphate pathway;
4) Be acquainted with the diverse family of proteins, from structural, and ‘immunological’ (immunoglobulins) to catalytic proteins (enzymes);
5) Have a profound knowledge on the biochemistry of the 'senses': the molecules and mechanisms that determine smell, taste, vision and hearing.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111756,2023,Biological psychology: The Human Body,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,"['A Gabbi', 'prof.dr. K Dijkstra']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Psychology entails the scientific study of the human mind and behavior. This course will focus heavily on the workings of the brain, the central nervous system, the digestive system, sleep, stress, and the role of drugs in the human body.  If you are fascinated by the issue of how certain brain structures and processes are involved in certain behaviors, then this course should definitely satisfy your curiosity!

During this course, you will become more familiar with this biology-oriented sub-field in psychology. Biological psychology, or biopsychology, usually refers to studies into the relationship between the body and human behavior in healthy humans (or animals), whereas (clinical) neuropsychology tends to refer to the relationship between brain damage and human behavior. Brain damage will not be a topic in this course.

Basic biological knowledge is helpful but not required for this course. However, as the explanation of behavior often requires an understanding of anatomy and the workings of the brain, we advise you to take notice of and attend the lectures and the additional learning resources if your background knowledge in biology is limited. You should be aware that certain brain structures are involved in certain behaviors. For example, the amygdalae (an almond-shaped group of nuclei located in the brain) seem highly active in threatening situations and set a variety of physical reactions in motion. It is therefore important to know where the amygdalae are located in the brain, to which other brain structures they are connected, and what the consequences of their activation are.

The (sometimes prerecorded) lectures will tell you about anatomy and explain the workings of the central and peripheral nervous system, as well as the principles of chemical neurotransmission. The documents on CANVAS and the books in the study landscape are good sources of information to help study these subjects. Appendices 1 and 2 contain the most important information about anatomical structures and terminology. Other topics that will be discussed are neurons, drugs, sleep, and stress, among others.

The tutorials will go deeper into the reciprocal relationship between the body and behavior. You will come to understand that we are trying to look at the physical and biological processes at work in a certain problem. This will apply to mechanisms in the body, i.e., how do they work, how do they make sense, biologically? You will find out that biopsychology deals with many ‘everyday’ symptoms such as eating, sleeping, drugs, stress, and emotion.

You will also get more hands-on experience with the topics of this course through various activities, such as homework assignments that are discussed in the tutorial group, and a group presentation that you will share during the tutorial meetings. These assignments should make the learning materials more comprehensible and will help you to be optimally engaged in the course.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of the course, when you have actively engaged with the course content, you will be able to formulate clear learning goals, will have gained a basic knowledge and understanding of the relevant themes in the workings of the human body. You will then be able to apply these concepts in the group discussions and assignments. You will also learn to thoroughly read empirical papers on relevant themes of this course, interpret the results and critically think about methodological issues related to this research.    `
Specifically, at the end of the course, you will have obtained basic knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • The functions and workings of nerves, neurons, and neurotransmitters
• The biological functions of the digestive system

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111220,2023,Biologische Determinanten van Leren en Ontwikkeling,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. M Achterberg'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This module follows on module 1.5 Developmental Psychology and deals in greater depth with the biological origin of learning and behavior. The module examines the relationship between functioning of the nervous system on the one hand, and overt and covert behaviour on the other. First, students will study the anatomy and functioning of the central and peripheral nervous system, the principles of neurotransmission, and plasticity of the nervous system. Later, biological foundations of memory, learning, emotions, stress, and sleep are discussed. The program will cover the research methods used in biological psychology.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <div>At the end of the course student will be able to:

column2: • Describe the anatomy, the development and the function of the central nervous system
• Describe the relevance of the theory of evolution for pedagogical sciences
• Describe the biological underpinnings of memory, learning, emotions, stress and sleep

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111696,2023,Biologische grondslagen van Opvoeding en Ontwikkeling,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. M Achterberg'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Deze module sluit aan bij module 1.3 Ontwikkelingspsychologie en gaat dieper in op de biologische oorsprong van opvoeding en ontwikkeling. De module onderzoekt de relatie tussen het functioneren van het (centrale) zenuwstelsel enerzijds en bewust en onbewust gedrag anderzijds. Eerst bestuderen studenten de anatomie en werking van het centrale zenuwstelsel, de principes van neurotransmissie en de plasticiteit van het zenuwstelsel. Later worden de biologische grondslagen van emoties, stress, sociale relaties, slaap en leren besproken. Het programma behandelt de onderzoeksmethoden die worden gebruikt in de biologische psychologie.

Aan de hand van een biologisch vraagstuk schrijven studenten een literatuurstudie (review). Ze leren hoe ze empirische bronnen moeten zoeken binnen dit vakgebied en hoe ze een onderzoeksvraag goed moeten formuleren voor een literatuurstudie. Bovendien leren ze hoe ze de inleiding, het middenstuk en de conclusie moeten opbouwen. Ze selecteren hiervoor verschillende empirische studies die ze behandelen en kritisch tegen elkaar afzetten. Naast het schriftelijk uitwerken van de literatuurstudie, leren studenten hoe ze de hoofdbevinding uit de literatuurstudie kunnen visualiseren. Deze visualisaties zullen zij aan elkaar presenteren in de vorm van een symposium. Tijdens deze presentaties wordt inzichtelijk gemaakt hoe de onderzochte literatuur impact kan hebben op de pedagogische of onderwijskundige praktijk. Ten slotte ondersteunt niet alleen de docent de studenten in hun schrijfproces, maar geven de studenten ook elkaar peerfeedback. </body>

column1: Aan het einde van de cursus zijn studenten in staat om:

column2: • de anatomie, ontwikkeling en functie van het centrale zenuwstelsel te beschrijven;
• de relevantie van neurowetenschappen en de evolutietheorie voor pedagogische wetenschappen te beschrijven;
• de neurobiologische onderbouwing van emoties, stress, sociale relaties, slaap en leren beschrijven;
• kennis te destilleren en interpreteren uit wetenschappelijke literatuur
• wetenschappelijke literatuur te vinden en correct naar bronnen te verwijzen;
• een onderzoeksvraag formuleren over een biologisch onderwerp, geschikt voor een literatuurstudie;
• verbanden te leggen tussen bronnen, informatie te integreren, kritisch te beschouwen en te presenteren;
• kritisch de methodologische waarde van een bron te kunnen inschatten;
• fundamentele kennis middels een presentatie over te brengen naar (fictieve) maatschappelijke partners en daarmee impact te maken
• verantwoordelijkheid te nemen voor het eigen leren;
• professionele feedback te geven aan medestudenten, waarbij zij rekening houden wie waarvoor verantwoordelijk is.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Research Master and PhD students (and others) often experience that not all expertise for biomedical techniques or essays they need to perform for their research project is readily available in their department. The organization of the Graduate school offers a wonderful opportunity to exchange this expertise. Therefore, the course ‘Biomedical Research Techniques’ is organized to create an overview of techniques routinely used in the various departments. This course is also part of the Research MSc Infection & Immunity.
The program is organized according to a logical order in 5 steps: DNA, RNA, Proteome, Cell, Tissue and Organ.
This implies the following program in 5 days:

column2: • Day 1: primers and probes, sequencing, SNP-analysis, methylation
• Day 2: RNA, RNA expression arrays, RT PCR, siRNA, data mining (morning) and site visit core facilities labs genomics (afternoon)
• Day 3: proteomes, mass spectrometry (morning) and site visits to the mass spectrometry facilities (afternoon)
• Day 4: Flow cytometry, Cytotoxicity & Multi-parameter assays (morning); microscopy: quantitative confocal microscopy, image analysis, FRET, FRAP & computer modeling (afternoon)
• Day 5: Applied Molecular Imaging: MRI, CT, Nuclear, Optical in vivo (morning); BSL Lab and Pathology services (afternoon)

column1: Please find the program here by clicking here.
*the program may be subject to change.
Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course

This course includes mandatory attendance when registered. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points and the cancellation policy applies.

Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, participants may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Participants should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.

The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’.

Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years. On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.

Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided after completing this course. You will receive the EC in your Hora Finita account, after you have entered the training activity on your portfolio in Hora Finita.

For automatic approval of your training activities, ensure that you register your OSIRIS student number (the first six digits of your ERNA account) to your Hora Finita account under 'Research phase', 'TSP' tab, under the heading 'Education'.

Erasmus MC Graduate School PhD courses are free of charge*. However, free of charge does not mean free of responsibility. Once you have signed up for a course, we expect you to attend. For every late cancellation or no-show, we have had to disappoint others who would have liked to join.
*A payment of €1.00 is required for administrative purposes.

column1: Within the Biomedical Sciences track of the Erasmus MC Graduate School, a wide range of research projects is carried out, and various state-of-the-art technologies are employed to address questions of both fundamental and translational nature. As a (beginning) PhD student it is hard to find out what is done where, and who to approach.

The two-day Biomedical Science Introduction Course aims to provide students with this information and with the possibility to network and start collaborations. Research in the Biomedical Sciences track has been divided into six themes (listed in alphabetical order): Endocrinology metabolism & ageing, Haematopoiesis, lymphopoiesis & immune regulation, Infections & host response, Molecular life science, Neuroscience, and Solid tumors. In the course overviews of the research performed in each of the themes will be presented in dedicated sessions, and there will be ample opportunity for discussion with speakers and moderators, and for visits to labs.
Be sure to register at least one week prior to start of the course.
You will receive all details about the location the final program for the course one week prior to the start of the course.

column2: • To find out what is done where, and who to approach within the Research in the Biomedical Sciences

column1: Please find a draft program as example, click here.
*the program may be subject to change.
Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course

This course includes mandatory attendance when registered. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points and the cancellation policy applies.

Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, participants may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Participants should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.

The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’.

Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years. We have made the evaluation a mandatory part of the course in order to avoid selection bias in the outcomes, and to make sure every student is heard.

On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.
Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided after completing this course.

As Erasmus MC PhD candidates you will receive the EC in your Hora Finita account, after you have entered the training activity on your portfolio in Hora Finita. For automatic approval of your training activities, ensure that you register your OSIRIS student number (the first six digits of your ERNA account) to your Hora Finita account under 'Research phase', 'TSP' tab, under the heading 'Education'.

column1: As a PhD candidate, you have to get your research published to share it with a wider audience. But writing a paper can be daunting. During the writing process, there’s a lot you have to get right. Of course, it is important to represent your research accurately. However, it is equally important to do so in a way that is accessible and engages your readers. This course is to help you feel capable and confident when you navigate this complex task. Topics we will address include the writing process, scientific structure, paragraph organisation, language flow, giving and receiving feedback, and, most importantly, reader-friendliness.

This course is only open to PhD students who are in the process of writing a PhD thesis or academic article. Participants must be able to produce examples of their own written work, as this will be a part of the material used in the course.
Workshops, self-study, peer feedback, group discussion
Please note that for the course English level C1 or IELTS 7.0 score is required.

column1: This course is geared towards writing effective research papers. It is designed to help participants become aware of what it is that makes a text accessible and engaging for the audience, and it will help them apply this knowledge in practice. During the course, participants will be handed a range of practical
tools to make their writing more effective on text, paragraph, and sentence level.
This course aims to achieve the following learning goals:
1. To use language and style appropriate for scientific communication
2. To write accessibly, using different strategies to achieve cohesion and flow
3. To make optimal use of the different sections in a formal biomedical research paper
4. To look critically at the work of others and give feedback effectively

All participants are expected to follow each week’s class. In addition, all assignments must be completed by the deadlines. If you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points and the cancellation policy applies.
When unexpected absence occurs during the course, please contact the graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl, the EUR e-mail address of the teacher and ltc@eur.nl.

column1: Is euthanasie bij diep demente personen moreel toelaatbaar? Wanneer moeten artsen bij medisch begeleide voortplanting verzoeken om nieuwe technieken in te zetten weigeren? Bestaat er zoiets als een morele plicht om weesmedicijnen te financieren en te vergoeden? Wat horen overheid, industrie en individuen te doen om problemen als obesitas of orgaandonatie op te lossen? Zijn nieuwe technieken om menselijke  vermogens (cognitie, sociaal gedrag, stemming, uiterlijk) te verbeteren wel moreel wenselijk?

Biomedische ethiek en volksgezondheidsethiek zijn interessante en complexe onderzoeksvelden. Als discipline bevatten ze uiteenlopende theoretische benaderingen maar elke aanpak focust op concrete gevallen en probeert de uitdagingen waarmee de medische wetenschappen ons confronteren op te pakken en een zinvolle bijdrage te leveren aan het doordenken en beslechten ervan. In deze cursus worden prangende bio-ethische kwesties bestudeerd en onderzocht hoe theoretische benaderingen, concepten en methoden kunnen helpen om met die kwesties om te gaan. U wordt uitgedaagd om actief uw beredeneerde standpunt te bepalen en te verdedigen in discussies met uw medestudenten.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Aanwezigheid bij de colleges is verplicht. Bij afwezigheid maakt de student een vervangende opdracht.

Het kunnen identificeren en analyseren van ethische kwesties in de gezondheidszorg, bijvoorbeeld issues rond medisch begeleide voortplanting, beslissingen rond het levenseinde, of het gebruik van nieuwe genetische technieken.
Een beter begrip ontwikkelen van sleutelconcepten, waarden en theorieën die relevant zijn voor de gezondheidszorg, zoals autonomie, competentie, informed consent, paternalisme, ziekte en gezondheid.

Het kunnen reflecteren op een moreel probleem op het vlak van gezondheidsethiek door de argumenten voor en tegen mogelijke antwoorden te onderzoeken, als basis voor een redelijk en te rechtvaardigen oordeel.
Het kritisch kunnen reflecteren op de eigen morele overtuiging en in staat zijn de eigen aanbevolen handelwijze te rechtvaardigen.

column1: The block seminar is s a one-week course within the CEMS programme that takes place at the beginning of Term 1 at all CEMS schools. Block Seminars bring together professors and students from various CEMS institutions. Subjects derive from different cultural and academic perspectives; many topics are not a part of the universities’ standard curricula.

The Block Seminar is a mandatory element of the programme and accounts for 3 EC and students receive a letter grade for the Block Seminar in their CEMS curricular progress. For the MSc International Management curriculum, it is evaluated based on pass/fail.

RSM offers two parallel Block Seminars in cooperation with CEMS social partner & RSM corporate partner, the European Space Agency. The first block seminar, The Entrepreneurial Challenge: Turning Technology into Business (TTB) focuses on developing a (non-space) business application of a European Space Agency (ESA) technology. It learns the students about entrepreneurship and developing new, viable businesses. The second block seminar is about strategy consulting and to support entrepreneurs with the development of their new business.
Students are assigned to teams of 4-6 persons and as a team they work on a group assignment.

For the module TTB, the assignment is to develop a viable business concept using space technology. The business concept needs to be presented at the end of the working week. For the module NVC, the assignment is to provide entrepreneurs with actionable recommendations how to improve their new business. These recommendations also need to be presented at the end of the week.

The group project is a joint effort. This means that all team members should contribute equally and fully participate throughout the week. Lecturers, facilitators and experts will support and coach the students in their assignments during the week. The quality of the final work will be graded by the course lecturers in collaboration with an independent jury.
Further details on the course organization and assignment will be provided on Canvas and during the first meeting.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Both seminars offer a great opportunity to work closely together in teams on high-tech business opportunities and to learn more about the space tech industry. At the end of the seminar students should be able to:

column2: • Understand the role and potential value of space technology and business in today's and tomorrow's world.
• Write a business plan and develop a viable business model around a new space technology (Turning Technology into Business)
• Develop strategic recommendations for entrepreneurs to support them in the successful growth of their ventures (New Venture Creation)
• Pitch their work and ideas persuasively to outsiders

column1: The importance of Frugal Innovation has begun to thaw; people, companies and governments are exploring and grasping the importance of embedding society within business practice to achieve longer-term survivability and positive growth prospects. The question for this three day bootcamp is how you can design an inquisitive and explorative process to tackle your field assignment. It will be the first time that the groups for the field assignments will work intensively together. Therewith the bootcamp is an important stepping stone towards a more precise formulation of your field assignment and getting the experience of working in a multidisciplinary group. At the end of the course, you present your outcomes to experts in the field. This is a high-paced, innovative course that allows you to apply your skills. As such, be prepared to work fast and think creatively!

column1: In deze cursus leer je over visuele en auditieve waarneming. Je leert over theorieën over de perceptie van bijvoorbeeld contrast, beweging, kleur en objecten. Daarnaast leer je over experimentele paradigma's die onderzoekers gebruiken om perceptie en aandacht te bestuderen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Aan het einde van de cursus verwachten we dat je in staat bent tot het volgende:
•    Het beschrijven van de anatomie en fysiologie van het oog en het oor, en de structuren en processen in de hersenen die een rol spelen bij de waarneming van visuele en auditieve stimuli.
•    Uitleggen hoe mensen beslissingen nemen over de aan- of afwezigheid van een stimulus.
•    Uitleggen hoe mensen verschillen in stimulusintensiteit waarnemen.
•    Uitleggen hoe mensen kleuren waarnemen en welke tekortkomingen in kleurperceptie er zijn.
•    Het beschrijven van gangbare theorieën over hoe het cognitieve systeem visuele en auditieve elementen groepeert en interpreteert en hoe objecten en auditieve patronen worden herkend.
•    Uitleggen hoe en wanneer diepte wordt waargenomen.
•    Uitleggen hoe en wanneer beweging wordt waargenomen.
•    Het beschrijven van de (bidirectionele) relatie tussen perceptie en actie.
•    Het beschrijven van de belangrijkste paradigma's die worden gebruikt om aandacht en perceptie te bestuderen.
•    Het selecteren en interpreteren van statistische analyses van bevindingen verkregen met onderzoek dat gebruik maakt van deze paradigma's.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: From a marketing standpoint, the brand is the most valuable asset of the firm. Brands embody a firm’s strategy and drive its execution. As such, managing and developing a brand is a complex task that requires sharp critical-thinking skills, an advanced understanding of marketing concepts, and an imaginative mind.

The goal of this elective is to equip students with the fundamentals of brand development through a mix of research-driven frameworks, case-based discussions, and hands-on projects. After taking this class, students will possess a solid understanding of how, why, and when brands drive value; in-depth knowledge of the opportunities, issues, and challenges a brand can face throughout its life; the ability to critically evaluate brand positions and branding decisions.

This course is of particular relevance to students who seek to become brand managers, as the concepts and skills that they will learn directly relate to this executive role. Beyond this specific role, the course is also relevant to students who seek to work in strategy and/or marketing departments: understanding the function and strategic role of brands will help them adopt a longer-term orientation in their decisions.

As this course is the last elective of the MSc in Marketing Management, it is also designed to facilitate the transition for students from consumers of knowledge to marketing practitioners. The cases and examples developed in the lectures are specifically picked to show how the extensive knowledge of consumer behavior and marketing strategy that you have accumulated in the MSc can be used to generate novel insights for success in the marketplace.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand the strategic importance of brands to companies
• Measure brand equity and evaluate a brand’s strategic position
• Reflect on the usefulness and limitations of marketing frameworks
• Use branding decisions to drive value in heterogeneous circumstances
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: A brand is often considered to be the company’s most valuable asset, although the origin of this value resides in the mind of the consumer. This Branding course takes a strong consumer‐based view on branding, so we will discuss the foundation of branding in consumer behavior and consumer psychology. The course provides insight into how consumers perceive brands and the roles these brands play in their everyday lives.

We will look at product and service brands and we will look at brands and branding in international consumer markets as well as in international industrial markets. We will focus on the value of brands, brand associations, consumer‐brand relationships, brand building strategies, the leverage of brand value, brand architecture, and brand image measurement. Although the basis for our approach is the consumer, we will continuously translate these consumer insights into operational and strategic brand management practice.

We will build a strong theoretical foundation by studying journal articles about brands and branding, but we will continuously translate the models and concepts of this theory to practice by means of short articles from the business press, discussions on company's branding strategies (including several guest presentations by brand designers and brand managers) and practical team assignments. Apart from instructive and interesting, this course has the potential to be a lot of fun! We are confronted with brands every single day, and it is challenging to explore the processes by which these are built and communicated to you.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Appraise the main academic branding theories and concepts.
• Integrate practice cases of branding to solve brand questions;
• Discuss brand logos, mantras (slogans), personalities and identities.
• Integrate branding in company and marketing strategies;
• Discuss marketing plans to introduce and position new brands.
• Discuss marketing communication plans to launch and manage brands.

column1: Building my Career runs across block 1-5 and consists of various (digital) questionnaires, exercises, lectures, and other formats to prepare you for the labour market and your future career. As this preparation is not a straightforward, easy process we invite you first to start with an internal journey and learn more about yourself – in terms of personal drivers, interests and values and then find a fit with the external side – the industries. During the second part of this course you work on your personal career narrative and practice building up a personal professional network effectively in a series of workshops and assignments.

The diverse tools as used in this course will include not only job search and acquisition techniques, but also the tools for personal career development that provide the best insight into tactical decision-making; identifying and choosing from options with the goal of optimal career fulfilment now and in the future.

Using both a theoretical and practical approach, the goal of the lectures, workshops, exercises digital tools and between-class assignments is to produce competitive job candidates who enter the market well prepared to make informed career decisions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The objective of this course is to provide students with an understanding of and the tools to practice the fundamental principles underlying proactive career management. The immediate application is most evident during the post-graduation job search, but the foundational skills learned are applicable during all dynamic phases of a career.
By the end of the course, students will:

column2: • Understand the characteristics of the recruitment and application process
• Analyze strengths and weaknesses, personal values and skills as relevant for an individual student
• Identify career preparation gaps and create action points to fill the gaps
• Develop a relationship with one or more mentor and people in business
• Reflect and navigate through ethical dilemma’s

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114240,2023,Burgerlijk procesrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr. FM Ruitenbeek - Bart', 'prof.mr. AIM van Mierlo', 'RSM Bosch']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Het burgerlijk procesrecht is als het ware het sluitstuk van het materiële privaatrecht. Hier komen civielrechtelijke vakken als het goederen- en verbintenissenrecht, samen bij het bestuderen van de wijze waarop een partij haar geschil aan de overheidsrechter kan voorleggen en een uitspraak van de rechter ten uitvoer kan leggen. Het materiële recht dient als basis voor de bestudering van het burgerlijk procesrecht. Het wordt dan ook bekend verondersteld.

Wanneer partijen een tussen hen bestaand civiel geschil niet in onderling overleg kunnen oplossen, kunnen zij hun geschil voorleggen aan de overheidsrechter. Het burgerlijk procesrecht geeft de spelregels hoe partijen hun recht kunnen verwezenlijken. In dit vak krijg je een voorproefje van de rechtspraktijk: is het verstandig om te gaan procederen, hoe kan je het nodige bewijs leveren, welke procedure kies je, hoe begin je een procedure, hoe verloopt een procedure, welke ruimte heb je als rechter om over een zaak te beslissen, hoe kan een rechterlijke uitspraak ten uitvoer worden gelegd, kan tegen de uitspraak een rechtsmiddel worden ingesteld, hoe loopt de procedure daarna verder? Je gaat ook reflecteren op de botsende belangen in een procedure. Denk aan de wens van de politiek om procedures sneller te laten verlopen enerzijds en het belang van partijen om een gedegen beslissing in hun zaak te krijgen anderzijds.

Onderdeel van het vak maakt uit het concipiëren van eenvoudige processtukken. In dit vak is er aandacht voor de procesrechtelijke eisen waaraan een processtuk moet voldoen. Deze vaardigheid zal in de quizzes worden geoefend.
Omdat geschillen zich niet tot de landsgrenzen beperken, zal enige aandacht worden besteed aan grensoverschrijdend procederen.

De procedure voor de overheidsrechter is niet altijd de meest geëigende weg om het geschil op te lossen. In het vak burgerlijk procesrecht komen daarom ook alternatieve wijzen van geschiloplossing aan de orde, zoals arbitrage, bindend advies en mediation.

Ter illustratie worden op Canvas een procesdossier en voorbeelden van processtukken geplaatst waaraan tijdens de colleges en in de quizzes wordt gerefereerd. Zo kan je nog beter kan zien ‘hoe het er werkelijk aan toe gaat’. Het bekijken van informatie op rechtspraak.nl kan daarbij ook helpen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Uitleggen welke invloed de beginselen van procesrecht hebben op de beslechting of oplossing van geschillen en beoordelen of de beginselen in de procedureregels voldoende zijn gewaarborgd.
• De procedureregels in vorderings- en verzoekzaken in eerste aanleg omschrijven en in concrete gevallen toepassen.
• De procesrechtelijke regels toepassen bij het opstellen van eenvoudige processtukken.
• De regels rond de feitenvaststelling, de bewijslevering en bewijslastverdeling omschrijven, uitleggen en in concrete gevallen toepassen.

• De mogelijkheden om een uitspraak aan te tasten, beschrijven en in concrete gevallen toepassen en de procedureregels van de procedure in verzet en hoger beroep uitleggen en in concrete gevallen toepassen.
• De maatregelen tot bewaring van rechten en executie van uitspraken omschrijven en de specifieke regels in concrete gevallen toepassen.
• De procedureregels van de voornaamste vormen van alternatieve geschilbeslechting (arbitrage, bindend advies, mediation) uitleggen en in eenvoudige zaken toepassen.
• De bronnen van de regels voor de beslechting van grensoverschrijdende geschillen omschrijven en in eenvoudige zaken toepassen.
• Het materiële recht (verbintenissenrecht en goederen- en faillissementsrecht) toepassen bij het oplossen van procesrechtelijke vraagstukken, waaronder het opstellen van processtukken.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Considering the growing impact of governments and their policies (or structures such as the E.U.) on business, attention to politics is warranted and increasingly relevant in any business study. Business & politics: a “two-way street” and a much too complex topic. How do Businesses and Politics mix? Should they? When it comes to this topic, companies and their boards juggle two dominant views: (1) corporate political activities are a minefield with the potential of triggering corporate crises, and (2) ignoring politics may be even riskier.

Any business leader/decision-maker/professional should be aware of these complexities and learn how to navigate them while driving business change or implementing/developing business strategies. To help broaden this perspective, the course covers a wide range of topics, among which: market vs. non-market strategy, trade policies, tariffs, corporate social (ir)responsibility, corporate political activity, political risk management, and corporate governance.
The students will be helped in navigating all these topics through instructional videos, lectures, business cases, and academic articles (required literature).

By learning about the complexities of the intersection between business and politics, students will gain a complete toolbox to assess a business’ environment - broader than shareholders, customers, suppliers, etc.- and understand how businesses may also impact societies, the environment, and policies. Having this more comprehensive perspective on business strategy may help one think and develop better strategies or positively impact a firm’s strategy. Additionally, the course builds on and broadens the knowledge gained in courses such as Strategic Management, and Responsible Business Leaders.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After following this course, the student is able to:

column2: • Recognize the importance of non-market strategy in business
• Understand the business-government interface and the inventory of political strategies used by firms
• Understand how politics may impact business and the relevance of a corporate political strategy
• Evaluate different non-market strategies that firms can employ and think strategically about their implementation
• Evaluate a crisis situation within a firm and recognize the potential for developing/applying a non-market strategy.
• Define and explain what corporate governance, non-market strategies, and societal license to operate are.
• Create a high-level non-market strategy for a firm in crisis.

column1: The objective of this course is to learn quantitative empirical methods and techniques commonly used in practice, and to train the programming skills to apply these methods in research practice. The course reviews data analytics methods and techniques that are frequently used in management, and provides a context for further developing research skills. The course contributes to independent evaluation and application of quantitative empirical research.

The various methods presented deal with the formulation of research hypotheses, the development of causal relationships schemes, data collection, classification, regression, clustering, combining evidence and prior beliefs, and text analysis. Throughout the course, attention is paid to methodological issues, such as the implications of the measurement scales, the difference between statistical dependence and (assumed) causality, the possibly disturbing influence of confounding variables, the difference between explanation and prediction, the problem of over-fitting, and cross-validation.

Practical research skills are developed within the context of a research project that comprises most elements of the empirical cycle, from hypothesis generation to data collection, analysis and reflection. Throughout the course, use is made of software package R, explained below.

The relevance of the course is evidenced by the widespread use of analytical results in academic journals, professional literature, news papers, and other media. The generation of these results is rarely without creative choices, and their interpretation therefore requires a proper understanding of statistical methods and a critical attitude. The immediate relevance of the course is emphasized by the frequent use of quantitative methods in other courses, particularly the thesis trajectory.

The Business Analytics course is taught in the first two blocks of the curriculum of the Master in Management master (MIM). It provides foundational knowledge and skills in the domain of quantitative empirical methods that will be needed in other courses, including the thesis, in various extents.

Attendance during classes and workshops is expected; these venues can also be used to ask questions about the course material. Attendance during the presentations at the end of the course is mandatory.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Describe and relate different methods of analysis
• Explain and compare the assumptions underlying the methods and techniques discussed
• Apply statistical methods and techniques in relatively closed research settings, and analyze and discuss results

• Develop a research question, construct a conceptual model, plan research activities and perform this plan in a flexible way, collect, and analyze data, evaluate, interpret and discuss results, and report findings in scientific writing and oral form
• Apply statistical concepts in R programming, developing transparent, shareable code; using open data
• Cooperate responsibly in diverse teams to leverage the advantages of team diversity
• Effectively communicate (in written and oral form) ideas, solution approaches, and findings to diverse stakeholders, and in diverse formats

column1: Business analytics is becoming a key driver of competitive advantage. Only firms that can harness their data and develop strong analytic capabilities across all their business functions will be able to survive in fast-moving modern markets. In this course, students will learn how to use Python to manage and analyse large data sets, and present and communicate the results of their analyses in a manner that makes them actionable and understandable to business managers.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Analyse business data using appropriate statistical models with Python
• Interpret the results of statistical analyses and models with a focus on business implications
• Communicate the results of statistical analyses and models in a concise and understandable manner

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112597,2023,Business Analytics PT,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. CLP Pennings', 'dr. J van Dalen', 'NI Postma, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1.1 Doel en inhoud van het vak

Het doel van dit vak is het verkrijgen van kennis over veelgebruikte kwantitatieve empirische methoden en technieken en van programmeervaardigheden om deze methoden toe te passen in de onderzoekspraktijk. Het vak behandelt data analytics methoden en technieken die veel worden gebruikt door bedrijven, en biedt een context voor het verder ontwikkelen van onderzoeksvaardigheden. De verschillende gepresenteerde methoden gaan over het formuleren van onderzoekshypothesen, de ontwikkeling van causale relatieschema’s, gegevensverzameling, classificatie, regressie, clustering, het combineren van bewijs met eerdere veronderstellingen en tekstanalyse. Gedurende het vak wordt aandacht besteed aan methodologische problemen, zoals de

implicaties van meetschalen, het verschil tussen statistische afhankelijkheid en (veronderstelde) causaliteit, de mogelijke invloed van verstorende of ontbrekende variabelen, het verschil tussen verklaren en voorspellen, het probleem van over-fitting en cross-validation. Praktische onderzoeksvaardigheden worden ontwikkeld binnen de context van een onderzoeksproject dat de meeste elementen van de empirische cyclus omvat, van opstellen van een hypothese tot gegevensverzameling, analyse en reflectie. Gedurende het vak wordt er gebruik gemaakt van het softwarepakket R, dat hieronder wordt toegelicht.

The relevantie van het vak blijkt uit de wijdverbreide toepassing van analytische resultaten in academische tijdschriften, vakliteratuur, krantenartikelen, en andere media. Analytische resultaten liggen in toenemende mate aan de basis van besluitvorming bij bedrijven. De totstandkoming van deze resultaten is zelden zonder creatieve keuzen, en de interpretatie ervan vereist daarom een goed begrip van statistische methoden en een kritische houding. De directe relevantie van het vak blijkt verder uit het veelvuldige gebruik van kwantitatieve methoden in andere vakken, met name de scriptie.
1.3 Plaats en functie van het vak in het curriculum

Het vak Business Analytics wordt gegeven in de eerste twee blokken van het curriculum van de Parttime Master in Management master (MIM-P). Het behandelt fundamentele kennis en vaardigheden op het terrein van kwantitatieve empirische onderzoeksmethoden en -technieken die in verschillende mate worden toegepast in andere vakken, waaronder de scriptie.

Aanwezigheid bij campus activiteiten wordt beschouwd als de norm. Werkcolleges kunnen online worden gevolgd. Voor de presentaties van de resultaten aan het einde van het vak (in december) geldt verplichte aanwezigheid.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• De onderliggende aannames van de besproken methoden en technieken te verklaren en vergelijken
• Statistische technieken toe te passen op volledig gedefinieerde problemen
• Statistische technieken toe te passen in een onderzoekscontext en de resultaten te analyseren en evalueren

• Een wetenschappelijk onderzoek uit te voeren en rapporteren, inclusief het formuleren van een onderzoeksvraag, het opstellen van een con ceptueel model, het plannen en uitvoeren van onderzoeksactiviteiten, het verzamelen, verwerken en analyseren van gegevens, het evalueren, interpreteren en bespreken en rapporteren van de bevindingen in de vorm van een wetenschappelijk paper
• Statistische technieken toe te passen in het programma R, een transparante, leesbare code te ontwikkelen, en open data te gebruiken
• Op een verantwoordelijke manier samen te werken in diverse teams, voordeel te halen van team diversiteit
• Ideeën, oplossingsrichtingen en resultaten op effectieve manier te communiceren (in geschreven en gesproken vorm) aan uiteenlopende belanghebbenden en in verschillende formats

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The Business Analytics Workshop course involves completing a data analytics project for a company or organization (henceforth: partner organization). Together with the partner organization, teams of students formulate research questions, obtain and analyze data, and interpret and present their results.

Students are guided through the project by faculty supervisors. Guidance provided to students focuses on two domains: general skills and knowledge, and specific feedback on the project they conduct. Guidance related to general knowledge and skills focuses on project management, choice and application of research methods, and visual and oral presentation of results. In addition, students receive continuous feedback on their project progress from faculty supervisors and representatives of the partner organizations.

Before the start of the course, students can indicate their preference for the available projects. Based on these preferences, faculty supervisors form teams and allocate the teams to projects ahead of the course start.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Formulate appropriate research questions given stakeholders' interests and practical limitations
• Define data needs and obtain necessary data from relevant stakeholders
• Combine appropriate analytical methods with core models of marketing, finance, operations, information systems, or accounting to analyze data
• Interpret findings and formulate implications of results
• Develop and update a project plan and manage a project in a diverse team
• Develop and follow a structured approach towards the solution of an ill-defined business problem
• Communicate with relevant stakeholders to set up and manage a data analytics project
• Report project progress and results to diverse audiences
• Reflect on ethical aspects of a project and the own role in the project

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114552,2023,Business Analytics for International Managers,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. MSG Quinn', 'dr. S Mehta']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The rapid growth in data generation coupled with the decrease in storage cost created new markets and business opportunities, leading to major technical and managerial challenges. But how to take advantage of these growing data, popularly known as Big Data? What framework to adopt? What model to choose? And how to draw insights from it?
Business leaders must face those challenge with new tools and methods, allowing them to implement organizational changes that are critical to shift a business towards a data-driven approach.

This course will introduce students to business analytics and their main challenges. The course will cover the fundamentals of Data Science, including data preparation, modeling, evaluation, and deployment. Specifically, students will learn how to identify data problems and opportunities and how to structure, design, and deploy data-driven solutions that provide value to the business and social sectors. Students will have hands-on experience solving practical cases using R.
While prior experience with data analysis and a statistical software is a plus, there is no requirements to take the course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The key goal of this course is to provide students with a deeper view and understanding of the concepts and methodologies used in scientific research over large datasets that can be applied and implemented in industry contexts, with direct impact on firms’ performance. After the class, students should be able to make decisions in data-driven structures, i.e.:

column2: • Know what data science method to apply to a specific problem
• Understand the whole process behind data-driven markets, from collecting data to deriving actionable insights
• Assess how shifting to a data-driven approach might pose potential ethical and regulatory hurdle depending on the firm’s industry
• Gaining practical knowledge of how to run statistical prediction models and learn how to work with R

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113981,2023,Business Architecture and Transformation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. JR Sweeney', 'dr. MSG Quinn']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In Business Architecture & Transformation, we aim to explain the role of digital and leadership capabilities within organizations and how to assess these capabilities. We will present you with the concept of operating models and demonstrate real-life examples of which operating model fits which kind of company. We will explain the difference between digital operations and digital strategy. Further, we will look into how investments in IT can be assessed. We will point out the importance of IT governance to achieve strategic alignment between IT and business. Finally, we will talk about what really makes a true management leader in IT.

While you have looked into how to strategically use information and how to design business applications in the first block of your core courses, we try to give you a perspective on how you can manage IT projects on a higher level. We look into the business and management perspective of transformation processes and how strategic decisions on a CIO-level should be made.

This course is a combination of lectures, guest lecturers, online case analysis, and discussions. Specific course guidelines will be made available via Canvas before the course begins and need to be read and understood by each participant.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Evaluate the digital and leadership capabilities within an organization
• Create a digital strategy for an organization
• Determine the appropriate digital Governance structure for an organization
• Analyze the business processes of an organization
• Analyzing decision making fallacies in the context of IT decisions

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113670,2023,Business Ethics,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['MA de Kiewit, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The financial crisis of 2008 raised public discussion about a possible lack of moral conduct in the corporate world, especially within the financial industry. Ethics and compliance became terms often used. The pressure for financial organisations to comply with laws and regulations and implement compliance measures to live up to ethical standards is ever-increasing. Compliance measures and ‘Ethics & Compliance’ departments are now commonplace within the financial sector.

This course will provide students with more background knowledge on what business ethics means in practice for financial organisations. It will help students to better understand crucial ethics and compliance concepts and how their own ethical behaviour is sometimes influenced by external factors. Besides having knowledge about financial instruments it is important for the future finance professional to be aware of these topics because working in the financial sector will mean that they will likely also experience pressures that might challenge their own ethical norms or compliance standards. The aim of this course is to provide students with tools to recognize ethical concepts, possible pitfalls, dilemma situations and ways to manage these.
For this course it is needed that students actively participate during the lectures to fully benefit from this course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Identify and explain different ethical concepts that are influential in steering (non-) ethical behaviour
• Recognize dilemma situations and how to structurally manage ethical dilemmas
• Understand how organisations can manage ethical behaviour with the use of formal controls, corporate governance instruments and behavioural controls
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Prof. Dr. W.E.H. Dullaert (VU), Prof. Dr. W. Stam (VU), Prof. Dr. S.N. Khapova (VU), prof. dr. A. Menkveld (VU), prof. dr. M.H. Huysman (VU), Prof. Dr. F. Sotgiu (VU)

The seminars introduce the research groups at the three faculties to the first-year students. In the seminars, scholars relate ongoing research projects in their research groups. After having attended all seminars in the series, students select a research topic and address a professor who is not teaching in the first year of the program. Students write a research proposal (2-3 pages) and discuss the proposal with the researcher.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The main objective of this interactive seminar is to look into the history of fashion and the industry behind glamorous catwalks and shiny magazines. It aims to analyse fashion from a business history perspective, and the importance of fashion for the global and local economy. (Guest) lecturers will present historical backgrounds, theories and insights from the world of fashion. Students will thus study past and recent developments in the fashion industry. They will present and discuss literature, write a diverse range of assignments. The course ends with a written exam based on the historical literature discussed in class.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The main objective is to look into the history of the fashion industry and the world behind the glamorous catwalks and shiny magazines. It aims to analyse fashion from a business history perspective, to look for similarities and differences with other industries. After completing the minor, students should have a wide-range knowledge and critical understanding of the historical, business, economic dimensions of fashion and of the particularities of fashion products, businesses, and intermediaries.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: During your career as a (future) manager, you will come across with multiple types of contracts and applicable legal rules that regulate your business transactions and your company. Law and legal principles govern and influence our daily lives and business. The aim of this course is to give IBA-students a general introduction to the legal issues that manager usually will face while running an economic activity or a business unit. The goal is to provide basic insights in legal thinking and reasoning, allowing future managers to detect possible risks, flaws and opportunities legal rules can offer to their business. The course raises awareness for core principles of law.

To this end, a number of basic legal concepts, classifications and techniques are first presented (sources and principles of law). Subsequently, the aspects of private and public law on which economic activities are founded are discussed. Furthermore, the course will address various topics of commercial law, such as basic concepts of company law, distribution agreements, etc.

These topics are discussed from a transnational point-of-view. Taking into account the diverse and international background of IBA-students, the idea is to provide you an overview of general principles of (contract) law which are common to civil (continental) as well as Anglo-Saxon legal systems (such as e.g. UK common law); rather than providing a detailed description of two or more national legal systems. As such, awareness will be raised to similarities and differences between legal systems and the reasons behind these differences.

The ultimate goal of this course is to allow students to (i) identify, (ii) recognize, (iii) synthesize and (iv) assess the general, theoretical legal framework behind many commercial contracts and business transactions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course, you will be able to:

column2: • identify legal issues relevant to a company;
• evaluate which scenario is most appropriate for a business client / company;
• apply national and international legislation as well as case law to a specific case;
• understand a valid and legally binding contract;
• recognize and predict possible flaws and omissions in a contractual relationship.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Businesses are in dire need of innovative minds who can design and implement high-performance work practices, processes, and strategies. These minds will also help businesses discover opportunities for sustainable social and economic growth.

To achieve these objectives, the minor in Business Management will help you wield knowledge on the fundamental theories and practices in several management fields. The study contents of the minor are related, but not necessarily limited, to decision-making processes of strategic, tactical, and operational nature, and the factors that support those processes.

Students participating in the minor can expect to learn about and perform analysis at individual, team and organizational levels. Key to these analyses and the overall work in the minor is the study of customers and competitors and of how organizations (and their members) can leverage their resources (e.g., human capital, financial, value offering) to respond to the behavior of the latter and achieve high levels of performance.

The minor comprises three modules that cover topics that are critical for the long term development of a business organization,  (i) Organizational Behavior; (ii) Accounting and Financial Management; and (iii) Innovation Management. Overall, the minor answers a basic but foundational question: What are the key insights and best practices in business management?

While strategies, investments, and operations are important for organizational success, an organization cannot excel if attention is not paid to its social capital – the human resources. This module provides an introduction to the study of human behavior in organizations. These behaviors are mainly explained in reference to psychological mechanisms, situational factors, individual differences, and group phenomena that influence the way people interact in the organizational context. The module, therefore, focuses on an individual level of analysis and on a team level of analysis.

This module is specifically designed for students with no background in accounting and finance. Regardless of previous experience, by the end of the module, students would develop a strong economic intuition.

The module will cover, elaborate on and explore the basic building blocks of (corporate) finance so that students will understand how financial managers make decisions on a day-to-day basis (for example decisions related to liquidity), why and how firms invest in new projects (net present value and other investment decision criteria, capital structure theory) and how the value of a firm is increased (shareholder value maximization). Additionally, the module explores the abstract concept of risk and make it tangible and measurable by working through and applying the Capital Asset Pricing Model.

In order to achieve this, part of the work, during the module, will focus on significant parts of accounting, with a special emphasis on the core logic and mechanisms of balance sheet, income statement and cash flow statement. This will allow engaging in the analysis of a firm’s most important “health”-parameters (i.e. financial statement analysis: liquidity, profitability, asset management efficiency, capital structure and market value).

The synthesis of all these elements is achieved through case analysis. In addition to bringing together the different theoretical elements in the context of concrete business problems, active participation in case analyses will (1) allow students to enhance their problem-solving and decision-making abilities in various areas of marketing and (2) provide an opportunity to develop, present, and defend their own recommendations, and to examine and discuss the recommendations of others critically.

Innovation Management encompasses everything that firms do in and around the process of turning ideas into new products, new services, new methods, new materials or new business models. This process is typically multidisciplinary in nature in that people from different backgrounds and with various specializations work together (such as psychology, creativity, marketing, technology, strategy, and organizational design). Firms that effectively and efficiently integrate these backgrounds and their respective inputs are likely to be innovative, have a strong competitive advantage, and high survival rates. This module focuses on some of the most important aspects of managing the innovation process, from both a strategic and an operational perspective. In Innovation Management we discuss, amongst others, the adoption of innovations, creativity, idea management, innovation strategy, portfolio management, innovation process management, and innovation networks.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Organizational Behavior: 1. Understand the key concepts of organizational behavior. 2. Analyze problems within organizations grounded in individual and/or team behavior. 3. Appreciate the complexity of managing employees and the importance of critical thinking to reduce biases for managerial decisions

Accounting and Financial Management: 1. State and define the components of each of the financial statements (i.e. balance sheet, income statement and cash flow statement), differentiate between them, and interpret them. 2. State and define the core categories of financial statement analysis (i.e. liquidity, profitability, asset management efficiency, capital structure and market value), select the appropriate metrics to measure them, execute the necessary calculations and interpret their results. 3. Describe the relevance of the time value of money in the context of valuating projects and firms and execute and interpret the associated calculations. 4. Define and describe absolute and relative risk measurements. Interpret and critique specific risk metrics and judge their impact on the cost of capital. 5. Explain the concept of diversification in the context of portfolio theory and differentiate between portfolios carrying different amounts of risk.

Innovation Management: 1. Discuss what an innovation strategy is and how it relates to a firm's position in an ecosystem 2. Contrast different tools to manage an innovation portfolio 3. Analyze how both individual and group creativity can be stimulated 4. Examine different ways to evaluate and select ideas 5. Discuss the challenges of implementing and executing innovation
