Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course

This course includes mandatory attendance when registered. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points and the cancellation policy applies.

Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, participants may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Participants should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.

The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’.

Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years. On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.

Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided for PhD candidates and Research Master students. Other participants can e-mail graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl to request a certificate after completing this course.

As an Erasmus MC PhD candidate, please ensure that the OSIRIS student number (the first six digits of the ERNA account) is registered in the Hora Finita account. This can be found under 'Research phase', 'TSP' tab, under the heading 'Education'. Please add the course using the course code to your Hora Finita portfolio. Once these two steps are completed the EC’s will be automatically transferred and approved.

Erasmus MC Graduate School PhD education is free of charge*. However, free of charge does not mean free of responsibility. Once you have signed up for a course or event, we expect you to attend. For every late cancellation or no-show, we have had to disappoint others who would have liked to join.
Please find the cancellation and no-show policy on STiP.
*A payment of €1.00 is required for administrative purposes.

column1: <body>The ability to communicate effectively is very important for many professional practitioners. Professional communication differs from normal communication in a number of ways, for example by using professional interviews. Professional interviews have a clear purpose and how the interview is led and carried out should be geared towards achieving that goal. Good problem clarification, for example, is a condition of a good professional therapy or advice session. Furthermore, the client can expect that a professional takes the greatest care in dealing with his or her personal problems, which can be very sensitive issues. A number of basic communication skills and a good basic attitude are needed in order to achieve this goal. So, the aim of this course is to improve the knowledge and skills required for effective communication. Theory and research on communication is reviewed and basic attitudes and basic interviewing skills are practised in role-plays. Note. This course is not about the clinical interview as a tool for diagnosing clients.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The Clinical Communication Skills course will:

column5: Help you gain insight into the processes in counselling a person with a request for help.
Help you gain insight into and knowledge of the Van der Molen, Lang, Trower & Look (2014) interview model and how to use this model
Increase your knowledge and understanding of the concrete skills needed to help a person with a problem
Increase your knowledge and understanding of the adequate use of these interviewing skills

Deepen your knowledge in cultural differences that exist between (counsellors and) clients in perceptions of mental illnesses and help you gain insight into the multicultural counseling competencies needed to help clients from different cultures.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The WHO (Geneva, 2001) estimated that 450 million people will suffer from a mental or neurological illness at some point in their lives. That’s about 1 in every 4 people. Due to this 1 in 4 prevalence of mental illness, it is very likely that most of us know or have met someone who has been diagnosed with a mental illness. In this course, we’ll cover some of the main and more commonly occurring and diagnosed mental disorders as they appear in the DSM5. We’ll take a look at how these disorders are viewed from the traditional psychiatric perspective as well as how mental illness is viewed from other perspectives in the field of psychology, not only in terms of their causes, but also in terms of how they are described, understood and applied by practitioners in the field. By the end of the course, students will have gained an understanding of the scope of the field of clinical psychology, including how working in the field is not always as black and white as it may first appear.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: On completion of this course, students need to be able to:

column5: Have a basic understanding of the role of clinical assessment in the field of mental health

Know the basic documented history of mental illness and the field of clinical psychology, including the different models of understanding of mental illness and the causes of mental illness. Identify the diagnostic criteria for the specific disorders covered in the course (lectures and PBL activities)
Have and understanding of the DSM-5: it’s history, it’s organization and the main changes to the current edition, including the dimensional approach to mental illness diagnosis
Understand the diagnostic process and the concept of co-morbidity
Understand the role of culture in understanding and interpreting mental illness and mental health
Have a grasp of the overlap and differences between psychology and psychiatry

Develop a critical perspective on the field of clinical psychology, including having developed their own opinions (based on the course material) of what mental illness and mental health are, as well as what might distinguish abnormality from normality and how the field may or may nog contribute to stigma and discrimination

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111149,2023,Clinical Psychology: Anxiety and Stress,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. HK Wong'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Angststoornissen behoren tot de meest voorkomende psychiatrische stoornissen en kennen vele verschijningsvormen: zo zijn er de specifieke fobie, sociale fobie, paniekstoornis, agorafobie, gegeneraliseerde angststoornis, obsessief-compulsieve stoornis en de posttraumatische stress stoornis. De studenten zullen de verschillende angststoornissen van elkaar moeten kunnen onderscheiden. Daarnaast is het de bedoeling dat studenten het ontstaan van deze stoornissen kunnen verklaren: daartoe dienen ze niet alleen te beschikken over grondige kennis van algemene conditioneringprincipes, maar ook oog te hebben voor meer specifieke processen die bij iedere stoornis apart een rol spelen.

Stress is een belangrijk thema binnen de gezondheidspsychologie. In dit blok zal vooral worden stilgestaan bij de relatie tussen stress enerzijds en lichamelijke en geestelijke gezondheidsproblemen. Denk daarbij aan hart- en vaatziekten, kanker, en maagzweren, maar ook aan depressie en angststoornissen zoals de paniek- en de post-traumatische stress stoornis.

Studenten maken in dit blok kennis met persoonlijkheidsdiagnostiek. In dit blok oefenen de studenten met de Eysenck Personality Profiler (EPP). Verwacht wordt dat studenten zelf de EPP invullen, scoren, en hun profiel in verband brengen met normgegevens en een persoonsbeschrijving door een naaste. Tot slot dienen studenten hier op correcte wijze verslag van te leggen, waarbij er ook aandacht is voor zelfreflectie.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: De algemene doelstelling van dit blok is de aanwezige kennis van angststoornissen en stress te verdiepen en uit te breiden.
Specifiek kunnen de volgende doelen voor dit blok worden geformuleerd:

column5: Kennis hebben van biologische en psychologische processen die betrokken zijn bij stress en de ervaring er van.
Kennis hebben van de fenomenologie, de symptomatologie en de DSM-classificatie van de angststoornissen.
Kennis hebben van de etiologie van deze stoornissen.
Kennis hebben van de psychologische en farmacologische behandeling van angststoornissen.
In staat zijn om wetenschappelijke artikelen over psychische stoornissen kritisch te lezen en samen te vatten.
Kennis hebben van het interpreteren van een persoonlijkheidsvragenlijst aan de hand van normgegevens.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111760,2023,Clinical Psychology: Mental health challenges,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. A Harrewijn'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Clinical psychology focusses on disorders in mental health, which encompass unadjusted or problematic behaviour that significantly impacts daily life. These disorders are also known as psychological, psychiatric, or psychopathological disorders and their field of study is also referred to as psychopathology. The disorders are usually the result of a combination of biological, psychological, and social factors. In light of this, clinical psychology attempts to answer such questions as: How do psychological disorders arise? Why do they persist? What disorders can we distinguish? And how can we treat or prevent psychological disorders? In this course you will learn how psychological disorders are expressed, the theories on how they develop, and the treatment of these disorders.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The general objective of this course is to give you a broad overview of the field of clinical psychology. At the end of this course, you will be able to:

column2: • Describe, understand, and apply the diagnosis/classification of psychological disorders, in particular the DSM-5 classification system.

• Describe, understand, and apply the DSM-5 criteria, clinical typology, epidemiology, etiological theories with the corresponding empirical findings, and the most effective treatments for each of the disorders dealt with in this course.
• Observe patients, recognize symptoms of psychopathology, and apply a basic diagnosis.

• Conduct yourself professionally, by discussing the pros and cons of treatment options, by creating an open, safe space in the workgroups, and by treating experiences of others confidentially and with respect.
• Show empathy when other students give personal examples.
• Reflect on yourself as a psychologist and on how the study materials apply to you.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The lectures and literature will be offered in English to all students. The tutorial group meetings and exam will also be in English for the students in the International Bachelor of Psychology track. The national track offers tutorial group meetings and the exam in the Dutch language.</body>

column1: <body>In this course, which will be taught in Dutch, you will acquire the basic skills required to establish and lead a consultation as a physician. The course consists of two types of sessions that overlap Quads 1, 2, 3 and 4 of year 3: (1) Clinical reasoning (Klinisch redeneren, KR) and (2) Consultation (Consultvoering, CV). During the clinical reasoning sessions, you will learn how to make a diagnosis, after examining and analysing a patient’s complaints. You will learn what the importance is of knowing what kind of questions the physician should ask to obtain crucial and relevant information. In addition, you will learn which diseases can be the cause of a specific complaint, and how to make an accurate diagnosis by physical examinations and diagnostic tests. In the Consultation sessions, you will be able to practice the aforementioned skills. You will learn how to approach and interview patients, how to perform a physical examination, and how to interpret your findings. Due to the practical nature of the course, the assessment will be based mainly on practical exams performed in Quad 4.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The students will acquire the basic skills required to:
- Establish and lead an anamnesis as a physician
- Establish and lead a physical examination as a physician
- Make decisions regarding to diagnostic tests</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This course spans the entire academic year - starting quad 1 and ending quad 4 – and explicitly invites students from all majors. During the course we come together for eight sessions to read and work with – from cover to cover – one of the key texts in critical pedagogy by scholar, educator and activist bell hooks: Teaching to Transgress (1994). In this book, hooks writes from her experiences with racism, sexism and classism as a student and her own teaching practice to propose ‘education as the practice of freedom’ and the inclusive classroom as a transgressive space for change. Inspired by hooks’ work, in this course we will start by close reading and collectively making sense of hooks’ text, mixing it in with our own institutional setting and experiences along the way, to end up with students’ own pedagogical experimentations towards transgressing the boundaries of mind and body, public and private, teacher and student, knowledge and life.</body>

column1: The growing concern about scarcity of resources, pollution and emissions has increased the pressure on society to put more emphasis on sustainability development. From a company perspective there are several ramifications in terms of resource availability and costs, compliance with national and international legislation, and its perceived image to the outside world. Product reuse and recycling (“closing the loop”) can seriously contribute to business value creation and the reduction of environmental footprints at the same time. However, to sustain economically and ecologically viable operations one may have to thoroughly redesign existing supply chain processes (manufacturing, holding inventories, distributions) and integrate new ones (collection, recovery, redistribution).

This course enables you, as a future manager, to understand the relevant trade-offs related to economic, ecologic, and social aspects of doing business, and to apply the necessary tools and concepts to tackle the challenges in trying to close the loop.
Absences need to be notified. Alternative make-up assignments may follow.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand the procedures and concepts behind Closed-Loop Supply Chains (CLSCs)
• Use quantitative modeling to analyze operational, tactical and strategic decisions in CLSCs
• Understand the impact of making business decisions on the three sustainability pillars

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116927,2023,Coaching for Innovation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['LMM Gross, MSc', 'prof.dr. DA Stam', 'SGM Langeveld, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Coaching is a key factor for successful innovation. At the same time, the innovation context places unique as well as challenging demands on leaders and coaches. For example, different innovation contexts require specific behaviors and techniques. To prepare you to successfully lead innovation during your career, how to lead and coach innovation teams is one of the central themes of this course.

This hands-on course will equip you with the necessary knowledge and skills to become a successful innovation leader and coach. The course learnings will be delivered in an interactive way, with a focus on experiential learning. You will be able to take note of relevant theories and understand how these may work in practice, through exercises and role-plays. Moreover, the course will include multiple sessions of coaching training. The objective of these sessions is to equip you with the necessary skills to coach and manage multidisciplinary project teams. The course is open to both RSM and TU Delft students, which will further contribute to your skillset in working with people from different backgrounds.

After the weekly lectures and the coaching training in Block 3, you will apply your new coaching skills in Blocks 4 and 5, by coaching multidisciplinary teams of Bachelor students (BSc BA/IBA and BSc Applied Physics) who follow the course Technology Management. By taking part in this unique opportunity, you will be able to practice leading teams in a safe learning environment.

In Block 3 students will attend 1 session per week (3 hrs – mandatory). Students can miss a maximum of 2 sessions in Block 3, with good reason and informing the lecturers in advance. For each missed session in Block 3, students need to complete a compensatory written assignment, summarizing the learnings from the session that they missed. They can compile this assignment by studying the slides and readings, as well as interviewing 2-3 fellow students regarding what the main practical learnings of the session were.
The sessions in Blocks 4 and 5 concern the actual coaching. During Blocks 4 and 5, there are overall four mandatory attendance dates.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand the leadership/coaching theories that are central to leading for innovation
• Utilize coaching techniques and skills to inspire and motivate others to innovate
• Coach interdisciplinary teams in a coaching team to successfully complete (technological) innovation projects

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course you will study the mental processes involved in digital media processing. Four basic cognitive functions will be covered:

Among the topics that will be addressed are the following. Do people have an attentional bias for negative information? Do people forget information once it has been discredited? To what extent does conspiracy thinking rely on the same mechanisms we use to comprehend information? Why are the digital media a fertile soil for the spread of misinformation and conspiracy theories? How do our cognitive biases impact our social media use? In what ways can scientists research these issues? How can we minimize the negative impact of digital media messages on our cognitive system?</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The main objective of this course is for you to gain a basic understanding of the interaction between cognitive processes and the digital media. Students will be introduced to important theories behind basic cognitive processes, such as attention, memory, comprehension, and thinking. You will become familiar with empirical research on digital media use that is informed by these theories to address questions concerning topics such as misinformation, desinformation, conspiracy thinking, and thinking biases, as well as how to counter the negative impact of these processes.  At the end of this course, you will be familiar with major theories of cognitive information processing. You will be able to apply these theories to aspects of digital media use and thus acquire an understanding of digital media processing. You will have learned how psychologists conduct a variety of research tools, including surveys, experiments, and data mining, to understand how the digital media affect our thought processes. Furthermore, you will gain experience in critically evaluating research on cognition and the digital media. Finally, you will be able to think about  ways in which the potential negative impact of the digital media on our thought processes can be mitigated.</body>

column1: Cognitive Neurosciences is a specialist course in the master Brain and Cognition, Erasmus School of Social and Behavioral Sciences.

Building on the bachelor course the Brain and practical Brain Anatomy, the possibilities and limitations of the neuroscientific methods that are used to study cognitive functions are studied in further depth.
Depending on recent developments in the domain of cognitive neurosciences a number of themes will be selected, from the following research areas:
The themes will be studied against the background of different research methods:
Special attention will be given to the advantages and limitations of each of these techniques and to how these limitations are compensated by other techniques.
Students are divided in small groups. For each class, two empirical papers with with opposing findings are contrasted in terms theory, methods, and data.
In light of these articles each small group has to perform one of the following tasks:
- discussion: critical discussion/contrast of the controversy
- proposal: present a research design to solve the controversy

column1: We have nearly 8 billion people on earth, and all of us think. But why do we think? How do we think? And what happens if we stop thinking?

This course explores the answers to these profound questions. It will go further than the course ‘Brain & Behaviour’ as it will introduce concepts like schemas, mental imagery, categorisation and language, to understand how the content of thoughts are established. Furthermore, this course delves into memory and attention. In addition, it will introduce the study of complex thinking abilities, such as problem solving, reasoning and decision making, and looks at the deterioration of cognitive processes: What happens if we are unable to think properly?

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111142,2023,Cognitive Psychology: Thinking and Remembering,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,"['BZ Borcsok', 'dr. SKA Verheyen']",,"Inhoud

Menselijke cognitie kan beschouwd worden als een snelle weg waarlangs wij ons aan veranderende omstandigheden in onze omgeving aanpassen, naast de tragere methoden van genetische mutatie en (operant) leren. Hoe helpt aandacht ons efficiënt met de informatie uit onze externe en interne omgeving om te gaan, en wat gebeurt er als aandacht faalt? Kennis en kennisrepresentatie vormen een tweede thema. Relevante vragen daarbij zijn: op welke wijze beelden wij informatie uit onze omgeving innerlijk af en hoe gebruiken we de kennis bij het interpreteren van de wereld om ons heen? De structuur en het functioneren van onze geheugens is een derde onderwerp. Hoe wordt informatie onthouden voor de korte en lange termijn? Wat gebeurt er als we herinneringen ophalen? Het laatste thema betreft redeneren en denken. Zijn er wetmatigheden te onderkennen in ons redeneren? Hoe denkt de expert en hoe de beginner in een bepaald domein?

Het blok biedt een introductie in de centrale onderwerpen van de cognitieve psychologie. Hierbij spelen cognitieve processen als begrijpen, kennisverwerving en kennisrepresentatie, aandacht, herinneren, denken, en probleemoplossen een centrale rol. Studenten maken kennis met het klassieke model van het informatieverwerkende systeem dat aan deze processen ten grondslag ligt.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Many groups, for example, countries, juries, or families, take important collective decisions via voting methods. You can think about parliamentary and presidential elections, monetary policy boards at central banks setting monetary policy, or juries in sport and court. Elections are not only an important cornerstone of modern democracies, they also determine the fate of countries by electing leaders and shape policy expectations. For example, households adjust their consumption patterns due to expected altered tax rates, and corporations adjust strategies in response to anticipated changes in market regulations.

Elections and reaching decision via voting more generally are of high societal relevance, but how shall we organize these votes? How can we ensure that collective decisions respect normative values shared by the members? This course will cover the main principles of Social and Collective Choice in theory and practice to answer these questions. We will study different voting methods, their properties, and how they affect voting outcomes. Theoretically, the course will introduce theoretical frameworks to analyze different problems when a group needs to make a decision. Empirically, the course will present many interesting real-life cases that put theory into practice. Finally, the course will present a behavioral perspective on Social Choice and Collective decisions. The theoretical part is mostly based on the assumption that individual members act rationally. Yet, how do people vote in practice? What psychological factors are important to consider? To enhance the behavioral part, the course will present insights from recent experiments and field studies.
Week I: The core ideas of social choice
Week II: Two alternatives - information aggregation, Condorcet Jury Theorem
Week III: Two Alternatives: preference aggregation, May’s Theorem
Week IV: Three alternatives – Arrow’s impossibility theorem
Week V: Strategic voting, manipulability, Gibbart-Satterwhaite theorem, Median Voter Theorem, Duncan Black
Week VI: Ballot aggregation functions, Peter C. Fishburn, Approval Voting, Range Voting

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of the course, you should be able to advise a group of people on how to design their voting method to achieve a fairer election.
Sub-objectives to achieve the main learning objective. You will be able to:

column2: • describe the core concepts of Social Choice Theory and Behavioral Social Choice.
• describe a variety of real-world voting methods.
• apply theoretical frameworks to analyze voting methods.
• demonstrate why so many seemingly paradoxical election results are observed in the real world.
• assess the pros and cons of voting methods.
• develop recommendations on how to design fairer elections.

column1: Combinatorial optimisation deals with finding an optimal solution from a finite set of feasible solutions. Since enumerating this set is practically infeasible in general, one tries to exploit the problem structure to find an optimal solution in a computationally efficient way. In this course, we develop techniques for combinatorial optimisation problems.

This course uses knowledge of FEB21009X Linear Programming, FEB21010X Mathematical Methods and FEB21011X(S) Introduction to Programming, and is required for FEB22009 Introductory Seminar Econometrics and Operations Research and FEB23004 Quantitative Models in Logistics.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To recognise and model combinatorial optimisation problems as integer programming problems.
• To understand the basic theory and techniques to solve integer programming problems.
• To master the basic techniques to solve some specific combinatorial optimisation problems.
• To be able to implement the basic solution techniques in a software package.

column1: De combinatorische optimalisering houdt zich bezig met het vinden van een optimale oplossing uit een eindige verzameling van toegelaten oplossingen. Omdat volledige enumeratie van deze verzameling vaak onpraktisch is door het zeer grote aantal toegelaten oplossingen, probeert men gericht te zoeken naar een optimale oplossing door gebruik te maken van de aanwezige structuur. In dit college worden oplossingsmethoden voor combinatorische optimaliseringsproblemen behandeld. Technieken die worden behandeld zijn:

Dit vak gebruikt kennis van FEB21009 Lineair Programmeren, FEB21010 Wiskundige Methoden en FEB21011 Inleiding Programmeren, en is nodig voor FEB22009 Basiswerkcollege Econometrie en Operations Research and FEB23004 Quantitative Models in Logistics.

column1: This course unravels the multiplicity of commercial contracts underlying international trade. It offers students an insight in the fundamentals of a commercial contract. Despite the differences between these contracts in the contract chain, each commercial contract contains - to a large extent - similar clauses or types of clauses (e.g. on hardship and frustration, on the exclusion of liability, on damages, on confidentiality and arbitration & dispute resolution, etc). A first part will thus focus on:

column2: • contract formation (validity of the contract), the interpretation of contracts and the principle of good faith;
• allocation of liabilities (exoneration clauses, warranties & insurances), duties and risks;
• typical clauses in long-term agreements such as the right to set-off, hardship and frustration;
• multi-party transactions: the relativity of contract and the techniques of assignment, novation and (contractual) subrogation;
• the consequences of a breach of contract: remedies; and on

column1: In the course’s second part we turn our eye to some specific contracts. The focus lies with the sale of goods contract; agency, distribution and franchise agreements.
As it is vital to learn the basics of contract drafting, this course also offers students a workshop and an assignment dedicated to helping them develop the legal skills of contract drafting.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114014,2023,Commercial Law,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. FL Stevens', 'prof.mr. FGM Smeele', 'prof.mr.dr. W de Wit']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Commercial Law focuses on the contract of sale as the Master plan governing the organization of international commercial transactions. In it, the parties not only provide rules about when and where to deliver what quantity of which commodity for what price, but also for who should contract for transportation and insurance, as well as for payment and/or financing of the commercial transaction. Together, all these commercial contracts build a cluster with dynamics of its own. A key role is played by the documents reflecting these contracts. To name a few, the Bill of Exchange, the Bill of Lading, the Insurance Policy or Insurance Certificate, the Letter of Credit and the Letter of Indemnity. All these documents convey the message that in international commerce, contracts generally involve and affect third parties. From the moment of issuance, most of these documents are meant to pass from hand to hand until they reach their final destination where they will play their part. Each contract has certain peculiarities in accordance with the requirements of international trade. Attention will be given to standardized contract forms and customary abbreviations such as CIF, FOB, CAD LC and so on. Other topics to be discussed include:
- The phenomenon of negotiability of documents;
- The various roles played by the bill of lading and the implications of the presentation rule;

- The abstract payment obligation of a bank under a letter of credit or a letter of undertaking and the so-called strict conformity rule as applied by banks in their handling of commercial documents: strict to the letter of their instructions;
- Insurance for the benefit of (as yet unknown) persons interested in the goods.

Much of international trade is subjected to international Conventions and powerful customs and standardized contracts, often subject to English law and London arbitration. As of consequence these international standards will form an important basis for our studies into commercial law.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After completion of this course, the student can interpret and analyse critically, the main aspects of an international commercial transaction in relation to sale of goods, documents of title, banking, transport, insurance and customs law according to English law and from a civil law perspective, taking into account important international uniform law conventions. Further, the student will be able to develop a personal point of view, enter into a discussion, observe and analyse important developments, with regard to this topic and is able to apply his knowledge, to a given set of facts (case).</body>

column1: In this course you will learn more about the different aspects and the tools to use for the communication of your research.
Description of the modules All participants are asked to have a look at all modules, but to choose 3 from the 5 modules to deliver the assignment.

column2: • Summarize (how to summarize your research (or research proposal), both for an academic and a non-academic audience).
• Presentation (how to give a presentation and how to make an infographic or poster to visualize your research (question).

• Publication strategy This module will discuss how to choose journals or book publishers, how to assess their quality and how to make a good strategy for successful publication. After this module, you will be able to create your own publication plan.

• Your audience and how to reach it At the end of this module you will be aware of your different audiences, you will know more about societal relevance and impact, and you will have learned how to make your research visible for your audience by using several tools.

• Personal branding In today’s world of social media, it is more important than ever to ensure that you have an online presence, a ‘personal brand’, that looks professional and can be used for networking purposes.

column1: After completing this module, you will know how to ‘brand’ yourself through LinkedIn, what the most important elements of an optimized LinkedIn profile of an academic are, and how to promote your research to a specific audience.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: As the world’s urban population grows, the living conditions in cities differ drastically. Socio-economic divides, disabilities, and differences linked to gender, race and ethnicity have important consequences for people’s everyday experiences in/with the city and for their sense of belonging.

This course focuses on the key role of communication in sustaining and challenging these inequalities. The starting point is the acknowledgement that (economic) equality and social (e.g., cultural, racial, ethnic, gender) difference can go hand in hand. This means that socio-economic justice is not about everyone being the same, but about gender, ethnic, racial and other differences being properly recognized and represented. Recognition and representation are communication rights: They enable social groups to have a fair say in society and in the distribution of its resources.

Take Rotterdam as an example. Consider how the city is drawn and labeled in tourist maps and business brochures; how diverse city inhabitants and neighborhoods are portrayed in the media. Consider what corporate and municipal actors mean when they call the city “smart” and who benefits from that smartness. Consider the efforts of citizens who –wanting to be recognized as such— creatively claim spaces and visibility. Overall, consider which ways of being Rotterdammer and perspectives on the city prevail and why.

In dealing with these issues—not only in relation to Rotterdam, but to cities around the world—the course strongly relies on students’ own background and experiences. It pays attention to both the local and the cross-national from an interdisciplinary and critical perspective.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students have knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Critical and interdisciplinary theoretical perspectives on social inequality.

• Communicative practices related to specific inequalities and efforts to contest them in contemporary urban spaces.

column1: Students have developed the skills to:

column2: • Critically reflect upon, compare and articulate the strengths and weaknesses of different perspectives on the topic.

Students will have a general understanding of 'ethics' for the media professional. They will be introduced to different perspectives in (social) philosophy with an emphasis on different modes of ethical reasoning. This understanding will enable the students to evaluate how well or how poorly standards in the field (e.g., professional ethics in journalism or public relations), are constructed and formulated. Students will not only be able to identify the ethical perspectives underlying these standards, but also to identify the different ethical argumentations implied within these. Through readings and class discussions connected to real life cases, students will be trained in ethical reasoning and form personal ethical underpinnings for their future careers.
Note: The lectures of this course are mandatory.

• Formulate and defend their own ethical principles and reflect on their own intercultural competencies.

column1: T-mobile creates a YouTube viral video by capitalizing on the already viral flashmob videos online. Marc Jacobs gains a loyal following on Twitter through his personable tweets. KLM, designs a media campaign encouraging people to ‘stewardess’ themselves, gaining significant attention with well over 55,000 new fans on Facebook in just 7 days. Whether it is electronics, fashion non-profits, all companies and organizations seem challenged by new communications possibilities in the social media era. However, most are still experimenting with their communications and some are hesitant to adapt.

This course provides an overview and application of how companies and organizations are using social media. The course examines key patterns and ongoing challenges in social media marketing based on recent empirical findings, particularly in relation to social media and reputational risk, as well as social customer relationship management. In teams, students will focus on a particular theme and choose a particular company or organization. Then, applying their academic knowledge, they will conduct a practical consulting project. The course cumulates in a pitch to the company (in class) and a final written proposal using insights gained throughout the term. This workshop will be of interest to students keen on entering the private sector as consultants and communication specialists.

• Implement diverse methods of collecting and analyzing customer data
• Design and pitch a professional proposal for companies or organizations on their social media practices
• Effectively work in internationally diverse teams and identify key patterns and ongoing challenges in social media campaigns

column1: The course Communication Skills I is part of the learning path Vocational Skills. During your Bachelor and Master Program you will participate in several courses that are part of this learning path and that will build on each other helping you develop into an academically trained psychologist. The focus of the Vocational Skills learning path is on the development of important professional skills such as psychodiagnostics, communication, intervention and professional ethics. The aim is to help you gradually develop from a novice to a professional that is equipped with all the necessary skills to enter the labor market.

The goal of this first course in communication skills is to increase your knowledge and understanding of the skills required for effective communication in a professional counselling setting with a client. The reading materials, homework assignments, and activities during the practical sessions will help you develop the basic communication skills (listening and regulating skills) that are needed during the initial interview with a client (intake / problem clarification phase*). The goal of this initial interview is to establish a good working relation with the client and to explore and bring order into the client’s problem. You will practice the basic communication skills by performing exercises and role-plays in class and by giving and receiving feedback from your fellow students and trainer.

The final assignment of this practical consists of 1) a video recording of a problem clarification interview that you have conducted with a client and 2) a self-reflection report based on this interview.
*In this practical we will use the helping model of Egan (1994), in which three principal stages of the counselling process are distinguished:

This practical will focus on the first phase of this model – Problem Clarification. The other two phases will be covered extensively in the practicals in the second and third year of the Psychology Bachelor Program. </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course, you will be able to:

column2: • Distinguish the three counselling stages in the helping model of Egan (1994) (Problem Clarification, Gaining New Insights, Treatment).
• Understand the main goals of the Problem Clarification Phase.
• Understand the function of the different basic communication skills (listening and regulating skills) in a problem clarification interview.

• Effectively apply the basic communication skills in an initial interview with a client (problem clarification), taking into account the purpose of the interview, the (professional) context and the frame of reference of the client.
• Support the learning process of fellow students by observing interviews and providing adequate feedback on their behavior.
• Critically reflect on your own actions and performance in the final problem clarification interview.
• Formulate clear learning objectives and a concrete improvement plan from these reflections.

column1: The introduction and use of new communication technologies in society can never be told in just one story. It is a process of mutual shaping; society and technology influence each other, with various outcomes, opportunities and impacts for different groups of people in various contexts. In this course, we will look at the interplay between communication technologies and society. The course is both historical and thematic in nature and offers a critical exploration of (a selection of) cultural, social, political and economic impacts of various communication technologies on our society. During this course, students will work on an online portfolio that contains both learning resources, questions and assignments. The tutorials are interactive and will challenge the students to apply the lessons learned in activities and discussions.

column1: Graduates of the IBCoM program can take on specialized communication jobs in a variety of fields, including marketing, management, sales, corporate communications, public relations, internal communications, government, public affairs, education, journalism, the media and entertainment industries, and the art world.

This course will help IBCoM students orient on the opportunities in these professional fields, in preparation for their internships (required in the second year of the program), and for the job market after they have graduated from the program. During the lectures, guest speakers from a variety of relevant fields will present their views on the labor market in communication and media and discuss the issues that they consider key to acquiring and fulfilling particular positions or internships in their field. In the meetings students will train and develop their skills to find and prepare for an internship or job relevant to their career goals.
Note: This course is only open to IBCoM students.
Students should have completed the course Communication and Media Labour Market Orientation (CM2008) before they may start with the internship (CM3041) in BA-2.

<body>In this course, we will examine communication as it relates to organizations and organizing. The course will focus on the history, major theories, and contemporary issues and dilemmas of organizations in an international and globalizing environment. Topics covered are communication processes and structure, organizational culture, leadership, branding and identity, power, teamwork, and gender in organizations. Critiques of organizational communication systems, structures and theories are also presented.</body>

column1: This course presents an overview of state-of-the art approaches to understanding media and communication as social forces. The first part of the course considers how media and communication feature in processes of major social change(s). It does so through the concept of mediatization, which approaches social, cultural, political and economic practices as increasingly organized around the workings and logic of the media. Case studies will illustrate how different fields and institutions are greatly affected by such media logic.

The second part of the course focuses on the different ways in which we can understand media and communication as technologies in governing the behavior of citizens in contemporary society. The course emphasizes current developments in media and communications in an international perspective to provide context and comparison. Course activities include in-depth discussion of key issues and questions, in-class assignments, presentations and discussions of student assignments and coursework.</body>

column1: This course has as general theme European company law and corporate restructuring in the internal market of the EU and concerns legal as well as fiscal aspects. European company law has reshaped national company laws of the EU-member states. The course starts with the relevant aspects of European company law, including harmonization of company law, freedom of establishment, representation, supranational companies and the relevant aspects of European insolvency law, followed by legal and fiscal aspects of national and cross border mergers & acquisitions. Further, different forms of corporate restructuring will be discussed during the lectures. Finally, aspects of European labour law, more specific, transfer of undertaking, will be dealt with.
The course is taught on the basis of the compulsory reading materials, case law materials and practical cases. Active participation and discussion of the students is expected and motivated.
If possible, students will be encouraged to attend a conference or a seminar on a relevant topic somewhere in The Netherlands.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Upon completion of this course the student has or is able to:
- thoroughly understand the meaning and significance of the harmonization program of company law in Europe and how national company law is influenced by it;
- independently analyze, assess and evaluate trends and developments of freedom of establishment for companies in Europe;
- independently analyze and solve legal questions concerning representation;
- in-depth knowledge of the structure, characteristics and developments of supranational companies;
- independently analyze and solve legal questions concerning national and cross border mergers and acquisitions;
- independently analyze and solve legal questions concerning European insolvency law;
- independently analyze and solve questions concerning relevant tax aspects of national and cross border mergers and acquisitions;
- independently analyze and solve legal questions concerning transfer of undertaking;
- work together in order to write an academic paper on a relevant topic
- critically discuss the topics and literature of the course and to defend a formulated proposition in that respect.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114137,2023,Comparative Constitutional Law,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. NS Efthymiou'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The idea underlying this course is to present constitutional law from a comparative perspective, in order to improve the knowledge of the student's national constitutional system. For that reason, not only constitutional texts will be compared and analysed, but also specific features of constitutional systems, such as separation of powers and the rule of law, judicial review (or the absence of judicial review), and parliaments and governments.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Constitutional law has become increasingly important not only in the context of national legal systems, but also in an international context, as part of attempts to rebuild states that are in crisis or have become ‘failed states’ where stability and security are jeopardized, peaceful means of solving conflicts are under pressure and the rights of private citizens are not guaranteed. This course aims at increasing the familiarity of students with basic notions of constitutional law in various constitutional systems. Focus will be on substantive themes and on method.
Students are expected to give a group presentation in which they link themes that are present in the literature to constitutional questions that have arisen in their home country.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115139,2023,Comparative Health Policy,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['dr. JJ Schuurmans', 'dr. LE Oldenhof', 'M Kalisvaart', 'OS van der Woerd, MSc', 'prof.dr. HM van de Bovenkamp', 'prof.dr. RA Bal', 'SA Hasnida, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: How can we find out why countries that are similar in many ways sometimes have very different healthcare policies? Or, the other way around, why countries that at first sight appear to be very different, turn out to have rather similar policies? The aim of this course is to provide you with theoretical perspectives and methodological tools to answer the question of how to perform a comparative health policy analysis to explain cross-country differences and similarities.

We use an institutional theory framework. Institutional theory looks at the ‘building blocks’ of society. The relationships between state, market and community differ between countries. For instance, the relative dominance of the state in country A versus the market in country B can explain differences between their healthcare policies. Institutional theory also looks at how these building blocks or the relationships between them change overtime and what the role of past decisions and human action is in causing (or blocking) change.

We use a case-oriented research design to find out what is inside the ‘black box’ of healthcare policies across countries. This is a qualitative approach, in which we are not so much interested in finding correlations or testing hypotheses, but rather in learning more about the stories behind the policies. Concepts from institutional theory will help to structure the search for information and to interpret the findings.

The group paper assignment will determine 60% of the final course grade; the individual assignment will make up the other 40%. The minimal grade for each assignment is a 4.0, which can be compensated with the other grade in order to complete the course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course, you will be able to execute a comparative health policy analysis and to judge the possibilities for cross-country learning.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114144,2023,Comparative Law,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['prof.dr. FJM De Ly'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course some of the basic tenets of comparative law are dealt with. First, the focus is on classification and characteristics of the major legal systems in the world. Apart from the French, German and English systems, also non-European legal systems are discussed such as the United States. In addition, uniform law (including European harmonization) is analyzed (objectives, manifestations, instruments, uniform interpretation, organizations and coordination). Finally, the methodology of comparative legal research is discussed.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The objective of the course is to familiarize the participating students with the characteristics of the major legal traditions, with basic notions of uniform law (including European harmonization) and with the methodology of comparative law research.

After completion of the course, the student should have an understanding of the characteristics and structure of the major legal traditions and of uniform law. In addition, he should be capable of doing comparative legal research.
The student shall be assessed on the basis of knowledge or on the basis of the skill of writing a comparative law paper.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/110719,2023,Comparative Public Policy,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. M Schiller', 'prof.dr. PWA Scholten']",,"Inhoud

<body>Benchmarking and lesson drawing by comparing public policies are important strategies for policy innovation. At various policy levels, policy actors are looking at each other to study to find out what policies have been developed, what the assumptions behind these policies were, how they have been implemented, to what extent these policies were either more or less effective and how policy change was organized. Another strategy has been to compare policy domains, examining for instance why some issues rise on the agenda more easily or are implemented very differently across policy domains. Yet, comparing public policies comes with many difficulties. To overcome these hurdles, this course adopts a theory-driven design for comparing public policies. More precisely we will look at public policies from four angles, i.e. the:

The course is directed to the explanation of public policies: what mode of public policy provides the best explanation for the design, implementation and effectiveness of public policies? Taking the policy cycle and its various stages [agenda setting, policy formulation, policy implementation, policy evaluation and policy change as a point of departure, students have to carry-out a comparative policy analysis on a policy issue of their own choice. The design should be presented in the form of a poster. The findings have to be reported in a research paper paying due attention to the course literature.

In addition, this course will discuss strategies for policy learning based on comparative analyses. How to design a comparative analysis in such a way that the findings will lead to policy learning, and what to do when research findings are available to ensure that policy change takes place? The course will be completed with a cross-national comparison in terms of policy convergence (or divergence) in policy settings such as the European Union (OMC, exchange of best-practices)?</body>

column1: Competition policy (also called ""antitrust policy"") is a term used broadly to describe intervention by public authorities to ensure competition in markets for goods and services. This course aims at making students familiar with the application of economic arguments in European competition law. Comparisons with U.S. antitrust law are included where appropriate for a better understanding of cases and the implications of legislation and court rulings on economic efficiency.
This course is open for EMLE students only.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115138,2023,Competition in Health Care Markets,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['dr. AF Roos', 'dr. P Makai', 'dr.ir. RCMH Douven', 'prof.dr. M Varkevisser']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Following years of controls, rationing and expenditure caps, many countries introduce market-based health care reforms. Competitive interactions between health care providers and payers create incentives that affect market players’ behavior and the price, quality and quality of health care services. This is especially true in the United States, where the majority of total health expenditures are privately financed and prices, quantities and qualities for health care services are determined by market interactions. But competitive forces also shape strategic interactions in other health care systems (for example, the Netherlands), including those which are mostly publicly financed and where prices are regulated (for example, the British NHS).

In this multidisciplinary course, students are introduced to (i) determinants of market structure, prices, quality, provider networks and competition in health insurance and provider markets as well as (ii) the basic principles of competition law. Unique attributes in health care not only affect the functioning of market-based health care systems, but also complicate competition enforcement. Therefore, competition (or: antitrust) enforcement in the health care sector is also extensively discussed.
The central aim of this course is to study:

column2: • the functioning and performance of competitive health care systems
• the use and adequacy of competition enforcement in health care
• the challenges related to competition (enforcement) in health care.

column1: To that end, the course introduces students to state-of-the-art concepts and literature in the field of industrial organization of health care markets and antitrust enforcement in health care.
The course consists of pre-recorded video lectures and interactive live meetings for questions & answers and in-depth discussion of practical examples.
Some classes will be taught by guest teachers.</body>

column1: By the end of this course the student is able to:

column2: • Evaluate the functioning and performance of competitive health care markets
<li>Assess the use and adequacy of the enforcement of main competition instruments in health care from both an economic and legal perspective:

column1: Understand the theoretical & empirical challenges related to competition and the enforcement of competition policy in health care.

column1: Strategic management is a discipline at the forefront of business research and practice. This advanced course on strategic management particularly focuses on what is perhaps the most pressing issue for practicing managers: how can I make my firm outperform its competitors? To formulate such value-creating strategies, managers must identify a suitable business model, formulate strategies, identify their firms’ core capabilities, learn from their and others’ experiences, develop new ways of outcompeting their rivals, and potentially balance such competition with ecosystem cooperation. Critically, they have to do all of this while adapting to massive disruptions to business-as-usual by the rapid development of AI and the proliferation of platform forms of organization. To develop a holistic view on business that takes these needs into account, students in this course will be exposed to the key aspects and challenges of putting in place a system that delivers and captures value under such conditions.

The emphasis does not lay on identifying the “right” answer. Instead, the focus of this course is on creating a learning environment that stimulates students’ critical engagement with the study material. Teaching methods therefore include a combination of lectures and supervised workshops in which student groups will work on concrete projects that will allow them to practically apply their knowledge. To develop their knowledge, skills, and attitudes, students will read articles from leading academic and managerial journals as well as analyze business cases. Students must prepare the assigned material prior to each class to be able to contribute to the interactive classroom discussions as well as being able to complete the group assignments. To support students’ learning experience, the instructor will be available for questions during these assignments.

column2: Business Models and Value Creation Strategies: The essence of a business model is in defining the manner by which the enterprise delivers value to customers, entices customers to pay for value, and converts those payments to profit. We will discuss how firms can develop new business models to successfully compete in today’s marketplace. We will further discuss how firms can develop the dynamic capabilities needed to constantly adapt its business model in response to technological, societal, and environmental changes.

Competitive Dynamics and Interfirm Rivalry: A fundamental link in strategic management is the relationship competitor analysis and interfirm rivalry. Competitor analysis is often flawed because managers often misidentify their key rivals, especially in an era in which industry boundaries become blurred and competitors often emerge from places that one would not expect such as emerging markets. We will discuss how managers can safeguard against flaws in competitive analysis and how competitive dynamics influence value creation.

Organizational Learning and Experimentation: In a world of increasing complexity and uncertainty, even the most careful strategic plans are bound to have critical blind spots. How should managers adjust their firms’ strategies in circumstances in which careful forward-looking planning is likely to be ineffective? One suggestion is that firms can learn. We will discuss in greater detail the sources of limits to conventional strategic planning and how firms can institute organizational learning as distinct strategy to potentially overcome some of these limitations. Special focus will be given to lean strategies and experimentation.

Digitalization and Emergence of Business Ecosystems: The 4th Industrial Revolution is often linked to an increasing trend towards digitalization. Digitalization is a phenomenon that refers to the use of digital technologies to change business models and provide value producing opportunities in the present or future. We will discuss how digitalization may alter existing business models and discuss its implications for the economy. The increasing trend towards digitalization is probably best reflected in the rise of business ecosystems. While the phenomenon of business ecosystems is not new, it has gained more attention over the past decade with the emergence of global players such as Facebook, Uber, or Microsoft which successfully orchestrate such business ecosystems. We will discuss the features of business ecosystems with a focus on multi-sided platforms as a particular salient form of such ecosystems. We will also discuss the role of data analytics and artificial intelligence (AI), with a specific focus on their implications for the future of work.

Platform Dynamics, Governance and Competitive Strategy in Platforms: This part of the course will delve into the unique dynamics of platform-based disruption, platform-based businesses, including network effects, multi-sided markets, and platform governance. It will also explore the intricacies of within platform competition. Furthermore, the discussion will encompass strategies for the successful launch and growth of platforms. Central to this theme is the exploration of competitive strategies within platform environments, focusing on how firms can leverage these dynamics for effective competition.

AI Strategy: This portion of the course will tackle how artificial intelligence is revolutionizing traditional industries while simultaneously unlocking novel competitive opportunities. We will delve into the capabilities of AI and its strategic implications. The course will also engage with the ethical implications of AI deployment in various sectors, raising critical awareness about responsible and sustainable AI usage. As AI disruption may become a norm in the business landscape, we will examine its broader impacts on industries and economies. This discussion will encompass both the challenges and opportunities posed by AI disruption, ensuring a nuanced understanding of this phenomenon.

• Implementation of Digital Transformation: Following the examination of the phenomenon platforms and AI, the course will shift focus to the practical aspects of implementing a digital transformation strategy. This entails exploring change management practices suitable for digital transitions, understanding agile methodologies and their role in accelerating digital transformation, and the crucial part of leadership in guiding such transitions. The module will emphasize the significance of an adaptable and responsive leadership style in navigating the complexities of digital transformation. This part of the course aims to provide a holistic view of the processes and strategies involved in digital transformation, equipping students with practical knowledge for navigating the contemporary digital landscape.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To appraise the value of scientific research for business strategy and apply it
• To evaluate an existing strategy of a business in new or unfamiliar contexts
• To communicate your conclusions about a business’s competitive threats and opportunities
• To integrate strategic management theories to develop business strategies and realize organizational goals with incomplete or limited information
• To assess the larger socio-economic context within which firms operate and how digital disruption affects society as a whole

column1: <body>After successful completion of this course, students will be familiar with the Python programming language and its ecosystem. They will be able to use this knowledge to solve problems in risk management and derivatives pricing. In particular, students will be able to compute the Value at Risk using multiple methods and be aware of pros and cons of each of the methods. Further, students will be able to apply numerical methods (binomial trees and Monte Carlo simulation) to price derivatives and they will know how the numerical methods are related to theoretical models (Black-Scholes).</body>

column1: The course starts by introducing various Computer Science topics relevant for Business Analytics. After that, in order to be able to query relational databases, the SQL query language will be studied. As means to process Big Data, we will look at parallel computing models, focusing on the Map-Reduce parallel computing style. Also, with the purpose of reducing the number of computations for finding similar items (a fundamental data mining problem), we will describe Locality-Sensitive Hashing. In addition, with the aim to address the information overload problem (on the Web), we will discuss recommender systems.

In order to better assimilate the topics covered during lectures, the students will work in teams on several assignments on the discussed topics. The students will also write a report describing the proposed solutions. In addition a larger individual assignment that involves programming will result in a short paper.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Have an overview of Computer Science topics (e.g., Machine Learning, Data Mining, Query Languages, Recommender Systems, etc.) relevant for Business Analytics.
• Know Computer Science techniques (e.g., Locality-Sensitive Hashing, SQL, Map-Reduce, Matrix Factorization, etc.) applicable for Business Analytics.
• Exploit Computer Science techniques for building Business Analytics solutions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course focuses upon certain concrete legal problems that are related to the use of information technology in society. Examples are: legal protection and rights with respect to software, databases and data; e-commerce and electronic markets; legal questions related to the use of artificial intelligence, blockchain technology and ‘smart contracts’; privacy protection and computer crime; liability of intermediary service providers.

Students will learn to analyse these problems and examine possible solutions within the context of their own national legal system and of harmonized EU legislation. The problems of integrating technological developments in areas that have always been paper-based, and the role and use of 'electronic signatures' in these areas will also be examined. In addition to these practical aspects, the impact of technology on the development of legal principles will be discussed.

Furthermore, information technology has given rise to new possibilities for legal practice as well as for performing (empirical) legal research. A term that is sometimes used for this is ‘LegalTech’. Several practical applications connected with this will be discussed during the course. Among these are new ways to increase legal knowledge, as well as to manage this knowledge and to apply it.

By working on two practical assignments, students will have the opportunity to apply parts of the subject matter of this course in practice. For one of the assignments, they will have the opportunity to perform ‘jurimetrical research’ into judicial decision making. By analysing case reports, a prediction model featuring the most important decision factors can be built.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The aim of this course is twofold:
•    to familiarize students with the social changes brought about by the 'Information Society', and to place these within a legal context;

•    to assess the impact of IT developments for the legal profession (sometimes referred to as ‘LegalTech’) and to gain insight in new tools and methodologies (for instance, for performing legal research) that are (or will be) available to lawyers.
After the course, students will be able to
•    understand and describe the way in which technology is developing;
•    formulate legal questions and problems relevant to our current ‘Information Society’;
•    provide solutions to these questions and problems;
•    discern the essential characteristics of the internet, as far as these are legally relevant;
•    assess the impact of IT on legal practice;
•    perform empirical research, as a group member, with respect to (data relating to) legal decision making;
•    explain the importance of proper knowledge management for legal organizations, and the role information systems can play for that.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Categories and concepts make up the knowledge people have about things and people in the world. Being able to make a connection between our earlier experiences and new interactions with the environment ensure that we can recognise and understand new things and people. For most people this is a fairly simple process which runs largely automatically, but understanding it from a psychological viewpoint is highly complicated. Four broad topics will be covered during this course: Learning categories and the formation of prototypes and stereotypes, and the consequences for categorizing things and people. The effect of brain damage or abnormalities on categorisation and concept representations, with a special focus on deficits that result in the inability to recognize particular categories of things such as animals or human faces. Embodied cognition, which will address the question whether bodily sensations or actions are involved in the representations of categories. The grounding of concepts in the brain, addressing the question where and how conceptual knowledge is represented by the brain, and which methods can be used to investigate this question.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Students learn the most important theories and empirical data on the way people represent their knowledge and the influence this has on behaviour. Attention will also be devoted to research methods both in theory and practice. At the end of the course, students should be able to understand, describe, and critically compare theories of categorization and concept representations. They should be able to understand, describe, and critically evaluate studies that test such theories.

column1: This course offers an introduction to the basic concepts and methods of law and economics. It illustrates the broad utility of these tools by way of applications to the analysis of various core areas of law. This course does not aim to develop practical skills or new insights, but rather to show the broad utility of economic analysis of law. By combining examples from various areas of law, students will learn that the economic approach to law provides a unified vision of the law, tying together diverse areas of the law into a common theoretical structure.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course takes a global perspective in exploring the theoretical social context of cultural policy with examples from European cultural strategy, though policy in the United States and other parts of the world are also examined. Classes are grounded in sociological theory and knowledge will be extended and enhanced through empirical research.  Emphasis is on the various dilemmas facing those who create, study, and work with cultural policy. Topics covered include how culture is defined, what is considered legitimate and consequently worthy of state support; art’s growing position in the marketplace; how globalization may affect local and national culture; the organizational needs of managers versus the creative needs of artists; how consumption practices influence policy and policy’s effect on cultural participation and education. We end the course considering how cultural policy has shifted to match changing cultural and social values.

The course is for advanced students interested in academic or applied careers in arts, culture, and public policy. In exploring various forms of culture and cultural research, the course cuts across disciplines, including economics, humanities, and social-psychology, though is grounded primarily in sociological theory and methodology. This course is a seminar and, consequently, the class work is a combination of lecture, discussion, class exercises and student presentation. Students will contribute to the content of the course through discussion and presentation of case studies that serve as exemplars. In this way, the class is research intensive, relying on student interests to direct the exploration of the course's main themes. The class is conducted entirely in English and students are required to discuss and report in every class.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Students will learn to distinguish the main policy concerns debated by academics and those involved in cultural policy creation and research. Students will be able to address these concerns through a foundation of cultural and organizational sociological theory and empirical research. Finally, students will be able to link concepts considered in class to the broader social context and current courses of action.</body>
