column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In today's world, war between states has become a rarity, whereas violent conflict within national boundaries is of growing concern. The causes and dynamics of civil wars, and other types of intra-state conflicts, require a different understanding than classical wars. Conflicts are increasingly complex, featuring multiple parties, transnational dynamics, and strategies to resolve them.

The course focuses on contemporary conflicts and is structured around three parts: (I) how conflicts arise, (II) how they can be managed, and (III) how they can be transformed and resolved. Borrowing from fields such as International Relations, Political Science, Sociology, Psychology, history, anthropology, Law, this course has a distinctly interdisciplinary outlook.

A variety of violent conflicts are featured ranging from ethnic, electoral, ethnic, resource-based and secessionist. By adopting a case study-approach, we will attempt to understand the causes of conflict as well as techniques and interventions developed to end and resolve them such as peacekeeping, mediation, and transitional justice. Finally, you will gain tools to understand and analyse conflict, and gain practical experience in negotiating a resolution to a conflict by means of a simulation game.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • have basic knowledge of various types of conflict in the contemporary world;
• be familiar with different conflict models and able to apply these models, concepts and theories to a range of conflicts;
• have acquired an understanding of the main methods and tools used in conflict resolution;
• have acquired basic skills in conflict analysis, problem-solving and negotiation

column1: <body>This course explores sustainability complexities, transitions, frameworks, and action research. It emphasizes hands-on engagement, group work, impactful communication, and practical examples. Students gain insights into sustainability science, planetary boundaries, nature-positive economy, doughnut economy, and sustainable development goals. They learn about actors, processes, and dynamics shaping sustainable systems. Action research is emphasized, highlighting the role of science, policy, and society in sustainability action and transition governance. Work sessions employ tools like the X-curve framework and serious games. Excursions provide real-life sustainability examples. Collaboration is fostered through group assignments. Individual reflections encourage critical thinking. The course prepares students to address sustainability challenges and contribute to solutions.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column3: • the complexity of (un)sustainability and the basics of transitions.
• Sustainability science and the several key normative frameworks originating from it.
• Action-research and the role it envisions for science-policy-society.
• The role of governance and how it can accelerate societal transitions.

column2: <li>Students can engage with and critically reflect on:

column3: • (un)sustainability in real-life settings (i.e., excursions) and how proposed interventions contribute to transformative or incremental change.
• Gaining actionable insights for governance from transition thinking, sustainability frameworks, action-research.
• the complexity of (un)sustainability, societal transitions, and their designed interventions in an impactful and creative way.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113786,2023,Consultancy Project,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. BAS Koene'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The Consultancy project (or CP) constitutes and important part of the second half of the Master in Management program at Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University (RSM). Over a period of approximately 4 months, you will work intensively on a consultancy project in a team of approximately six students. Both a university and a company coach supervise the project.

The projects are proposed by managers from a variety of organizations. They refer to actual business needs managers are currently facing. Thus managers (=clients) expect useful and sustainable recommendations for an extant question or problem. The general aim of the project is to respond professionally to a real-world management problem, to learn from working together in multidisciplinary and multicultural teams and manage the project effectively (i.e. team and client processes), to define, scope, analyze and structure a complex problem, to apply and integrate business knowledge on a ‘real-world’ case and to develop useful recommendations.
This course is worth 6 EC and runs from blocks 3 through 5.

Lectures, seminars and coaching are offered throughout the project to help students with mastering skills that are relevant for project management and consultancy projects. During the course most time is spent on project work. Lectures, seminars and workshop meetings are kept to a minimum, but are important moments to learn about and professionally reflect on key consulting skills and your experiences in the projects. Therefore, attendance to all meetings is MANDATORY for successful completion of the consultancy project, as well as toward your final grade for the module

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Analytical skills: Dealing with a high amount of information in a short time in an (formerly) unknown domain and gain/maintain an overview
• Analytical skills: Being able to define, scope, analyse and structure an (formerly) unknown and ill-defined problem
• Problem-solving skills: Develop consistent, relevant and sustainable solutions for the client based on high professional standards and understand the managerial implications
• Managerial skills: Think independently and behave autonomously: working on problems – not following instructions
• Managerial skills: manage and satisfy the various requirements from stakeholders
• Managerial skills: Make use of the cross-cultural and disciplinary diversity in a team
• Leadership skills: experience and reflect on your impact on a team process and think about improvements

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112603,2023,Consultancy Project PT,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. SP Kaptein'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Veel organisaties lopen tegen vraagstukken aan die zij niet zelf kunnen oplossen. Vaak ontbeert het hen aan de kennis of expertise die nodig is. Op dergelijke momenten kunnen zij een consultant inhuren. Het kennisvoordeel van een consultant kan betrekking hebben op specialistische kennis van een industrie of vakgebied, een specifieke methode of opgebouwde ervaringen.

In dit consultancyproject, dat een belangrijk onderdeel vormt van het pMiM-programma, gaan studenten in groepen van vier studenten intensief aan de slag om een bestaand probleem voor één private of (semi-) publieke organisatie op te lossen. Net als in het echt, komt deze “opdracht” uit het netwerk van de consultant. Dat kan de organisatie zijn waar een van de studenten werkzaam is (met als voordeel dat deze organisatie extra rendement krijgt op hun medewerker die het pMiM-programma doorloopt) maar dat is niet noodzakelijk (al is het wel aanbevelenswaardig om een organisatie te vinden waar men contacten heeft zodat men vlot kan starten). Het is echter uitgesloten dat men een adviesopdracht doet voor zichzelf (want dan is men klant en consultant tegelijkertijd). Samen met de klant (opdrachtgever) wordt er gekeken naar een vraagstuk waar de consultants mee aan de slag gaan.

Dit vraagstuk dient te liggen op het gebied van een of meerdere van de VN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Zo slaan we meerdere vliegen in één klap. We helpen de organisatie en de samenleving. Niet voor niets wil RSM organisaties stimuleren tot een “force for positive change”. Alle teams werken dan ook vanuit het gezamenlijke adviesbureau “SDG Consultancy”, waarbij studenten de adviesteams vormen en de docent de adviespartner.

Het algemeen doel van het consultancyproject is om op een professionele wijze, met hulp van wetenschappelijke inzichten, een echt, weerbarstig probleem voor een organisatie op te lossen, om te leren samen te werken in multidisciplinaire en/of multiculturele teams, een probleem goed te definiëren, te structuren en af te bakenen en om een consultancyproces van begin tot eind te doorlopen zodat tot handzame aanbevelingen voor de organisatie van de opdrachtgever wordt gekomen. De implementatie van de aanbevelingen hoort niet tot de scope van dit project.
Dit vak bestaat uit 6 EC en loopt in blok 4 en 5, jaar 1

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Na afronding van het vak is de student tot het volgende in staat:

column2: • Omgaan met grote hoeveelheid informatie in een korte tijd, op een onbekend terrein en in een onbekende setting en hierin het overzicht te krijgen en bewaren.
• Identificeren, analyseren, vaststellen en structureren van een onbekend probleem.
• Ontwikkelen van een relevante en bestendige oplossing voor de klant gebaseerd op professionele standaarden en het begrijpen van de managementimplicaties van die oplossing.
• Oplossen van een probleem, in plaats van het opvolgen van instructies, door onafhankelijk denken en autonoom handelen.
• Managen van en tegemoetkomen aan de verschillende behoeften en verwachtingen van belanghebbenden.
• Gebruikmaken van de culturele en disciplinaire diversiteit in een team.
• Reflecteren op de eigen impact op het teamproces.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The Consulting Challenge is an opportunity to apply research and evidence-based knowledge to business problems. In this course, student teams will be aligned with a specific business organization confronting a management communication challenge. The challenge could cover a broad spectrum of corporate communication issues including, but not limited to, (re)branding, customer segmentation, corporate responsibility, stakeholder engagement, reputation management, and social media strategy. Using insights from theory and research, and supported by academic and industry mentors, student teams will assume the role of consultants and deliver a set of strategic recommendations to the business.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students have gained knowledge and an understanding of:
- The intersections of (communication) theory and practice in solving business challenges.
- The processes involved in executing a consulting project.
- The role and function of a communication consultant and/or strategic advisor to a business.
- Develop research and evidence-based insights for business problems.
- Implement diverse methods of collecting and analyzing research data
- Establish and maintain a professional relationship with a business.
- Effectively engage in group work to conceptualize and execute a consulting project.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Consumers are confronted in their daily lives with numerous marketing actions. Companies and manufacturers use media to persuade consumers to buy their products or to use their services. To understand the idea behind these communication messages you will learn in this course different concepts and theories from the behavioral sciences. For example you will learn how consumers make decisions and how they learn and remember information. You will also learn how consumers are persuaded or motivated. Moreover you will learn how consumers form attitudes about products and you will get insight into how all these theories and concepts are used by companies in their media communication and marketing strategies.

column2: • This course is not accessible for students who have already completed the CM2062, CM2072 or CM2272 course.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The purpose of this course is to introduce you to the study of consumer behavior. We will examine many concepts and theories from the behavioral sciences and analyze their usefulness for developing marketing strategies. The goal is to teach you these key concepts and to develop your ability to apply them in analyzing marketing situations and developing appropriate marketing strategies.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115094,2023,Consumer Behavior and Brand Loyalty,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. K Riskos'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: If a company wants to build brand loyalty, it needs to first understand its consumers. In this course we examine the connection between understanding consumer behavior and the steps to build brand loyalty.

This course is project- and practice-oriented as we apply theory to a specific company through case study. Thus, analyze the company’s consumer behavior and brand loyalty tactics and they study the process of building brand loyalty through consumer brand engagement  in physical and online servicescapes. On that basis, students develop a new service for the company that can enhance consumer brand experience and thus lead to increased brand loyalty.

The course is meant to provide prominent theories on consumer behavior from a marketing perspective. Students will get a better understanding of various marketing concepts like consumer psychology and perception, consumer engagement and experience, brand value, brand loyalty and brand equity.  They also examine how these concepts can be effectively used by companies in order to increase profits. The course will stimulate creativity and innovation as students go through a process of analysis and idea development. Also, the students will improve their debating skills as they discuss their proposals and ideas within the context of group presentations.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students will have knowledge and understanding of:
- Consumer psychology, needs, motivations and learning process;
- Consumer Brand Engagement and Experience;
- Brand Value, Brand Loyalty, and Brand Equity;
- Developing new service ideas to strengthen consumer brand satisfaction and loyalty;
- Applying theory in practice by analysing specific companies.
Develop their analytical and creative competencies, both individually (through individual assignments) and in teams (during seminar debates, reports and presentations);
Advance their understanding of consumers’ behavior, and how companies interact with consumers create positive brand experience and increase consumer brand engagement;
Improve the insights into branding and strategies for building brand and brand equity;
Practice their debating skills, opinion expression, argument defense, presentation, and pitch abilities.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115108,2023,Consumer Behavior and Brand Loyalty,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. K Riskos'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: If a company wants to build brand loyalty, it needs to first understand its customer. In this course we examine the connection between understanding a company’s target market and creating brand loyalty.

This course is project- and practice-oriented as we apply theory to a problem situation in a company. Thus, students work on specific companies; they analyse the companies’ brand, target market and brand loyalty strategies and they study how they engage with consumers in physical and online servicescapes. On that basis, students develop a new service for the company that can enhance customer experiences and thus lead to increased brand loyalty.

The course is meant to provide prominent theories on consumer behaviour from a marketing perspective. Students will get a better understanding of various marketing processes within a company as they study how they engage with consumers. They also examine, based on scientific literature, the various aspects of branding and the confluence of factors leading to brand loyalty. The course will stimulate creativity and innovation as students go through a process of analysis and idea development. Also, the students will improve their debating skills as they discuss their proposals and ideas within the context of group presentations.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students will have knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Developing new service ideas to strengthen consumer satisfaction and loyalty;
• Applying theory in practice by analysing specific companies.
• Develop their analytical and creative competencies, both individually (through individual assignments) and in teams (during seminar debates, reports and presentations);
• Advance their understanding of consumers’ motivations and behaviour, and how companies interact with consumers in online and offline servicescapes;
• Improve the insights into branding and strategies for building brand loyalty through enhancing customer experiences;
• Practice their debating skills, opinion expression, argument defense, presentation, and pitch abilities.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113738,2023,Consumer Behaviour,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. DR Schley'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The purpose of this course is to introduce students in the MSc Marketing Management program to the field of consumer behavior. The course is designed from the perspective of understanding the behavior of consumers, drawing from psychology, but also from sociology, anthropology and economics. It is geared toward future managers who will need to make decisions regarding consumer marketing programs.
My hope is that this course will:

column2: Provide you with theories, models, and other tools to better understand the “why” behind consumer behavior.
Provide you with general ideas about how to influence consumers, and about how you as a consumer are influenced by others (including marketers).
Prepare you to write a master thesis on the topic of consumer behavior.

column1: Understanding consumer behavior is a key requirement for effective marketing strategy and is vital to business success in today’s economy. The ideas from the course are relevant for all types of organizations (large, small, public, or private). This course is based upon the idea that consumers are much more than sales figures and that an integrated approach to understanding consumer behavior is critical to get the most from your marketing efforts. There is a fair amount of work in the course because I believe that the assigned work will help you to better understand and integrate the material in the course. Please note however, that it is not my intention to give out work for the sake of work. I will do my best to stimulate, guide, and facilitate your learning. But keep in mind that at this point in your education, what you get out of a course depends on what you put into it.
To understand the material, you must attend class. It will be very difficult to be successful in the course without regular attendance. Please be punctual.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Provide you with a foundation in the theories, models, and other tools used by academic and industry marketers for understanding the determinants of consumer behavior
• Demonstrate the ability to use marketing tools to influence consumers' attitudes and decisions
• Demonstrate the ability to work collaboratively on a complex task

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112131,2023,Consumer Behaviour,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. AT Barendregt'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course uses a multi-dimension perspective to explain and apply the consumers’ behavioural elements. Ultimately therefore, the benefit of this course is that students (future marketeers) will be able to identify and analyse how consumer behaviour works in practice, offering students the tools to apply this knowledge to their own future marketing practice.

This course starts with the historical context of consumption, it assesses how this process works for individual consumers and it identifies and discusses the consumers’ decision-making processes, very much touching several behavioural study areas in psychology as well.

For marketeers, it is critically important to appraise how both current and future buyers respond to the products and services that are offered to them and to use this insight to successfully offer products and services to buyers and consumers. We will assess the past, current and future trends in consumer behaviour.

Obviously, it is necessary that marketeers learn how to study the behaviour of their (potential) buyers before they can apply their findings and insights to help optimize the design of their products and services and thus generate the necessary profit for their firms.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To evaluate past, current and future trends as well as consumer behaviour developments.
• To identify how behavioural insight thinking impacts on consumer behaviour.
• To identify the decision-making process stages of consumer shopping behaviour.
• To explain how behavioural, cognitive and social learning impacts on consumer behaviour.
• To explain the perceptual process, from exposure to stimuli to consumer response.
• To assess what attitude theory is and how this theory is used in consumer marketing.
• To analyse how personality, self and psychographics explain the consumer’s behaviour.
• To explain the role of group influence mechanisms on consumer behaviour.
• To appraise how buyer behaviour relates to segments, differentiation and distinctiveness.
• To assess and compare individual (age/knowledge/income) and external (socio-cultural /geographic/demographic/technological) factors that influence consumer behaviour.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This course module has been updated during 2023 to meet the latest developments regarding online consumer behaviour, online marketing as well as neuromarketing.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>There are no extra costs for the course materials. However, the group assignment makes it necessary for students to travel to various parts of Rotterdam or The Hague. Consequently, the students will have to have at least a public transport subscription.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114837,2023,Consumer Culture,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. MJ Berghman', 'dr. SJ Opree']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The goal of this course is to provide students with a proper understanding of consumption from the academic perspectives of the homo economicus, homo sociologicus, and homo aestheticus. Using this multi-disciplinary perspective, consumption will be addressed as a socially embedded practice where aspects of freedom and individual choice are to be considered in the light of the opportunities for consumption offered by a socio-historically specific context. This implies that students develop an understanding of the causes and consequences of consumption (both material and cultural) at both the micro-level (e.g., identity, routines, meaning-making) and the macro-level (e.g., sustainability, politics, citizenship). Having been offered a solid theoretical foundation on consumption, students will apply theoretical insights to actual consumption practices by conducting interviews on informants’ consumption practices. In addition, they will keep and present a one-week diary of their consumption and explore to what extent the theories offered apply to themselves, explicitly linking micro- and macro-levels of analysis so as to grasp the complex links between consumer behaviour on the one hand and its causes and consequences at the level of society.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The main theories and concepts, including a critical appraisal of their historical emergence, regarding consumption and consumer culture
• The consumer research traditions within economics and the social sciences
• Apply theoretical concepts regarding consumption and consumer culture to empirical observations / their own lives
• Report and reflect on their findings in oral and written form

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113739,2023,Consumer Marketing Research,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. R Cadario'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course, students will familiarize themselves with the main marketing research approaches for understanding consumer behavior. Students will acquire knowledge on: (1) how to accurately measure and analyze consumers’ preferences, attitudes and choices, and (2) how marketing variables (such as product benefits, assortments, advertisements and retail environments) affect consumer behavior. The course introduces the main methods for analyzing consumer behavior (e.g. structured and unstructured observations, experiments and survey research), and focuses on the design and analysis of experiments and surveys.
Attendance to lectures or workshop is not compulsory, but highly recommended. There will be no make-up courses in case you cannot attend a course.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115107,2023,Consumer Perceptions of Corporate Social Responsibility,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. A van Prooijen', 'dr. Y Wang']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

A growing number of companies have started to recognize the value of sustainable business practices, and have adopted a pro-active search for opportunities to improve their societal and environmental impacts. These socially responsible practices can lead to a range of shared benefits for the company and for society. Despite these mutual benefits, it can be challenging for companies to promote their CSR activities. On the one hand, it is important for companies to communicate about their CSR performance in order to acquire potential reputational benefits. Moreover, consumers increasingly demand transparency from companies about their business conduct. On the other hand, consumers do not always respond positively to CSR information of companies. Consumers can be sceptical about the credibility of corporate claims about their involvement in CSR. Thus, even though companies might have sincere motives for their sustainability initiatives, the promotion of these initiatives can backfire due to suspicions of corporate greenwashing. Topics that are discussed in this course include the drivers of consumers’ preference for socially responsible companies, how CSR communication is evaluated by consumers, perceptions of sincerity of corporate motives to invest in CSR, and the role of new media in CSR communication.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students will gain knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Theoretical approaches, concepts and perspectives in the field of Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) communication;
• Consumer attitudes, motives and intentions regarding CSR.
• Systematically analyse and critically reflect on theoretical and practical issues in CSR communication;
• Apply theoretical knowledge to and construct arguments about CSR-related communication strategies and issues.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116817,2023,Consumer Psychology and Emerging Technologies,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. SP Mariadassou'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: New technologies have revolutionized the ways in which consumers exchange information, evaluate options, and make choices. In this course, we will discuss the fundamental principles of psychology surrounding decision processes and examine how technological advancements and emerging AI mediate consumer interactions. For example, we will consider how algorithms are used in the domains of finance, healthcare, and social media, and we will examine the conditions under which consumers are receptive to such algorithms. We will discuss the degree to which consumers rely on recommendation systems in their decision-making, and we will discuss the psychology associated with personalized recommendations and targeted ads. The goal of this course is to give you an understanding of how fundamental principles in consumer psychology can be applied to existing and emerging technologies. The course will require you to read papers in academic journals (some old and some new), submit written assignments, and present your ideas to the class. These assignments are intended to improve your research and communication skills.
Attendance is not mandatory but is strongly recommended. Much of the course will be discussion-based, and your participation will affect your final grade.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand and explain the importance and meaning of customer-centric marketing for today’s businesses;
• Possess a good expertise and think critically about companies’ practices in the domain of customer centricity;
• Understand and explain the latest research in the area of customer centricity;
• Understand and explain the general intuition behind the methods companies have at their disposal to develop a customer-centric marketing strategy;
• Provide and justify concrete managerial recommendations to non-technical audiences through (online) presentation and (digital) reporting.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114621,2023,Consumption and Identity,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. LE Braden'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In modern society, identity is increasingly shaped and defined by what we buy, brands we wear, products we use, and consumer loyalties we claim. Perhaps as a consequence, in the past several decades consumer studies have grown in importance for sociological research. Accordingly, this course examines the connection between consumption and identity.  We begin by exploring contemporary theories of consumption, including ideas on rationalization and taste distinctions.  We then turn to consumption’s role in mediating the modern tension between establishing individual identity and community membership. We next address the possible dangers of using commodities of the culture industry to help shape our societies and ourselves. To what degree does the culture industry determine consumption practices and understandings? To address this question, we first examine the other side of consumption, supply, and how cultural producers and gatekeepers determine what products to offer. Once consumers attain these products, are they active or passive—i.e., how do they use, change, or reject commercial goods? Finally, we end the course by examining consumption’s role in social mobilization, including protest, to effect change.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students will be able to identify the major issues within consumption studies and address those issues through a foundation of sociological theory and empirical research. Students will also be able to link concepts considered in class and the literature to the broader social context and their own social realities and consumption practices.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114646,2023,Contemporary Aesthetics,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. TJ Hoebink'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: For a few decades already we are witnessing a convergence between certain philosophical theories of art and certain sociological theories of art. Think, for example, of the Institutional Theory of Art, which has its roots in the aesthetic theory of Arthur C. Danto and others and has evolved into Howard Becker’s sociological analysis of “art worlds”. Or think of how increasingly more contemporary artists and aesthetic theorists recognize the interactive and participatory nature of artistic practices. Doing so, authors such as Bishop and Bourriaud add a new chapter to the relational turn in aesthetics and the sociology of culture and aim to go beyond the postmodern proclamation of the “end of art” by recognizing the sociological, rather than philosophical, nature of contemporary (visual) art, literature and popular culture. In this course, you will familiarize yourself with the works of authors as varied as Becker, Bishop, Bourdieu, Bourriaud, Danto, and Rancière, as well as with theories (and criticisms) on relational aesthetics and the participatory turn in contemporary art. By studying the convergence between the philosophy of art and the sociology of culture, you will be encouraged to take a helicopter perspective on your field of study and to develop a better understanding of what is meant with the rather ambiguous label of “contemporary art”.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The aim of this course is to develop students’ understanding of the interrelations between the disciplines of aesthetics and the sociology of culture. After completing this course, students will be acquainted with various (contemporary) philosophical and sociological theories (and criticisms) on recent developments within contemporary art. Moreover, they will learn the skills to apply the theoretical knowledge of the course to empirical research on contemporary artistic practices.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114609,2023,Contemporary Approaches in Cultural Sociology,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. LE Braden', 'dr. MJ Berghman', 'I Vitola', 'MF Rodriguez Rodriguez']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In recent decades, cultural sociology has been one of the fastest growing areas of sociological study. Some have even argued that contemporary sociology has been witnessing a ‘cultural turn’ – making culture (‘meaning-making’) a central aspect of sociological inquiry in many different areas such as politics, economy, the state, etc. This course addresses major themes and theories in cultural sociology by discerning three ideal typical approaches:

column2: • culture as cognitive structure approach, which studies the way in which cultural codes, schemas, narratives and texts constrain and enable the possible range and arrangement of meanings;
• culture in action approach, which focuses on the practical ways in which culture is reflexively used and set to work to solve everyday problems;
• production of culture approach, which focuses on how the content of culture (in the more restricted sense) is affected by its production, distribution and consumption.

column1: We will study exemplary works from all three contemporary approaches in cultural sociology, and, furthermore, focus on work that integrates key ideas from these different approaches into the study of making meaning in various cultural genres such as music, literature, fashion and sports. Finally, we will zoom in on how gender, race/ethnicity and nationality affect meaning-making, and how each of the three abovementioned approaches has studied such questions differently.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>In this course students will develop and expand their knowledge of the sociological perspective on the arts and culture in the broad sense. They will be able to distinguish three contemporary theoretical approaches in cultural sociology (culture as cognitive structure, culture in action and production of culture) and identify these approaches in recent sociological research.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course aims to introduce students to the leading concepts and current research discussions in Organizational Behavior (OB) and Human Resource Management (HRM) fields of studies with a particular focus on those that are shaped by and relevant to the contemporary societal changes, developments, and global challenges.
The course is structured as a five-week course, where each week is dedicated to a discussion on one of the following society-relevant topics and how OB and HRM research addresses them:

column2: • Meaning and Purpose – current research considering the importance of individual and organizational purpose, responsible organizational policies and practices and their impact on individuals in organizations;
• Careers and employability – employees’ contemporary career attitudes and behaviors, sustainable careers; career mobility and employability.
• Diverse and Inclusive HRM – multifaceted understanding of how HRM addressed diversity (e.g., age, gender, ethnicity, etc.) and stimulates inclusion in organizations.
• New Ways of Working – individuals proactively crafting their work, where, and how they do it, working in teams and ‘new normal’ conditions.
• Leaders for Sustainable Future – developing moral, ethical, and responsible leaders.

B Sahin', 'dr. CH Biekart', 'dr. JD Handmaker', 'dr. S Heumann', 'dr. S Mullassery Sathiamma', 'dr. SMS Jayasundara - Smits', 'mr.dr. DJE Misiedjan', 'prof.dr. RA Icaza Garza']",,

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Ever since the advent of the 20th century, political philosophers have felt the need to philosophically legitimise the notion of a ‘liberal representative democracy’. In response, to both abstract thought and material history, many thinkers have tried to criticise liberal democracy’s basic premises; and conceptually restructure thinking about politics at large. This process is still going on, as can be seen in the writings of many contemporary political thinkers. In this course we focus on several key debates – and bones of contention – on liberal democracies in contemporary political theory and political philosophy. Central concepts include: justice, popular sovereignty, legitimacy, deliberative democracy, antagonism, hegemony and populism. These concepts will be discussed in reference to thinkers as diverse as Carl Schmitt, John Rawls, Jürgen Habermas, and Bonnie Honig.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course focuses on key technological thought in the continental tradition, either on a particular thinker or approach. This year's Contemporary Though of Technology will focus on the work of Gilbert Simondon, who introduces a new approach to the study of technical objects. His On the Mode of Existence of Technical Objects (1958) is one of the most important philosophical texts on technology.

We will study Simondon's technological thought and its relation to thinkers such as Martin Heidegger, Norbert Wiener, Georges Canguilhem and Bernard Stiegler. This course will also revisit some of the critical technological events in the 20th century and elaborate on their philosophical importance: the emergence of an interdisciplinary approach called Cybernetics proposed by Norbert Wiener and its continuation in the research of Artificial Intelligence since the 1956 Dartmouth Conference, and later the invention of the Internet and its proliferation, which led to today's human conditions. We are living among many digital machines. How do we understand them? Are they mere functionalities? What kind of value do they have? How can we elaborate on the relation between humans, machines and the world? This course will address these questions by thinking with Simondon and recontextualising his thoughts against today's technological development. Students will be asked to write a final essay after the course to address a key concept or a key question related to this course.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: ·        Will comprehend the question concerning technology in the tradition of continental philosophy.
·        Can read and comment upon core philosophical texts on technology.
·        Can apply the concepts developed in this course to reflect on contemporary crises in ecology and technology.
·        Can critically engage with the current debates on the becoming of humans and machines.

column1: This course is an introduction to asset pricing theory in continuous time. The first part of the course focuses on the methods and tools which are essential to understand and work with continuous-time asset pricing models. Students will learn about the most important concepts of stochastic calculus including, inter alia, Itô’s calculus, martingales, measures and stochastic optimal control. The second part of the course will give an overview of important asset pricing models including, e.g., the Lucas economy, models with incomplete information, and intermediary asset pricing.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: By the end of the course, Students will be able to
1. Apply the tools of stochastic calculus in the context of continuous-time asset pricing, i.e., to solve optimal consumption and investment problems and to derive asset pricing equilibria
2. Analyze the solution of continuous-time asset pricing models by assessing the connection between the model features and economic implications
3. Compare the outcomes of different models and reflect on their potential drawbacks

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The role of the financial controller is changing in ways that mirror those of the broader finance function. Rather than serving as a rear-view mirror that only provides information about historical performance, the financial controller increasingly participate in the analysis and formulation of solutions to higher value-added, strategic issues. Reliance on forward-looking techniques tools allows the finance function to anticipate the future needs of the company to drive appropriate action, improve the current operating results and eventually maximize the bottom line.

The dynamic and integrative role of the controller function in business corporations is the focus of this course. Classes cover the principles underlying planning and control decisions in functional and divisional organizations, as well the design and consequences of responsibility accounting and performance measurement systems under various market conditions. The course also extends to financial controller’s roles in budgeting, strategic planning, pricing, risk management, corporate finance and investment related decision making.

The course is structured in lectures and tutorials. During the lecture part, the respective topics of each session are introduced and discussed. Overall, by linking together financial management techniques and analytical business skills, the course aims at preparing students to manage the entire spectrum of responsibilities expected by financial professionals.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand and explain the characteristics of management planning and control in functional and divisional organizations
• Understand and explain responsibility accounting and the role of efficiency and effectiveness in performance measurement
• Understand and explain controllers' roles in cost management, strategic planning, programming, and budgeting, pricing, corporate finance and investment related decision making
• Apply methods and techniques essential for working as a corporate Controller
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course aims to develop a basic understanding of economic behaviour. We will do so by examining the intuitions and the real-world underpinning of the ‘maths and the models’ of economics. The focus is on teaching economic tools and concepts by addressing relevant questions, such as the causes and consequences of the financial crisis or economic inequality. Topics that will be discussed include individual decision making (‘how do people divide their time between leisure and working?’), strategic decision making (‘how do people act in situations of strategic interdependence’), the financial world (‘how is money created?’), and how the economy can be described and measured, at an aggregate level.

The course is empirically motivated and illustrated. Based on facts from history, experiments and data, students will learn how economic insights and models can be used to understand the real world. The course will introduce you to key concepts in economic theory and economic reasoning on the basis of the curriculum developed by the core economics project.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After following this course, you will have an understanding of:

column2: • what the science of economics is about;
• the characteristics of the different recent economic epochs and their effect on the economy and the science of economics;
• choices people make given the opportunities available;
• the working and the limits of markets
• the elements of the aggregate economy and how government policies can affect these elements;
• the role banks play in the economy.

column1: This course provides an overview of the approaches, perspectives, and dimensions of corporate communication in an environment where branding and reputation are paramount. Students will learn about the functions, practices, challenges and opportunities of corporate communication in an international and social-mediated context.. Students will understand and critique the various roles that communication plays in the internal and external relations of organizations through a mix of case studies, course readings, and perspectives from the field.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112057,2023,Corporate Entrepreneurship,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. PA Distel'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In today’s dynamic, turbulent, and continuously changing economic business environment, entrepreneurship is an essential and indispensable element in the success of every business organization—whether small or large, new or long-established and mature. Corporate entrepreneurship (or intrapreneurship) refers to activities involved in creating and exploiting new resource combinations in the context of existing corporations. Yet, the ability to think and act entrepreneurially and engage in ongoing processes of creativity often fails because established organizations present hostile environments for entrepreneurial ideas. This core course focuses primarily on organizational and managerial efforts aimed at the identification, development and exploitation of technical and organizational entrepreneurial ideas, the management of new product or process developments, and on effective new venture management in the context of large corporations. Topics include ways how organizations can stimulate corporate entrepreneurship, entrepreneurial action, work contexts, exploration and exploitation, and organizational culture.
In-class attendance in every lecture session is highly encouraged (but not mandatory) for obtaining the best learning experience.

For the team presentation sessions, attendance of every team member is mandatory. Only if you have a valid reason such as unforeseeable circumstances (e.g., medical reasons), you are allowed to miss a team presentation session. Should such unforeseeable circumstances arise, please inform the course coordinator as soon as possible via email (distel@rsm.nl) – otherwise you can be excluded from the course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Explain how managers can overcome the obstacles to Corporate Entrepreneurship and explain how they can create work environments that facilitate innovation in established organizations
• Explain the complexity of Corporate Entrepreneurship and describe its different forms, contexts and levels
• Analyze strategic situations and design appropriate Corporate Entrepreneurship strategies
• Explain the leadership challenges and managerial capabilities of Corporate Entrepreneurship

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113669,2023,Corporate Finance,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. RJ Dottling, MSc', 'prof.dr. D Schoenmaker']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Corporate Finance deals with two broad and interrelated themes: how to value businesses and corporate investment opportunities; and how to finance corporate investment and activities.

The first part of the course covers company and investment valuation, starting with the objective of the firm. We then discuss the process of value creation for the various stakeholders of a company and the effect of transitions on value creation. Next, we analyse analytical investment appraisal methods. The net present value rule is expanded with social and environmental factors towards an integrated present value rule. Formal company valuation models are analyzed and expanded to an integrated valuation model. Students will do a group assignment on integrated valuation.

The second part of the course deals with financing and financial policy, starting with the trade-off theory of capital structure. We then cover agency conflicts and models of asymmetric information, and analyze how they affect firm value and optimal capital structure. A key goal is to formally analyze these issues using tractable analytical models. This formal analytical approach follows best practices in the academic corporate finance literature and is important to avoid pitfalls in intuitive reasoning.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Value a firm, project or investment proposal
• Describe and understand the various types of financial instruments used to finance firms, from an economic, financial, social, and environmental point of view
• Evaluate the effect of various financial policies on firm value, and suggest a suitable capital structure for a firm
• Critically evaluate the effects of agency and information problems on firms’ financial policies and capital structure using a formal model
• Understand the role of stakeholders in corporate decision-making vis-à-vis financial considerations

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113788,2023,Corporate Finance,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. D Metzger'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course provides an introduction to modern financial theories for students without a financial background. The themes we deal with in this course are particularly relevant for business decision-making in areas such as whether to invest in a project and how to deal with risks. We ultimately aim to build intuition in finance and as such, we will also analogize to other domains, such as personal finance. The course is both theoretical and applied.
Specifically, we will address the following questions:
•         How do managers evaluate investment decisions?
•         How do investors deal with returns and risks?
•         How should managers finance a firm’s investment?
Preparation, attendance, and active participation is expected.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Valuate assets with the net present value and other valuation methods
• Select amongst investment opportunities by comparing risk and return
• Formulate the implications of the efficient market hypothesis on the prices of equity
• Understand the implications of capital structure for risk and return
• Understand the concept of time value of money and be able to value a stream of cash flows

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115170,2023,Corporate Finance,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['CP Koning, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course is an extensive introduction to the basic tools, techniques and theories that are necessary to understand the financial decision-making in the modern corporation. The themes we deal with in this course are particularly relevant for business decision-making and will dive into questions such as: whether or not to invest in a project, how to finance an investment, and how to deal with uncertainty.

Corporate finance can be seen as supportive to other fields such as strategy or marketing; often in these fields the business decisions are formulated (e.g., in what markets or products should we invest), whereas in corporate finance we evaluate these choices and analyse how to fund them best.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Evaluate the financing decisions of companies using different theories relating to capital
Analyze the impact of leverage on a company's risk and return profile
Compare and contrast different capital structures in terms of their effects on cost of capital and financial risk
Calculate the value of a company that is financed with equity and debt based on an analysis of the relevant cash flows
Analyze the impact of dividend policy on the value of companies.
Describe the fundamental concepts of options, including the difference between call and put options.
Apply various option valuation methods, such as the Black-Scholes model, risk-neutral pricing and replicating portfolio.
Analyze the underlying mechanisms of short-term capital management
Calculate and interpret the most important metrics used in short-term financing
Be able to connect concepts of traditional Corporate Finance to Sustainable Finance.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Finance appears to be at the nexus of recent political developments, not least due to its effect on the recent financial crisis. Corporate finance is much more than a collection of equations, matrices and models. Corporate finance is a set of first principles that govern how we run businesses. This is an introductory finance course that addresses the key decisions and issues faced by senior financial officers in corporations and the analytical frameworks and approaches that are helpful in addressing these issues. This course is an extensive introduction to the basic tools, techniques and theories that are necessary to understand the financial decision-making in the modern corporation. At the end of this course you will be able to apply Corporate Finance to unstructured real-life problems, get the bigger picture before you press the button, and be able to make numerical exercises as well as understanding the theories/models behind them.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After successfully completing the course you will be able to:

column2: • explain the implications of the model of Hirshleifer and the separation theorem of Fisher;
• apply the net present value method and other investment selection criteria;
• determine the value of financial assets such as shares and bonds;
• combine individual financial assets into a portfolio of financial assets;
• explain the difference between profits and cash flows;
• explain the portfolio theory and the Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM);
• apply the CAPM to set a discount rate;
• explain the consequences of an efficient market for the investors in financial assets;
• explain the consequences of an efficient market for the investors in real assets;
• determine the net present value of a merger.

column1: The course Financial Management runs across two blocks. We start in block 2, where mainly topics related to accounting are discussed. Accounting is referred to as the language of business, because it is widely used to reflect all types of business activities. This course provides insights in core concepts in accounting. We discuss the various ways in which financial and non-financial information can be compiled, and how this information is communicated to decision makers. In general, we distinguish between financial accounting and management accounting.

Financial accounting deals with the primary financial statements – balance sheet, income statement and cash flow statement – and is designed primarily to assist external stakeholders, such as investors and creditors, in deciding where or whether to invest their money. What information financial statements present, how it is linked and how to interpret this information is discussed.

Management accounting emphasizes the use of accounting information for internal planning and control purposes. Any organization’s long-term competitive success is critically dependent on (1) the quality of accounting information about its products, services, processes, suppliers, and customers, (2) taking rational decisions based on accounting information, and (3) motivating its employees and controlling its performance consistent with that information. Important topics include cost accounting, cost-volume-profit analysis, budgeting, responsibility accounting, relevant costing and decision-making.

In block 3 topics in finance are discussed. Finance deals with topics that are particularly relevant for business decision-making in areas as whether or not to invest in a project, how to finance an investment, and how to deal with uncertainty. Finance is associated with decision-making related to external stakeholders.

This part of the course deals with the modern fundamentals of finance and describes how investment opportunities are valued in financial markets. The most important concepts in this course are the net present value, capital budgeting, the risk-return relationship, the efficient market hypothesis, and capital structure. We will use these concepts for addressing two central questions throughout this course:

column2: • How should a financial manager of a firm take investments decisions?

column1: This course is worth 6 EC and runs in block 2 and 3.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course the student should be able to:

column2: Understand the concept of time value of money and be able to value a stream of cash flows
Valuate assets by means of both the net present value and multiples
Select amongst investment opportunities by comparing risk and return, as well as by comparing any alternatives available
Relate investment decisions to capital budgeting and capital structure
Understand the implications of capital structure for cost of capital and firm value
Formulate the implications of the efficient market hypothesis on the prices of equity
Interpret and analyze a balance sheet and income statement;
Identify different cost types and relevant costs for specific business decisions;
Choose the economically optimal alternative course of action;
List the behavioral effects of performance evaluations based on financial indicators;
Understand the link between financial and management accounting.

column1: Instructor: Dr V.N. Vladimirov (UvA), Prof. Dr. S. Gryglewicz

This course covers core and new topics in Corporate Finance theory with an emphasis on introducing the microeconomic tools needed to address open research questions and discussing. Students are expected to be familiar with basic notions in finance and game theory. Some basic knowledge of contract theory is an advantage, but the course will be largely self-contained in this respect. The main focus of the lectures will be on financial contracting in the presence of agency problems, asymmetric information, and incomplete contracting. For each topic there will be some recommended and/or required literature to accompany the lectures. The textbooks closest to the material covered in class are Tirole ""The Theory of Corporate Finance"" and Bolton and Dewatripon ""Contract Theory."" However, some of the readings will be based on articles. A detailed list of reading assignments will be available at the start of each lecture.

2. an ability to operationalize research questions in corporate finance and to select and apply correctly advanced techniques and theoretical methodology

column1: Content: Corporate Governance is about ‘the rules of the game’ within which firms develop and exploit their resources and undertake business activities to create and appropriate value. These ‘rules of the game’ are shaped both at the country level (e.g. markets, laws, culture) and at the level of the firm (e.g. ownership, the board, alliances, etc.), at which level they are most flexible. At the firm level, these rules of the game include the ownership of the firm, its basic decision-making structures and practices, as well as the accountability structures and practices through which those who make and/or execute decisions can be held accountable by those bearing residual risk from those decisions. In publicly listed firms, for example, executives make the bulk of everyday decisions, while dispersed and therefore mostly uninvolved shareholders (as well as other stakeholders) bear the risks that result from them. This has traditionally made the question how dispersed, and uninvolved shareholders can secure maximal returns from the firm a central corporate governance challenge for publicly listed firms.

A striking fact about economic reality, however, is that there do not just exist publicly listed firms but many different forms of ownership, such as: founder owned start-ups, partnerships, cooperatives, family firms, state-owned firms, and non-profit organizations, for example, that each dominate specific industries, such as Fintech, accounting, agriculture, defense, higher education, and healthcare, for eaxmple. Firms with different types of ownership face their own distinctive corporate governance challenges and will therefore need to develop an equally distinctive set of corporate governance structures and practices to meet these challenges. As a result, there does not exist any single corporate governance model that is suitable for all firms.

Overarching aim of the course: Given that is there exists no single best solution to questions of corporate ownership and governance, the overarching aim of this course is to develop a strategic understanding of corporate ownership and governance. In this view, the ultimate aim of corporate ownership and governance is to align the firm’s ownership, decision-making, and accountability structures and practices, on the one hand, with its strategy, core activities, key resources, and critical resource dependencies, on the other, to unleash value creation and value appropriation for the firm and its owners and stakeholders.

To develop a strategic understanding of corporate ownership and governance, we will discuss various forms of ownership, such as publicly listed firms, (professional) partnerships, family firms, and founder owned start-ups, for example, in order to explore a variety of corporate governance structures and practices that can be implemented to meet these challenges. Because the ownership of the firm generally is the most foundational ‘governance choice’ to be made, we will often begin our analysis by discussing the costs and benefits of different forms of ownership and the specific governance challenges that arise from these. We will also discuss the corporate governance role of the firm’s stakeholders, however, and explore the governance strategies and practices that firms can develop and implement to secure stakeholders’ continued involvement in, or support for, the firm. Finally, we will explore how firms can secure their societal license to operate, because as institutions of private ordering, firms can only exist and function within an institutional context comprised of public ordering (e.g. the state, the law, society, etc).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: As the overarching aim of this course is to develop a strategic understanding of the ownership and governance of firms, the course seeks to develop a thorough understanding of the concepts and theories that can be used to strategically analyze questions of ownership and governance of firms, as well as the research (including methods) and available empirical evidence in support of these theories and conceptual frameworks. Because questions about the ownership and governance of firms cannot be resolved in any simple mathematical or deterministic way, the goal is not to know everything discussed in every reading or every lecture by heart. Instead, the main pedagogical aim of the course is to develop a basic but thorough understanding of the concepts, theoretical frameworks, and knowledge about their empirical support that is required to analyze questions of ownership and governance at a pre-experience MSc level of academic competence. And because the study of ownership and governance is nothing like rocket science, this course seeks to develop a critical attitude of students with respect to the concepts, theories, and research discussed, as well as some foundational practical skills in applying the learnings of this course. After successfully completing the course, therefore, students should master the following:

column2: • Identify and understand theoretical concepts and frameworks at the intersection of corporate strategy, ownership, and governance;
• Integrate theoretical insights, conceptual frameworks, and relevant empirical evidence that shape our understanding of the strategic ownership and governance choices of firms;
• Apply concepts, theoretical insights, and frameworks to real-life cases involving the development and implementation of a corporate ownership and governance strategy for firms;

• Collect, process, and analyze data required for critically evaluating a firms’ current ownership and governance practices in order to to develop the ownership and governance part of a firm’s overall corporate strategy;
• Analyze opportunities and challenges in developing strategic options for ownership and governance changes in firms;
• Develop a corporate ownership and governance strategy for a particular firm;

• Demonstrate an ability to work in teams on the (skills) assignments for this course, showcasing you mastering the knowledge, skills, and attitudes as they are relevant in developing a corporate ownership and governance strategy for a firm.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114036,2023,Corporate Governance and Corporate Litigation,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr. M de Mooij', 'mr.drs. KH Boonzaaijer', 'mr.drs. R Bierenbroodspot']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Het vak Corporate Governance en Corporate Litigation richt zich op de interne structuur van N.V.’s en B.V.’s, op de aansprakelijkheidspositie van functionarissen van N.V.’s en B.V.’s en op juridische procedures rondom vennootschappen. Tot de vragen en aspecten die aan de orde komen tijdens dit vak behoren de volgende.

column2: • Wat is corporate governance? Wat is corporate litigation?
• Is er een verschil tussen corporate governance en corporate litigation in besloten vennootschappelijke verhoudingen en open verhoudingen (beursvennootschappen)?
• Wat is het gevolg van toepasselijkheid van de structuurregeling op de interne verhoudingen?
• Wat is de invloed van concernvorming op de interne verhoudingen?
• Welke (juridische) regels beheersen de interne verhoudingen in vennootschappen?
• Welke rol spelen duurzaamheid en maatschappelijk verantwoord ondernemen binnen corporate governance en corporate litigation?
• Wat is de invloed van digitale transformatie op corporate governance?
• Wat zijn de taken en bevoegdheden van het bestuur? Wat is het belang van bestuursautonomie? Hoe wordt bestuursautonomie beschermd? Wanneer is sprake van onbehoorlijk bestuur; wanneer van wanbeleid?
• Wat zijn de verschillen en overeenkomsten tussen een dualistisch bestuursmodel (two tier board) en een monistisch bestuursmodel (one tier board)?
• Hoe functioneert de raad van commissarissen? Wat is het belang van onafhankelijkheid van commissarissen?
• Hoe functioneert de algemene vergadering? Zijn er verschillen tussen een vennootschap met een verspreid aandelenbezit of met een beperkt aantal (groot)aandeelhouders?
• Welke rechten en plichten hebben aandeelhouders? Hoe is de bescherming van minderheidsaandeelhouders geregeld? Hoe kunnen zij hun positie in een juridische procedure beschermen?
• Hoe kunnen vennootschappen zich beschermen tegen activistische aandeelhouders?
• Op welke wijze komen de hiervoor vermelde vragen aan de orde in juridische procedures op het terrein van het ondernemingsrecht?
• Wat zijn de vennootschapsrechtelijke en procesrechtelijke aspecten die verband houden met geschillen binnen/rond ondernemingen?

• Waar en hoe zijn de enquêteprocedure, de geschillenregelingprocedure, de uitkoopprocedure, relevante aansprakelijkheidsprocedures en de procedure voor aantasting van besluiten van de vennootschap geregeld?
• Het vak besteedt daar waar nuttig/mogelijk aandacht aan rechtsvergelijkende aspecten.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Na voltooiing van dit vak kunnen studenten:

column2: • de onderwerpen die behoren tot corporate governance benoemen, beoordelen of in een concreet geval sprake is van goede corporate governance en daarbij de eigen kenmerken van open en besloten verhoudingen betrekken;
• de interne verhoudingen en de verantwoordelijkheid en aansprakelijkheid van verschillende actoren in kapitaalvennootschappen beschrijven en casusposities hierover oplossen;
• Europese en internationale perspectieven betrekken bij onderwerpen die behoren tot corporate governance en corporate litigation;
• economische, historische en psychologische aspecten en inzichten betrekken bij onderwerpen die behoren tot corporate governance en corporate litigation;

• de verschillende ondernemingsrechtelijke procedures onderscheiden, hun toepassingsgebied benoemen, voor een bepaald geschil de meest geschikte procedurele rechtsgang kiezen en regels van bewijsrecht benoemen voor deze procedures;
• nationale en internationale wetenschappelijke teksten over onderwerpen die behoren tot corporate governance en corporate litigation analyseren, beoordelen en daarop kritisch reflecteren;

• in samenwerking met medestudenten analyseren, aan de hand van toepasselijke wettelijke, statutaire en contractuele regels en regels die voortvloeien uit corporate governance codes, wat de interne structuur van een concrete vennootschap is en welke sterke en zwakke punten aan die interne structuur zijn verbonden uit het oogpunt van een goede corporate governance.

column1: Economic efficiency may be undermined by misallocation of financial resources. This course discusses corporate law and financial regulation from the perspective of the correction of financial markets failure. The course focuses on the various legal, contractual and extra-legal mechanisms available to protect (minority) shareholders and other stakeholders from the self-serving behavior of managers and of controlling shareholders. Moreover, the course addresses the problem of financial distress and its consequences for the financing of private and public enterprises, as well as for financial stability.
This course is open for EMLE students only.
