column1: Corporate Innovation and Venture Capital: Corporate entrepreneurship refers to the spawning of or pioneering of new businesses within established firms building on their strengths -- an increasingly important process in the organization of corporate research and management of innovation -- and distinct from the study of entrepreneurship (or the founding of new firms).

This course will explore changes in managing innovation in large established companies and emerging models of corporate entrepreneurship. The course will study formal theories of intrapraneurship that have emerged in the last decade and explore the phenomenon through case studies of particular firms, case studies of particular inventions, and also industry studies of how corporate entrepreneurship (and its failure) determine industry dynamics. We will also cover empirical studies of the tradeoff between entrepreneurship and intrapraneurship.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To describe and explain several theories of corporate entrepreneurship.
• To develop a framework for studying alternative forms of corporate entrepreneurship.
• To examine critically the challenges for large established firms in organizing and managing corporate entrepreneurship programs research in an established firm.
• To propose ways for public policy to facilitate corporate entrepreneurship programs.
• To analyze and calculate the conditions under which entrepreneurs prefer corporate entrepreneurship relative to pure entrepreneurship.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114782,2023,Corporate Management with Social Media,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. E Londo'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Although new and social media are ubiquitous in our personal lives, organizations are still grappling with their complex and multi-dimensional implications in the way they conduct business and engage with stakeholders. Just as social media afford organizations new possibilities to communicate, they also leave them more vulnerable to new reputation risks in the form of online pranks, hoaxes, and rumors.  Too,  organizational  experiences  with  social  media  vary  dramatically  along  the  leader- laggard spectrum. Well-known examples include KLM s ‘trial by ash cloud’ that launched the airline into the social space with no looking back. At IBM, social is central to product innovation, creating  new ways of collaboration, and business process transformation.

Certainly, social media have changed the way managers operate and shape their work culture. There is a belief that being more accessible and transparent through social media will enhance not just business practices but will gain trust, consumer and employee loyalty, and possibly even yield higher market share. Yet, there are major ethical, interpersonal, organizational, and political challenges of applying social media in organizational communication contexts. This course will examine the ways   in which new and social media influence, alter, and challenge communication management and reflect on the theoretical and pragmatic implications of these developments.

The course surveys academic and industry scholarship to provide diverse disciplinary and applied perspectives on the impact of new media on the business landscape, with specific attention to their communicative dimensions. Indicative topics include social media and public relations,

managing (online) corporate reputation and crisis communication, employee engagement, corporate social responsibility, and digital activism. We will also invite guest speakers to offer insight into industry practices and ongoing research relevant to the course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: - How new and social media influence, alter, and challenge corporate communication and strategic management functions (e.g. stakeholder relations, brand identity, crisis communication, reputation management).
- The strategic uses and implications of social media for internal and external organizational communication and across contexts (e.g., B2C, B2B).
- The opportunities, peculiarities, and strengths of different social media platforms for corporate communication.
- Critically review the use of social media in strategic communication, marketing, branding, and public relations.
- Individually and in groups, apply research-based knowledge to practical cases.
- Present their evidence-based analyses, arguments, and recommendations in a coherent and impactful manner.

column1: The course focuses on understanding complex financial reporting issues such as business combinations, consolidation, foreign currencies, joint arrangements, hedge accounting and financial instruments. In addition, recent developments in corporate reporting are discussed including reporting on sustainability.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the IFRS topics business combinations, consolidation, foreign currencies, joint arrangements and financial instruments.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the international dimension of financial accounting and the role of the IASB.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the incentives management face in applying IFRS and why accounting regulation is important.
• Students are able to: prepare and understand the parts of the annual report that relate to business combinations, consolidation, foreign currencies, joint arrangements and financial instruments.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the recent developments regarding sustainability reporting.

column1: Companies are increasingly pressured by stakeholders to not only pursue financial corporate goals, but to also take responsibility for how business operations impact society and the environment. Corporate social responsibility (CSR) addresses the question what the role of business in society is, and it encompasses a wide range of organizational activities. A strong CSR performance can represent a key reputational asset for organizations of all types. At the same time, the societal norms to which companies are expected to adhere to are continuously evolving, and stakeholder demands do not always align. Thus, it can be a major challenge for companies to strategically engage in CSR, which also impacts the communication about these efforts to stakeholders.

The media regularly covers various examples of corporate scandals. Promotional CSR information therefore can be scrutinized and criticized, as stakeholders know that companies are sometimes more concerned about “looking good” rather than “doing good”. Yet, to reap the reputational benefits of CSR, stakeholders will need to become aware of CSR initiatives. This requires companies to balance the need to inform stakeholders, while simultaneously trying to avoid the risk of a backlash of CSR communication.

In this course, students will first review the contemporary state of international CSR research from different theoretical lenses. Examples of topics that will be discussed include the different types of communication strategies and channels, the disclosure of CSR and when this can lead to perceptions of corporate hypocrisy and deception (i.e., ‘colorwashing’), engaging stakeholders such as consumers and employees in CSR, CSR initiatives in stigmatized industries, and collaborations with non-profit organizations.

In small groups, students will then develop and conduct a survey or an experiment on a research question related to CSR communication. The design of the method and the data collection will be done collectively, but each student will choose their own specific subtopic. This research workshop therefore helps students to practice and get familiarized with quantitative research. In the meetings, students will be guided through each step of developing and conducting a survey or an experiment, including SPSS data analysis and interpretation. </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: - The evolution, debates, and theories in international CSR scholarship;
- The multi-dimensional role of communication in CSR research and practice;
- Various quantitative research methods to examine CSR communication strategies.
- Design and conduct a small-scale empirical study about CSR communication using quantitative methods;
- Report the findings of their research project in a clear, comprehensive manner;
- Critically reflect on the limitations and implications of their research.</body>

column1: The statistics are very clear and pressing: if we want to reach the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), we still have a funding gap of a $ 2.5 trillion annually. We therefore need to find other ways to invest in the SDGs and to scale the impact as merely financial resources will not suffice. An increasingly relevant player in this field are Corporate Social Investors (CSIs); e.g. corporate foundations, corporate social impact funds and corporate social accelerators.

Why? Because these CSIs operate in between the business and the ultimate beneficiary and are in the unique position to leverage corporate resources such as financial means, products, services, technology and the corporate network for the public good. As companies realize that by only pursuing commercial strategies, our wicked problems will not be resolved, an increasing number of companies are implementing non-commercial strategies to contribute to society.

Indeed, CSI’s are formalized in a separate legal structure to safeguard that they put social impact at the core of their activities rather than financial return. As such, CSIs are aimed at “transforming patterns of thought, behaviour, social relationships, institutions, and social structure to generate beneficial outcomes for individuals, communities, organisations, society, and/or the environment beyond the benefits for the instigators of such transformation” (Stephan et al., 2016, p. 1252; italics added).

The aim of this course is to introduce students to Corporate Social Investments where social impact is at the core of the activities, rather than the financial return. We will discuss why companies pursue this strategy and why they set up these organizational structures. What is the role of these CSIs in society? What are their strategies? What can they do that the company cannot? And, how are these CSIs managed efficiently and effectively?
Module 1: Introduction and Corporate Social Investors in Europe
Module 2: Impact Only, Impact first or Finance First?
Module 6: Contemporary modes of corporate social investments.

In each module, we will be joined by an expert from the field. Guest lecturers in 2023 include representatives of Ikea Social Entrepreneurship, Philips Foundation, the Chocolonely Foundation, and Human Safety Net among others.
The sessions are on campus. Some guest lectures might take place online. Students are expected to attend all sessions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand why, when and how businesses choose for non-commercial strategies to create positive social change
• Explain the difference between finance first (or only) and impact first (or only) strategies and when (not) to pursue one above the other
• Argue why corporate social investors are (not) needed when companies implement their sustainability agenda (and/or adopt SDGs)
• Apply various theories (mostly organizational behavior theories) around corporate social investment on contemporary managerial issues of corporate social investors
• Defend and be critical towards an impact-first or impact only strategy that companies may seek in their sustainability portfolio

column1: The corporate strategy course aims to focus on the role that strategy plays in corporate development,  This follows closely after the competitive strategy course and in which students will explore additional elements such as portfolio strategy and restructuring, the importance and role of corporate strategy in heling firms on a growth path, as well as how firms should respond to global political and economic challenges while responding to the grand challenges faced by firms in the 21st century.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To evaluate critical concepts, tools and outcomes of strategy formulation and strategic management
• To apply strategy formulation in a real-life situation
• To apply tools and methods for formulating strategy
• To learn from high-level managers in the field
• To learn how to evaluate a firm’s strategic moves (e.g. diversification, divestitures) in terms of shareholder value creation

• Cultivating -via understating, remembering, analyzing, applying, evaluating, and creating- competencies related to expertise, by gaining invaluable and practical insights about managing innovation strategically; critical thinking, by applying the concepts and models of managing innovation strategically in preparing the team assignments of the course and evaluating various ideas in the debates and discussions in-class to develop viable solutions that are logical and evidence-based; collaborating, by cooperating with various individuals with different insights and backgrounds in doing the team assignments and engaging in presentations and debates in an open, safe, and reflective learning environment; communicating, by presenting novel ideas effectively and also engaging in debates and discussions to achieve tailored solutions that are viable and game-changing; and leadership & becoming a positive impact agent, by solving problems that make a difference in the society via innovation and leading change by leading purpose-driven innovations
• Evaluate firms’ non-market issues with strategic tools and methods
• Analyze key issues faced by firms in the non-market context
• Discuss different non-market strategies, as well as the integration of market and non-market strategies
